Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is an <vocabulary>evil woman</vocabulary>. Surprisingly, "mother in law" is not one of the meanings for this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That bitch sure has good ears!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの悪女、耳だけはいいんだよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: She is a wicked woman, but is always on time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かの女は悪女だが、いつも時間はきっちり守る。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The evil woman took my breath away. I was crazy about her.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その悪女は息をのむほど美しかった。僕は彼女に夢中だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s you also have <vocabulary>five hundred</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: Please memorize five hundred kanji by the end of March.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三月まつまでに、かん字を五百こおぼえてください。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本には五百円玉というものがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "How are we going to get five hundred horses into one car?" asked the woman. "You’re right! Do you think I should have brought the van instead?" the man replied.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「どうやって五百頭もの馬を車に乗せるっていうの？」と女が聞いた。「そうだよね。代わりにバンを持ってきた方が良かったかな。」と男は答えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>携帯</jp> refers to a mobile phone? This is a <kanji>strap</kanji> (<jp>ストラップ</jp>) for a mobile phone, making this a <vocabulary>cell phone strap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone strap</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>けいたいすとらっぷ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>けいたいストラップ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: けいたいすとらっぷ,けいたいストラップ
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of <jp>携帯</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The cell phone strap is so gross just thinking about it makes me puke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの携帯ストラップが気色悪すぎて、考えるだけでも吐きそうだわ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: What is a <kanji>child</kanji> of <kanji>bamboo</kanji>? That would be a baby bamboo. Because "baby bamboo" doesn't really make sense, we'll instead call this word <vocabulary>bamboo shoots</vocabulary>. P.S. Fresh bamboo shoots cooked on a fire are delicious, make sure you try them sometime.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the readings of the kanji for <jp>竹</jp> and the vocabulary for <jp>子</jp> you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m boiling bamboo shoots.
Context 1-JP: <jp>竹の子をゆでているところです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you go up north from the entrance of Mt. Fuji, there is a place where you can dig up a lot of bamboo shoots on your way.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふじ山の入り口から北の方にのぼっていくと、と中に竹の子が山のようにとれるところがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, man. It’s cool, it’s cool. Take all the bamboo shoots you want," said the panda.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「あ、お兄さん。わかりました。わかりました。竹の子、好きなだけ持って行ってください。」とパンダが言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji. So you should be able to read this word already.
Context 1-EN: This cat’s ears are brown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このねこの耳はちゃいろです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>パンの耳はわたしの大こうぶつです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I named my left ear Mimi. My right ear doesn’t hear very well, so I named it Mama.
Context 3-JP: <jp>わたしは、左耳をミミと名付けた。右耳はよく聞こえないので、ママと名付けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>eat</kanji> ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have <vocabulary>Japanese style food</vocabulary>. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some <jp>和食</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Well I like having Japanese style food for breakfast.
Context 1-JP: <jp>朝ごはんは、和食がいいですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There's been an increase in Americans who prefer Japanese cuisine to Western cuisine.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカ人の中にもさい近、よう食よりも和食がすきな人がふえている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Japanese style food doesn’t always mean sushi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>和食イコール寿司ってわけじゃない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, which is also the reading you learned when you learned this kanji!
Context 1-EN: I don’t like bugs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>虫はにが手です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That insect is spinning white thread from its mouth.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの虫、口から白い糸をはいているよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: No, that bug doesn’t bite. However, I will bite you if you still kill it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ううん。その虫は噛まないよ。でも、もし君がそれでもそいつを殺すって言うなら、僕が君のことを噛むよ。</jp>

Meaning: Japanese Style Clothes,Japanese Clothing,Japanese Style Clothing,Japanese Clothes
Meaning Mnemonic:
Japanese style clothes (Japanese Style Clothes). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing.

What kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some 和服.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You look good in Japanese style clothes too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>和服もに合ってるね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many Japanese style clothes do you have?
Context 2-JP: <jp>何ちゃく和服をもっていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Have you seen Japanese people running marathons in Japanese style clothes?
Context 3-JP: <jp>和服でマラソンをする日本人を見たことがありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know about <jp>大統領</jp> (<kanji>president</kanji>), right? Well, this is the <kanji>vice</kanji> version of the president, aka the <vocabulary>vice president</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word <jp>大統領</jp> first, though.
Context 1-EN: I think we should give it a try. You may not become the president, but maybe you’ll become the vice president.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やってみるべきだと思うけど。大統領は無理でも、副大統領ぐらいなら狙えるんじゃない？</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic:
In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap.

This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for <jp>膝小</jp> plus the on'yomi reading for <jp>僧</jp>. You've learned them all already, so you should be able to read this as long as you remember them all.
Context 1-EN: I fell off my bike and my kneecap hurts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自転車で転んで、膝小僧が痛い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I recently got a tattoo on my right kneecap.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近、右の膝小僧にタトゥーを入れたんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How's your kneecap?
Context 3-JP: <jp>膝小僧の調子はどうですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned already with the kanji. Huzzah!
Context 1-EN: There is a village nearby.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちかくに村があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Your mother was born in this village.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたのお母さんはこの村で生まれたのよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yes, I have definitely stepped in the horse poop in your village.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ええ、私はあなたの村で一度本当に馬糞を踏んでしまったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>village</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>. That isn't someone dancing while wearing construction worker clothes, that's a <vocabulary>villager</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses double kun'yomi for its reading, probably because it's like two separate words (village and person) put together into one big word. You should know these two kun'yomi readings (it's the main reading for <jp>村</jp> that you learned and you should know <jp>人</jp> by now), though you will need to look out for the rendaku'd <reading><jp>びと</jp></reading> reading.
Context 1-EN: The villagers are all old people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>村人は、年よりばかりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That line is kinda like something a villager would say in a fantasy game, isn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんかファンタジーゲームの村人っぽいセリフだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Pessimists say, "the glass is half empty," but the villager surprised me by shouting "Refill!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>悲観主義者は「もうコップ半分しかない」と言うが、その村人は「おかわり！」と言って私を驚かせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> refers to <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary> thing. This is the <vocabulary>number one</vocabulary> place you can get. In fact, it's simply the <vocabulary>best</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You should put your health first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分のけんこうが第一ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My first preference is Feb 14th and my second preference is Feb 21st.
Context 2-JP: <jp>第一きぼうは二月十四日で、第二きぼうは二月二十一日です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What was your first impression of the famous blowfish family?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの有名なフグ一家の第一印象はどうでしたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something has been <kanji>determine</kanji>d <kanji>beforehand</kanji>. What is this thing? This action? It is a <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Hey, can I make plans on Sunday?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねえ、日よう日、予定を入れてもいい？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The asteroid is on a direct path to Earth and is estimated to hit somewhere in the North Atlantic Ocean.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その小わく星は地きゅうに向かっていて、北大西ようのどこかにしょうとつする予定だ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hate when I schedule out my day, but nobody follows the script.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私がせっかく予定を立てても、誰もその通りに動いてくれないことが嫌です。</jp>

Meaning: Viewing Cherry Blossoms,Sakura Viewing,Cherry Blossom Viewing
Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>flower</kanji>s that you <kanji>see</kanji> you are viewing flowers. But not just any flowers. What flowers do Japanese people love viewing? That's right, this word refers to <vocabulary>viewing cherry blossoms</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this vocab is all kun'yomi, but you learned the kun'yomi readings of both these when you learned their kanji. So no worries there. You can spend the extra time viewing the cherry blossoms.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t go sakura viewing this year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ことしは花見にいかなかった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm gonna introduce you to the best cherry blossom viewing spots in Hokuriku region.
Context 2-JP: <jp>北りくち方の花見の名しょをごしょうかいします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Before I die, I want to have a drinking party under the cherry blossoms one more time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>死ぬ前にもう一度花見をしながら宴会がしたいなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>short</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>short</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What's a very short race? A midget car (みじか) race. Don't tell me you've never heard of midget car racing.
Context 1-EN: Isn't that skirt a bit too short?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのスカート、ちょっと短すぎるんじゃない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The baby's short, flailing arms and legs are so cute!
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんが短い手足をバタバタさせてるのは本当にかわいい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wah! I didn’t know your tail was shorter than mine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>わぁ！あんたの尻尾が私より短いなんて、知らなかったわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>起きる</jp> means "to wake up." This word, however, means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Think of it this way. When an action "wakes up" in a way it is occurring as well. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Just imagine a <reading>core</reading> (<jp>こる</jp>) of uranium just occurring out of nowhere to help you to remember this word.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as <jp>起きる</jp> too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.
Context 1-EN: I never expected something like this would happen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まさかこんなことが起こるなんて、思ってもみなかったよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please calm down and think carefully about what's taken place.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今起こったことについて、落ち着いてよく考えてみてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, do you want to kiss me?" "Absolutely no way would I ever want to kiss you in a million years. That would never happen even if heaven and earth were turned upside down."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、僕にキスしたい？」「ありえない。100万年経ってもあんたとキスなんて絶対にしたくないから。天地がひっくり返っても、起こりっこないよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Push open</kanji> the door to the conversation that is going to <kanji>be imminent</kanji> by saying the proper <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>salutation</vocabulary>. This word might also refer to a short <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> you give at an event or ceremony.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: You're such a good child for greeting people properly even though you're still so little.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ小さいのに挨拶ができて良い子だね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Greetings are an essential part of communication.
Context 2-JP: <jp>挨拶はコミュニケーションに欠かせない要素です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was in the area, so I came by to say hi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>近くにいたので、挨拶しに来ました。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Seen,To Be Visible,To Seem
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see. 見る means "to see," and 見える is to be seen or to seem. The "to be seen" meaning makes sense. The "to seem" meaning is a little odd, but if you think about it, you can figure it out. You have to see something to know what it seems like, which is why this also means "to seem."

Note: 見える could also be the potential form of 見る. In that context, this word would also mean things like "can see" or "visible." You won't get this word wrong if you put those in, but since this is a vocabulary word we're not actually looking for conjugations here.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you see the red flag over there?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこの赤いはたが見えますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't help thinking about how I seem to others.
Context 2-JP: <jp>他人からどう見えるのかがすごく気になってし方がない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The sun was so bright, I could barely see how high the balloon had risen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>太陽が眩しくて、風船がどのくらいの高さまで上がっていったのかほとんど見えなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. It's related to the meaning of the kanji <jp>見</jp> "see," but this one is about having someone else see something. In other words, it means <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read it.
Context 1-EN: What picture did the shop worker show the woman?
Context 1-JP: <jp>みせの人は、なんのえを女の人に見せましたか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: It seems tops that show a bit of skin are popular this summer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今年のなつは、すはだをチラリと見せるトップスが人気のようです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If I win this poker game, I’ll show you guys my Charizard card.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし俺がこのポーカーゲームでかったら、お前らに俺のリザードンのカードを見せてやるよ。</jp>

Meaning: Tokyo Metropolis,Tokyo Metro,Tokyo Metropolitan Area,Tokyo Metro Area
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Tokyo</kanji> <kanji>Metropolis</kanji> is, of course, the <vocabulary>Tokyo Metropolis</vocabulary>. Technically this is one of Japan's prefectures, but it's called a "Metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just <jp>東京</jp> and <jp>都</jp> (<jp>と</jp>). Really it's all just the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so you can think of it that way as well.
Context 1-EN: There are a lot of first-rate restaurants in the Tokyo Metropolitan Area.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京都には、一流のレストランがたくさんある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Taro Yamada (pseudonym), who is in his 30s and a salaryman in the Tokyo Metropolis, is working in an industry that is notorious for its hard work and long working hours.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京都の３０代会社員、山田太ろうさん（仮名）は、げきむと長時間ろうどうで知られるぎょうかいで働いています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The leaves started falling earlier this year than last year in Tokyo Metro’s Sumida Ward, where the Tokyo Sky Tree stands.
Context 3-JP: <jp>スカイツリーがそびえ立つ東京都墨田区では、今年は昨年よりも早く木の葉が落ち始めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>strike</kanji> or <kanji>beat</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to strike</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to beat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you're going to strike something over and over it makes a ta-ta (たた) sound. Imagine you're about to beat a steel drum, for example. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it?
Context 1-EN: You have a talent for beating drums.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ドラムを叩く才能がありますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Didn't I tell you to knock before opening the door?!
Context 2-JP: <jp>開ける前に、ドアを叩いてって言ったよね！？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Being hit with spiked bats really hurts!
Context 3-JP: <jp>釘バットで叩かれるのって、本当に痛い！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> you <kanji>see</kanji> is the <vocabulary>way of seeing</vocabulary> something. This is like when someone has a dumb opinion and you're like "oh, okay, so that's one way of seeing it..."
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the readings of the kanji you've already learned, even though they're kun'yomi.
Context 1-EN: I don't know how to look at this chart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このひょうの見方が分かりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are various ways of seeing and understanding.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いろんな見方やとらえ方があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you look at it from a different point of view, we could consider Tofugu to be tofu that's fugu flavor.
Context 3-JP: <jp>別の見方をすれば、トーフグは河豚味の豆腐だと考えることもできる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>dark</kanji> if you try to <kanji>write down</kanji> something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is <vocabulary>memorization</vocabulary>! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Even if you use rote memorization to memorize them in the short term, you'll forget them again quickly, won't you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>短期間で丸暗記しても、すぐわすれてしまうだろう？</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many digits of pi can you remember, Sakuragi?
Context 2-JP: <jp>さくら木さんは、円しゅうりつを何けた目まで暗記していますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: He's the class clown and is always playing the fool, but he is very good at memorization.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼はクラスのお調子者で、いつもボケているが、暗記力はすごい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a <kanji>person</kanji> is <kanji>kill</kanji>ed, you have yourself a <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There is some truth to that mother's motive for murder.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの母親の殺人の動きは分からなくもない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The company, which until now had specialized in online Japanese learning resources, has for the first time released a hard-core murder game.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今まで、オンライン日本語学習教ざいを専門としていた会社が、初めて本かくてきな殺人ゲームを発売しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: From a murderer's perspective, I am not very pleased with her because her methods of killing are so boring.
Context 3-JP: <jp>一人の殺人者として言わせてもらうけど、俺はあまり彼女を評価していないよ。殺人方法がつまらないからね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.
Context 1-EN: Shall I buy clams on my way back?
Context 1-JP: <jp>かえりに、貝をかってきましょうか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My body gets itchy when I eat shellfish.
Context 2-JP: <jp>貝るいやこうかくるいをたべると、からだがかゆくなります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I swallowed my engagement ring because I hadn’t noticed he put it in the oyster shell.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、牡蠣の貝殻の中に置かれていることに気付かずに、婚約指輪を飲み込んでしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lodge</kanji> you're staying in has a <kanji>topic</kanji> around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your <vocabulary>homework</vocabulary>. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's hard to see the answers to your homework because I'm looking at it from an angle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ななめから見てるから、宿題の答えが見えづらいんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you take a quick look at my homework from today, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日のわたしの宿題、ちょっと見てもらえないかな？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "But, Mom! I..." "No buts. Now go to your room and do your homework."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「でも、ママ！僕…」「つべこべ言わないの。さあ、自分の部屋へ行って、宿題をしなさい。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>feeling</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to feel</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?
Context 1-EN: Don't look at it, feel it with your heart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>見るのではなく、心で感じてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Due to the rising power of WaniKani, Tofugu feels that it's been losing its place within the company.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニの台頭により、トーフグは会社に自分のい場所がなくなっていると感じている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I feel like my older brother has been giving me the cold shoulder recently.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近兄に冷たくされていると感じます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>ちゃん</jp> is the honorific you put on a child's name. So, who is this mysterious child you're calling <kanji>red</kanji>? When a baby is born, what color are they? You got it, they're all red. And, because you want to be nice and cute you add <jp>ちゃん</jp> to that. That's why <jp>あかちゃん</jp> is a <vocabulary>baby</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the reading of the kanji 赤 you should know the reading of this too.
Context 1-EN: The baby girl was born without complications.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぶじに、女の赤ちゃんがうまれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This cute baby girl's name is Emma.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このかわいい女の子の赤ちゃんの名まえはエマちゃんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to see a picture of you from when you were a baby.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの赤ちゃんの頃の写真が見てみたいわ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Enough,To Be Sufficient,To Suffice
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leg</kanji> or <kanji>sufficient</kanji>, and we're going with the "sufficient" meaning for this word! This word means <vocabulary>to be enough</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the た portion. Whenever we need to remember the た we use the word "taco."

What do you have enough of? What is sufficient? Turns out it's tacos (た). Your bunker is filled with them and it's going to be enough to last the winter.
Context 1-EN: I wonder if this much will be enough.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これだけで、足りるのかな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Because the princess in Monaco is ignorant to most things, she thinks that 100,000 yen is enough to buy a car.
Context 2-JP: <jp>モナコの王女はせけんしらずなので、車をかうのに十万円もあれば足りるとおもっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I vow to drink enough wine to make something crafty with the corks tonight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今夜、ワインコルクで何か工作をするのに足りるだけのワインを飲むことを誓います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji <kanji>degree</kanji> can mean both degree in terms of angles and degree in terms of temperature. This word is how you talk about these things. Just attach it to a number and you have yourself the number of <vocabulary>degrees</vocabulary> that something is. After the numbers 1, 2 and 3 (and in some other situations) this can also mean <vocabulary>times</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the <jp>〜</jp> as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.
Context 1-EN: My brother has a cold and a fever of 38 degrees Celsius.
Context 1-JP: <jp>弟は、かぜで38度のねつがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What temperature do you usually set the AC to?
Context 2-JP: <jp>エアコンのおん度はいつも何度ぐらいにしていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think about 24 degrees is just right for me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>２４度ぐらいがちょうどいいと思うんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the verb version of the vocab word 戦い, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means to fight or to battle.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>戦い</jp> a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.
Context 1-EN: Japan and America fought in WWII.
Context 1-JP: <jp>第二次世界大戦で日本とアメリカは戦いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We battle against this gigantic monster called kanji every day so we can get good at Japanese.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしたちは日本語がうまくなるために、毎日このかん字というきょ大な化け物と戦っているんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Kendo is normally a one-on-one martial art, but 5 years ago Koichi had to fight against two guys at the same time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>剣道は通常、一対一で戦う武道だが、コウイチは五年前、二人の男を同時に相手にしなくてはいけなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No enemies here!
Context 1-EN: "Which side are you on, Fugu? Are you my enemy?" "I’m on your side, Salmon."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「フグ、あなたはどっちの味方なの？私の敵なの？」「僕は君の味方だよ、サーモン。」</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic:
The energy you hold in your body is your feelings. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling."

Now, don't confuse this with the future vocab word 気持ちいい which means "good feeling." This one just means "feeling" because it doesn't have an adjective attached to it, telling you more about this feeling that you're having.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji, though <jp>気</jp> is on'yomi and <jp>持ち</jp> is kun'yomi. One of those weird exception readings, but it'll work out for you anyway, as long as you're studying the kanji well enough.
Context 1-EN: I know exactly how you feel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの気持ちはよく分かります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I feel sick, like I'm going to throw up.
Context 2-JP: <jp>気持ちがわるくてはきそうです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Here’s a little something for you. This is just a small token of my appreciation. Go ahead, open it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これ、つまらないものですが。ささやかな感謝の気持ちです。どうぞ、開けてみてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You want things to <kanji>depart</kanji> from your store so you have to <kanji>sell</kanji> them. You put all these things up <vocabulary>for  sale</vocabulary>. You are <vocabulary>selling</vocabulary> these items.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’ve decided to sell bacon and okonomiyaki cheese tarts from Tofugu this summer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この夏、Tofuguから、「ベーコンとおこのみやきのチーズタルト」が発売されることが決定しました！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Portland's famous Tofugu tea, with the dirt of Koichi's nails, is now on sale on the Tofugu website!
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのつめのあかをせんじたポートランド名物トーフグ茶がトーフグのウェブサイトででぜっさん発売中です！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t wait until the Tofugu dating pillows are on sale.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguのデート用抱きまくらが発売されるのが待ち遠しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You hopefully have seen the word <jp>注文</jp> (order, request). This is just the verb version: <vocabulary>to order</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the reading of <jp>注文</jp> you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.
Context 1-EN: I ordered wrapping paper covered in silver glitter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>銀色のラメの入ったラッピングペーパーを注文しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ordered Koichi's used briefs on Amazon by mistake.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アマゾンで、間ちがえてコウイチの使用ずみブリーフを注文してしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We could eat out or order takeout. I don’t mind one way or the other.
Context 3-JP: <jp>外食でも、お持ち帰りで注文しても、僕はどちらでも構わないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To do a <kanji>concept</kanji> of an <kanji>image</kanji> (in your mind) would require you <vocabulary>to imagine</vocabulary> it, because it's just a concept and not real.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Every once in a while Koichi will move in an unimaginable way while he's working.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは仕事中、たまに想像できないような動きをする。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you imagine having a job where you visit temples and shrines to collect their red ink stamps in a book?
Context 2-JP: <jp>てらや神社をめぐってごしゅいんちょうにごしゅいんを集める仕事って、想像できる？</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you want to learn how to vomit without sticking your finger down your throat, just imagine Koichi naked.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし指を喉に突っ込む以外でゲロを吐く方法を学びたいなら、裸のコウイチを想像するといいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. This also includes the place where your <vocabulary>eyebrows</vocabulary> live: your <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're staring lovingly at your own eyebrows in the mirror when your mom walks in and you gasp, "Ma! You... (まゆ)" but you're in so much shock you can't finish the sentence, "Ma, you shaved off your eyebrows?!"
Context 1-EN: Eyebrow shape varies from person to person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>眉の形は人によって違う。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to get my eyebrow pierced soon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>早く、眉にピアス開けたいな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you know paying attention to how eyebrows move makes it easier to perceive facial expressions?
Context 3-JP: <jp>眉の動きに注目すると表情を捉えやすいって知ってましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji.
Context 1-EN: For your wedding ring which would you prefer: silver or gold?
Context 1-JP: <jp>けっこん指わは、銀か金、どちらにする？</jp>
Context 2-EN: No matter how old I get, I still like silver things.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いくつになっても銀せいひんがすきです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: At the red light a silver pick-up truck pulled up alongside me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>赤信号で、銀の軽トラが私の横に止まった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
Reading Mnemonic: The kanji here uses <jp>えき</jp> as both its on'yomi and kun'yomi, so no worries here. You can go to this station or that station, and both stations will use the same reading as the kanji it comes from.
Context 1-EN: Please get off the train at Shinjuku Station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新宿駅でおりて下さい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is a Tofugu pot sticker shop in front of Ueno Station that Koichi opened with one hundred million yen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>上野駅の駅の前にはコウイチが一億円かけて出店したトーフグやきぎょうざの店があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It was nice finally talking to you in person. I never thought I would run into you at a station.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ようやく直接お話することができてよかったです。まさか駅でバッタリお会いするなんて思ってもいませんでしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lodge</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>. It is also considered to be an <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>Yah do</reading> (<jp>やど</jp>) what you must to get <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>s for the night. Whether that's an <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary> or whatever. <reading>Yah do</reading> what you gotta do.
Context 1-EN: When I went there ten years ago, there weren't any lodgings like this at all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>十年前にそこをおとずれた時には、こんな宿は全くありませんでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We still haven’t decided on a hotel yet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>宿がまだ決まってないんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This inn is historically famous as well, so not only do inn guests visit but sightseers do as well.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この宿は歴史的にも有名で、宿泊客だけでなく見物客も訪れる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>power</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> isn't a samurai at all. A Samurai's all about precision, after all. So, imagine someone that's a huge mass of muscle (and fat). This Japanese warrior is all about power... ramming into people as hard as they can to knock them over. This person is a <vocabulary>sumo wrestler</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you want a sumo wrestler's autograph, why don't you go to Ryogoku?
Context 1-JP: <jp>力士のサインがほしいなら両国に行ってみたら？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The sumo wrestler kept patting down his bangs on our first date.
Context 2-JP: <jp>初デートで、力士はずっと前がみをなでつけてたんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for attending today’s conference regarding the repeated misconduct of our sumo wrestlers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お集まりの皆さん、本日は度重なる力士の不祥事に関する会議にご出席いただき有難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. <kanji>Confused</kanji> is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already <vocabulary>hurried</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary>, and things were <vocabulary>hectic</vocabulary>. So this adjective is what causes your confusion.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: December is a hectic season for restaurants.
Context 1-JP: <jp>十二月はレストランにとって慌ただしい時期だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Seriously, your older sister is such a frantic person, Katsuo-kun.
Context 2-JP: <jp>本当、カツオくんのお姉さんって慌ただしい性格ね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It was a hasty departure. I didn't even get to drink a cup of coffee.
Context 3-JP: <jp>出発が慌ただしく、コーヒーも飲めなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you have two heavy things, you have double and dual the heavy (compared to one, at least).

This word is a prefix attached to other words to show that it is "double." 二重 kanji time!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please draw double lines under kanji you don’t know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>分からないかん字の下に、二重せんを引いてください。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本は二重国せきをみとめていません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Well, let’s stop the small talk and cut to the chase. What was the topic of today’s meeting?" "We were going to talk about your double chin, sir." "Right, right. Let’s get started."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「それでは、世間話はそれぐらいにして、本題に入ろう。今日の議題は何だったかな？」「今日はあなたの二重あごについて話しをすることになっています。」「そうだったな。それでは始めようか。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> <kanji>phenomenon</kanji>. That's when energy is doing stuff in the sky and nobody understands it. That's the <vocabulary>weather</vocabulary> for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you explain the difference between forecasters and meteorologists?
Context 1-JP: <jp>気象予報士と気象学者の違いが説明できますか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A <kanji>foot</kanji> is a <vocabulary>foot</vocabulary>, you know?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

If you remember in the radical/kanji mnemonic, you kick someone with your foot. But what happens after you kick them? Turns out they were made of fire, and you just burned your foot off, turning it to ashes (あし). Imagine this happening.
Context 1-EN: I have a tattoo on my leg.
Context 1-JP: <jp>足にタトゥーがある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was a kid, I thought hands were feet and feet were hands.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは子どものとき、手のことを足、足のことを手だとおもっていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If I cut off my foot it will grow back soon, right?
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし私が足を切り落としても、すぐにまた生えてくるんだよね？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember that <jp>手</jp> can refer a "person" in some words? Well this is one of them. In this case, we have <kanji>choose</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, or perhaps a better way to think of it is like "chosen person." One situation in which you'd choose a person to do something is in sports, like in a schoolyard pick. Keep that in mind and you should be able to remember that this means <vocabulary>pro athlete</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sports player</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>選</jp> is what you'd expect. <jp>手</jp> is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen <jp>手</jp> using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.
Context 1-EN: Who is that handsome pro athlete?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのハンサムな選手はだれですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: These days, we can often see Japanese professional baseball players play in the major leagues.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近、日本人のプロ野球選手がメジャーリーグでもプレイするすがたがよく見られます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is magnificent pro kendo player.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは素晴らしい剣道の選手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji itself means <kanji>temporary</kanji>. When you add the <jp>に</jp> on there you're going towards temporary, which is <vocabulary>temporarily</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it:

Would you mind carrying (かり) this temporarily?
Context 1-EN: Even if Koichi said, "Tofugu’s female," I believe many users would have opposing opinions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>仮にコウイチが『トーフグはめすだ』と言っても、多くのユーザーはそのいけんに反対するんじゃないだろうか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If the worst were to happen to Tofugu, what would happen to lifetime members?
Context 2-JP: <jp>仮にトーフグにさいあくのじたいがおきたとしたら、ライフタイムメンバーの人たちはどうなるんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: What? Her boobs are made of balloons? Suppose that were true, who cares?
Context 3-JP: <jp>え？あの娘の胸は風船で作られているって？仮にそうだとしても、だから何なんだよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab is made up of a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it will usually take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So, from that you know that this word means <vocabulary>river</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You're in luck - the reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one you have to learn for this vocab!
Context 1-EN: There are a lot of fish swimming in this river.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この川には、さかながたくさんおよいでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Japan's longest river is Shinano River.
Context 2-JP: <jp>にほんいちながい川は、しなの川です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever I see a river, I get so pissed off.
Context 3-JP: <jp>川をみるといつもいかりがこみあげてくる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You visit your mom who lives inside of a car. It's sad, and you feel bad. The first thing that pops out of your mouth is: "Cool Room, Ma (くるま) because you don't know what else to say about your ma's living situation.

Be sure to sort of cut off the last letters of the first two words... something like "coo' roo' ma!" Sad thing is, there is only one room in this car your mom calls home.
Context 1-EN: I went to the ocean in my car on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日よう日に、車でうみにいきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wonder if somebody could give us a ride.
Context 2-JP: <jp>だれか車出してくれないかな？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My car wouldn’t be able to make it all the way to Florida.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の車は、フロリダまでもたないだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fee</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (or money, if you will) that you have to pay are your <vocabulary>fee</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>bills</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Are gas bills expensive in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本はガスの料金は高いですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's too hard to understand cell phone service fee plans. Could you explain them in a way that's clear and easy to understand?
Context 2-JP: <jp>けいたい電話の料金プランがふくざつすぎて分かりません。分かりやすくせつ明してくれませんか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m afraid this price is the best we can offer." "Well, that sounds fair. Okay, let’s finalize the deal."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「申し訳ありませんが、この料金が精一杯です。」「うーん。まぁ、妥当な値段のようですね。分かりました。これで手を打ちましょう。」</jp>

Meaning: As Much As You Want,All You Can
Meaning Mnemonic: Just <kanji>release</kanji> the <kanji>topic</kanji>... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and <vocabulary>as much as you want</vocabulary>. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next  couple levels.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Every time I go to an all-you-can-eat restaurant, I end up eating too much.
Context 1-JP: <jp>食べ放題に行くといつも食べすぎてしまいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If we go to karaoke, why don't we choose the plan where we can sing as much as we want until the morning?
Context 2-JP: <jp>カラオケに行くなら、朝まで歌い放題のプランにしようよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you purchase a lifetime subscription to Textfugu you can study Japanese as much as you want.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もしテキストフグの永久購読権を購読されるのであれば、日本語の学習がし放題ですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>reflect</kanji>. The verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be reflected</vocabulary>. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (<jp>る</jp>) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you 打つ (うつ) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: うつうつうつうつ.
Context 1-EN: The internal company document is being projected on the screen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スクリーンに社内用しりょうが映っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Looking at my own face reflected in the mirror I feel "how beautiful my face is" every day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>鏡に映った自分のかおを見て、「なんて美しいんだ」と毎日思っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A tear rolled down Koichi’s cheek when he saw the beautiful mountains reflected on the surface of the lake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは湖の水面に映る美しい山に感動し、ホロリと涙を流した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>child</kanji> who is a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> is just a child. A group of them is <vocabulary>children</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Ninety percent of the children were absent.
Context 1-JP: <jp>児童の九割が欠席しました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This the noun version of the kanji for <kanji>scent</kanji>. It also means <vocabulary>scent</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: Do you like the smell of leather jackets, senpai?
Context 1-JP: <jp>先輩、革ジャンの匂いは好きですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The odor of the bathroom is so strong that I don't want to breathe through my nose.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トイレは匂いが強すぎて、鼻で息をしたくない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This hot spring smells like banana.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この温泉は、バナナの匂いがする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji> shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is <vocabulary>insomnia</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Working with him is so stressful that I got insomnia.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼と仕事をするのがストレスで、不眠症になってしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be released</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this one from <jp>放す</jp> (to release) by thinking that it's pretty <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) for you to be released by your arch nemesis. He just let you go, strangely. How rare.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>放す</jp>. As long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here as well.
Context 1-EN: A horse was released from the stable.
Context 1-JP: <jp>馬が馬小屋から放れました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I worked hard and was finally released from my debts.
Context 2-JP: <jp>苦労して働いて、ようやくしゃっ金から放れることができました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I thought that I was finally free of having to care for my children but then my 53-year-old wife got pregnant again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ようやく子どもから手が放れたと思ったんだが、五十三歳の妻がまた妊娠してしまってね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an "-al" to a word (or a -like to a word). For example, add it onto <jp>日本</jp> (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like," which comes out to "Very Japanese." It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in, though <reading>-al</reading> and <reading>-like</reading> often do a decent job. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.
Context 1-EN: I personally thought I was able to give an American-style speech pretty well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分的には上手にアメリカ的なスピーチができたと思ってたんだけどな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I just personally love Koichi's mysterious smile.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの神ぴ的なえみが、こ人的にめっちゃツボなんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What do you mean by a Tofugu-like secret plan? Do you think you could be more specific?
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofugu的秘密計画って一体何ですか？もう少し具体的におっしゃって頂けませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The body part that lives between your <kanji>throat</kanji> and your <kanji>head</kanji> is your <vocabulary>larynx</vocabulary>. Otherwise known as the <vocabulary>voice box</vocabulary>, because your vocal cords live in there.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you really want to get a larynx work out, go to とう. It's loud, it's crowded, and you have to yell the entire time to get people to hear what you have to say. You also know 18 levels of kanji and you really want to shout them all out, which makes your voice box tired (but makes you happy).
Context 1-EN: The larynx is one part of the Adam's apple.
Context 1-JP: <jp>喉頭は、喉ぼとけの一部です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Laryngeal cancer is often caused by smoking and drinking.
Context 2-JP: <jp>喉頭ガンはたばこや飲酒が原因で起こることが多い。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Because of my laryngeal inflammation, it's painful for me to even breathe or drink water.
Context 3-JP: <jp>喉頭炎で息をしたり、水を飲んだりするのさえ苦しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>beforehand</kanji> <kanji>promise</kanji> is a promise you've made beforehand. This is a <vocabulary>reservation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>appointment</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could I make an appointment for a haircut and a perm?
Context 1-JP: <jp>パーマとカットの予約をしたいんですけど。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you're planning to go to Japan in 2020, you'd better book early because that's the year of the Tokyo Olympics.
Context 2-JP: <jp>2020年に日本へ行くなら早めに予約した方がいいですよ。その年は東京オリンピックがありますから。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are currently accepting advance reservations for Koichi's picture with his autograph. Among the people who made a reservation, we will offer three of you VIP tickets for Koichi's fan meeting in Hawaii. Please don't wait to reserve your spot!
Context 3-JP: <jp>ただ今、コウイチのサイン入りブロマイドの先行予約を受け付けております。予約された方の中から抽選で三名の方にコウイチのファンミーティングinハワイのVIPチケットをプレゼントいたします。皆様どしどしご応募ください！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>circumference</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You really want to measure the circumference of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy edge to measure.
Context 1-EN: I'm collecting coins with serrated edges.
Context 1-JP: <jp>周りがギザギザになっているコインを集めています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If there's something you love or are passionate about, you should stick with it regardless what the other people say.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大好きな事やむ中になれる事があるなら、周りが何と言おうと、それをやりつづけるべきだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm worried about what other people are thinking about me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>周りの目が気になるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Strike</kanji> your <kanji>head</kanji> against the floor to show your subservient respect by doing the <vocabulary>kowtow</vocabulary> bow. This is the most respectful bow you can possibly do. (Thank you China, for bringing this word into Japanese and thank you Japanese for bringing this into English.)
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

They used to make you kowtow every single time you came to とう. That's full on head to floor kowtowing in front of everyone who is already in とうきょう to prove that you appreciate being there. They might even make you do it these days too, if you're not being respectful enough while you're there.
Context 1-EN: "Kowtow" is what is called "dogeza" in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>叩頭とは、いわゆる日本の土下座のことです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Everyone in the room kowtowed toward the king.
Context 2-JP: <jp>部屋の中にいた全員が、王に向かって叩頭した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since the man refused to kowtow, he was put into a jail.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その男は、叩頭を拒否したため、刑務所に入れられた。</jp>

Meaning: Inside The Car,In The Car,In A Car,Inside A Car,Within The Car,Within A Car
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>inside</kanji> is simply that, <vocabulary>inside the car</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please wait in the car for a bit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと車内でまっていてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There was a fidgety-looking man with a Starbuck's cup on a bus in Seattle, but it was actually a handsome prince from Dubai.
Context 2-JP: <jp>シアトル市のバスの車内にスタバのコップをもったきょどうふしんな外人がいたとおもったら、ただのドバイのイケメン王子さまだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It seems like somebody left some bacon in the car.
Context 3-JP: <jp>誰かが車内にベーコンをいくつか忘れていったようだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: She who has <kanji>genius</kanji> <kanji>ability</kanji> has quite the <vocabulary>talent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The actors in this movie are all talented.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この映画に出えんしているはいゆうたちは、みんな才能があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you think you need to be talented to study a foreign language?
Context 2-JP: <jp>外国語を勉強するのに才能がいると思いますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You have a talent for throwing garbage into trash bins.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君はゴミをゴミ箱に投げ入れる才能があるね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>outside</kanji> the <kanji>example</kanji> doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: All the dishes at this restaurant are delicious without exception.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このレストランの料理は例外なくどれも美味しいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Except for a few exceptional cases, I haven't actually seen this hospital successfully complete the procedure.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きわめて例外のケースをのぞいて、この病院がその手術に成功したのをほとんど見たことがありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi usually sleeps in, but Friday is an exception because he has to wear a suit.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはいつも朝遅くまで寝ていますが、金曜日はスーツを着なくてはいけないので例外です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it:

Since you have generations of people making up this world, think of the rapper generation. What do they say all the time (obviously I don't know anything about rap)? They say "Yo yo yo!" (よ).
Context 1-EN: This app still isn’t world famous.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このアプリは、まだ世に出ていません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The world really is coming to an end.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まったく世も末だね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Other than assassins, nothing in this world is scarier than wasps.
Context 3-JP: <jp>暗殺者は別にして、スズメ蜂ほど怖いものはこの世の中にない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>bone</kanji> gets <kanji>fold</kanji>ed like paper, or something, you can bet you have a <vocabulary>broken bone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fracture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because <jp>こつ</jp> is shortened to <jp>こっ</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: This is a compound bone fracture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これはふくざつ骨折ですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi had a bad car accident last year. Not only did he break his legs, but he lost his head and now he's a robot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは去年ひどい自動車事こにあってね。足を骨折しただけじゃなく、頭まで失くしてしまって、今はロボットになっちゃったんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s been a while since we all got together. How have you been? Things are pretty much the same with me except I broke my pinky toe. Lol.
Context 3-JP: <jp>しばらくみんなで一緒に会ってないよね〜。最近どうしてるの？私は足の小指を骨折した以外は特に変わりないよ〜。（笑）</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>perfect</kanji> <kanji>finish</kanji> is when everything is at total <vocabulary>completion</vocabulary>. Nothing is left over and all is done.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Mission complete!
Context 1-JP: <jp>作戦完了！</jp>
Context 2-EN: The redevelopment that's been ongoing for a while in this town has finally been completed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この町でしばらくつづいていたさい開発工事がようやく完了した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll call you back when my cellphone battery has finished charging, okay?
Context 3-JP: <jp>携帯の充電が完了してから折り返してもいいかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>like</kanji> the <kanji>status</kanji> of what's in front of you. It has an excellent <vocabulary>shape</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>form</vocabulary> to it. Imagine something that would be pleasing to you in terms of its shape.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the <jp>かく</jp> reading, which gets changed to <jp>かっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Your style is pretty unique, eh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ずい文変わった格好だね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Your car has a nice shape!
Context 2-JP: <jp>格好のいい車ですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I don’t understand why Mikasa likes Eren. He’s arrogant, he’s inconsiderate, and he isn’t even good-looking." "Love is blind."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「何でミカサがエレンのことを好きなのか私には分からないわ。だって、エレンって傲慢だし、思いやりがないし、それに格好良くもないのに。」「恋は盲目っていうじゃない。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you wrap around the entire <kanji> circumference</kanji> of the <kanji>year</kanji> you've come back around to the start of it. This is the <vocabulary>anniversary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We're busy preparing for the anniversary event.
Context 1-JP: <jp>周年記念イベントの準備で忙しい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The next year is Tofugu's 10th anniversary, so Koichi is planning an anniversary project.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグは、来年で十周年になるので、コウイチは周年プロジェクトをけい画しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Next Sunday we’re celebrating Tofugu’s 15th anniversary at McDonald’s.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今度の日曜日に、私達はマクドナルドでTofuguの十五周年記念を祝います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A vocab made of a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) usually has the same exact meaning as the kanji it's made from. So by that you know that this vocab's meaning is <vocabulary>mountain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
When a vocab is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. To remember this word's reading we'll use a mnemonic.

What are you doing going up into the mountains? You're hunting for yams (やま). Go ahead, imagine yourself doing just that, climbing up the mountain (it's hard work!) and then digging in the ground with your hands, then pulling up that sweet, delicious yam! Mmm!
Context 1-EN: I'll climb a mountain with my friends.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ともだちといっしょに、山にのぼります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is the world's biggest man-made mountain.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これはせかい一大きい人工の山なんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: At 8 am, let’s meet naked on Bald Mountain.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あさ八じに、はだかではげ山にしゅうごうしましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you fold things at all sorts of angles you have quite a mess. It's not easy going through life with all these folds and angles. That's why this word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice and flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded :(

This can also mean valuable or kind.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the <jp>せつ</jp> changing to <jp>せっ</jp>, though. Another thing you have to go through <vocabulary>with trouble</vocabulary>, I'm afraid.
Context 1-EN: It's kind of you, but we're not making any more compromises on this matter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>折角ですが、これ以上妥協することは出来かねます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Are you going to throw away my kind advice?
Context 2-JP: <jp>おれの折角のちゅうこくをむだにするつもりなのか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Well, it’s a good opportunity to make a long-awaited change to my look, so I might as well get it shortened in the back by about 30 centimeters.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うーん。折角イメチェンするいい機会だし、後ろ髪を三十センチくらい切ってもらおうかな。</jp>

Meaning: To Replace,To Substitute For,To Substitute,To Be Replaced,To Be Substituted,To Be Substituted For
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>substitute</kanji>, so we can get to the meaning of this word through that: <vocabulary>To replace</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to substitute for</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the か portion.

You have to replace your car (か). It is getting old, and seems like it will explode at any moment, literally.
Context 1-EN: If you don’t mind, can I take your place?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしよければ、代わりましょうか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The prince found a new way to amuse himself, replacing kendama.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王子は、けん玉に代わるあたらしいあそびを見つけた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am looking for another genius to replace Steve Jobs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はスティーブ・ジョブズに代わる天才を探しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>good</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>favorable</vocabulary> thing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: Tofugu and the Japanese government have a good relationship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグと日本せいふは、良好なかんけいをたもっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Dr. Koichi told me that it's biologically favorable to be a dirty-minded person who doesn't talk about it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチ先生は、ムッツリスケベであることは生物学的に良好なことだっておっしゃってましたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The patient has been doing well for the last six months and has been able to live a normal life.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その患者さんの経過は過去六ヶ月間良好で、普段通りの生活を送ることができています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word has the kanji for <kanji>one</kanji> and <kanji>period</kanji>. You only have one period to live in so this is the only <vocabulary>lifetime</vocabulary> you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He made the company this much larger in just one generation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれは、一代でここまでかいしゃを大きくした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi went to take a once-in-a-lifetime gamble.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは一世一代の大しょうぶに打って出た。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He amassed an enormous fortune over the course of his lifetime and his son doubled it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は一代で巨額の財産を作ったが、彼の息子がさらにそれを二倍にした。</jp>

Meaning: To Say Humbly,To Say,To Humbly Say
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>Say</kanji> / <kanji>Say Humbly</kanji>. This is just the verb form, <vocabulary>to say humbly</vocabulary>. Please note that this is a very polite and humble way to say "to say" so it's used in especially polite situations. Because of this, it's probably going to be the <jp>ます</jp> form, which is <jp>申します</jp>. You can also call this "<vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>" as well, just remember that it's humble and polite!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. High Fives.
Context 1-EN: I am Koichi of Tofugu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグのコウイチと申します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu gives frank advice to young Japanese people!
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグが日本のわかものにモノ申す！</jp>
Context 3-EN: It goes without saying that my boss underwent gender affirmation surgery. Now she’s very happy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>申すまでもなく、私の上司は性転換手術をなされました。今の彼女は大変嬉しいそうだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>sad</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>sadness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading with <jp>悲しむ</jp>, hooray!
Context 1-EN: Koichi was nearly mad with sorrow at the loss of his cheese cake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、チーズケーキを失った悲しみで、気もくるわんばかりだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was overcome by grief when I heard the news of Pochi's death.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポチが死んだという知らせを聞いて、悲しみに打ちひしがれていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My sadness made me completely lose my appetite.
Context 3-JP: <jp>悲しみで食欲が全くわかなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>healing</kanji> <kanji>cure</kanji> will be great for <vocabulary>healing</vocabulary> sick people.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Cavities don’t just spontaneously heal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>虫歯が自然治癒することはありません。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic:
It's kind of like you're saying say say. This is what you say when you answer or greet someone on the telephone. There's a strange story about this. One reason you say 申し申し is because it's hard for foxes to say. So, you're confirming that the other person isn't a fox. The other explanation is that operators would say this, letting the person know on the other line that they're talking by saying "say say" but in a humble way. Either way, this is a telephone hello, so say it next time you talk to someone on the phone who is Japanese... just to make sure they aren't a fox.

We usually don't use kanji for this, so don't use it when you're writing. But you'll probably run into it in the wild so it's good to know!
Reading Whitelist: もうしもうし,もしもし
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.
Context 1-EN: Hello? Hanako?
Context 1-JP: <jp>申し申し、花子ちゃん？</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの、申し申し？きいていますか？？？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hello? This is Suzuki calling. Could I speak to Mr. Satou, please?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「申し申し。鈴木と申しますが、佐藤さんはいらっしゃいますか？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>回転</jp> means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>回転</jp> of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.
Context 1-EN: This Koichi doll revolves around this Viet doll at high speed by clockwork.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このコウイチ人形は、このビエト人形の周りを、時けい仕かけで高速で回転します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Michael can make the ball spin without touching it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルは、ふれずにそのボールを回転させることができます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The swivel chair rotates like this.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この回転椅子はこんな風に回転するんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fold</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to fold</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <vocabulary>fold</vocabulary> your <reading>o</reading>bi (<jp>お</jp>) really carefully and put it away with the rest of your kimono.
Context 1-EN: Please fold the gyoza skin over and make pleats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぎょうざの皮を半分に折って折り目を作って下さい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was folding origami at the cafe a girl approached me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きっ茶店で折り紙を折っていたら、一人の女の子が近よってきた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I was folding the paper I got a paper cut.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その紙を折った時に、指を切ってしまったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix.

There are similar words to this one, including 交じる which means "to be mixed" and 交わる which means "to intersect." This one is when you're doing the mixing. Like 交じる, the connotation is that the things being mixed are distinguishable from each other, like two types of fish, or books being mixed together. They don't become homogenous like paint or something would.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the ま portion. Who would mix things for you (like cakes and other goodies) growing up? That would be your Ma (ま).
Context 1-EN: Mix the cards up well, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トランプをよく交ぜてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why did you mix one woman into group with a bunch of men?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうしてたくさんの男たちの中に女を一人交ぜたんだ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s dangerous to mix tofu and puffer fish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>豆腐と河豚を交ぜるのは危険です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You have a ton of sunlight where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: hickory (ひかり) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.
Context 1-EN: The light from the sun is blinding, so please close the curtains.
Context 1-JP: <jp>太ようの光がまぶしいので、カーテンをしめてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In the moonlight, your teeth look just like pearls, Kanae.
Context 2-JP: <jp>月の光にてらされて、かなえちゃんの歯がまるでパールのように見えるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is still a slight glimmer of hope left for your child who was lost in North Korea.
Context 3-JP: <jp>北朝鮮で行方不明になったあなたの子供には、まだ微かに希望の光が残っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>nature</kanji> of <kanji>reason</kanji> is still <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had too much drink and I lost all sense of reason.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お酒を飲みすぎて、完全に理性を失ってしまっていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet said that nowadays even yakuza have to appeal to intellect instead of resorting to violence.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは、今時は、ヤクザもぼう力にたよるんじゃなく、理性にうったえなくっちゃダメだって言ってたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I understood it was hopeless, but I couldn’t hold on to reason.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ダメだと分かっていたが、理性を保てなかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>light</kanji>. What kind of light would this be? Obviously <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one uses the on'yomi readings, though <jp>にち</jp> gets shortened to <jp>にっ</jp>, so take note of that. Otherwise, you should be able to read this one!
Context 1-EN: Bathing too long in the sunlight isn’t good for your body.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日光をあびすぎるのは体によくない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm being as careful as possible to not get exposed to direct sunlight.
Context 2-JP: <jp>できるだけちょくしゃ日光にさらされないよう気をつけています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Seeing sunlight always makes me sneeze for some reason.
Context 3-JP: <jp>何故か日光を見るといつもくしゃみが出ます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do you <kanji>wear</kanji> to <kanji>heal</kanji> a really serious injury? An <vocabulary>adhesion</vocabulary>. Okay, so you don't actually wear these, but your body makes them for your insides to wear so you can heal. Nice job insides!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Were the risks of adhesion after surgery explained accurately to you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>手術後の癒着リスクについて、きちんと説明はなされましたか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word is the kanji same with hiragana attached, and it also means same.

It's a bit of an oddball among Japanese adjectives, because you don't need な or い to attach it to a noun. So it's usually considered to be a "special" な-adjective. Have a look at the context sentences to see it in action!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you think of the word "same" think same owner (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.
Context 1-EN: I meet the same person every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日、同じ人に会います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This exam was almost the same questions as last time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今回のしけんは、ぜん回とほぼ同じ内ようでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to make ramen that tastes the same as that shop’s no matter what.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの店と同じ味のラーメンがどうしても作りたいんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: <jp>着る</jp> (to wear), <jp>着く</jp> (to arrive), and now <jp>着ける</jp> (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to <jp>着る</jp>, right? In this case, this word is like <jp>付ける</jp>, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>着く</jp>'s reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with <jp>付ける</jp>, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc!
Context 1-EN: I wore earrings for the first time in a long time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>久しぶりにイヤリングを着けてみた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi has fun by secluding himself in his room and putting on masks from around the world every night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのしゅ味は、夜な夜な自分の部屋にこもって世界かく地のお面を着けてあそぶことです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you promise me that you will wear this good luck charm all the time, please?
Context 3-JP: <jp>このお守りを肌身離さず身に着けると約束してくれないか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means times. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be to revolve, to go around, or to rotate.

Bear in mind that this verb is intransitive, so it happens on its own. Something revolves or rotates, all by itself.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)" as they start to revolve around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.
Context 1-EN: I went around 18 holes with a customer today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、おきゃくさんと１８ホールを回りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That 100 yen coin is still spinning on the desk.
Context 2-JP: <jp>百円玉はまだつくえの上で回っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Those kittens revolve around their mother like the planets revolve around the sun.
Context 3-JP: <jp>惑星が太陽の周りを回るように、その子猫たちが親猫の周りを回っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's <vocabulary>for example</vocabulary>. So, you could start a sentence with this and be all like "<jp>例えば</jp>, I am using <jp>例えば</jp> in a sentence."
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "<vocabulary>for examples</vocabulary>" like this, you were <reading>taught</reading> (<jp>たと</jp>) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...
Context 1-EN: For example, let's say there was a person who used to be very popular but isn't at all anymore.
Context 1-JP: <jp>例えば、昔はすごく人気があったけど、今は落ちぶれてしまった人がいたとしましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: For instance, what do you think Koichi would say when he almost bit his tongue?
Context 2-JP: <jp>例えば、舌をかみそうになった時、コウイチなら何て言うと思う？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, Sakura, why don’t you come over to my house, like, once or twice a week or something?
Context 3-JP: <jp>なぁ、さくらちゃん、例えば、週に一度や二度ぐらい、うちに来ないか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of your <kanji>thought</kanji>s are very small. You've thought of everything you possibly can to solve this problem. In the end, the remainder of your thoughts is left with one phrase: "<vocabulary>too bad</vocabulary>." There's nothing else to think but the remainder.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That's so unfortunate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは残念すぎる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was such a rare chance, so it's too bad that I missed it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>折角のチャンスだったのに、残念です。</jp>
