Context 3-EN: "Is it true that I have to eat spiders on this TV program?" "Unfortunately, it is."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「このテレビ番組のために私が蜘蛛を食べなくちゃいけないって、本当？」「残念ながらそのようです。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus <jp>つ</jp> on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for <kanji>seven</kanji> plus <jp>つ</jp>. So, this one is <vocabulary>seven things</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion).

What thing do you have seven of? The seven things that you have are seven Nanas (なな). These are your grandmas, cloned. Just think, "It's lucky to have seven nanas. They can all cook my favorite foods for me!"
Context 1-EN: There are seven apples in a box.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はこのなかにりんごが七つあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Just the two of us ate seven melons.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二人でメロンを七つたべました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After I count to seven, I will be a woman.
Context 3-JP: <jp>七つかぞえると、わたしは女になる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>many</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>many</vocabulary> (or you could say <vocabulary>much</vocabulary>). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Think of something that is many. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "おお!!!" as you get smushed.
Context 1-EN: There is too much food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このりょうりは多すぎます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are many people who firmly believe that they are right.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「自分は正しい」とおもいこんでいる人は多い。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wasn’t able to sleep because there were far too many people on the train, so I just sang loudly instead.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電車にはとても多くの乗客が乗っていたので、眠ることはできなかったが、大声で歌うことはできた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus <jp>つ</jp> on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for <kanji>one</kanji> plus <jp>つ</jp>. So, this one is <vocabulary>one thing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion).

So, you have one thing. What one thing do you have? You have one of He-Man's Toes, aka a single He-Toe (ひと). So what's the thing you have only one of? You have one He-Toe. Imagine He-Man walking around with one missing toe, trying to find you so he can get it back. At least you'll be able to run faster than him now.
Context 1-EN: Choose one answer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こたえを一つえらびます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's limited to one per customer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お一人さま一つかぎりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I met a one-eyed goblin yesterday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>きのう、一つめこぞうにあった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>low</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>low</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You look down and very low to the ground is a man, looking up at you. Your friend is there too, but you don't know this little man. Your friend says "He coo', he coo," referring to the low to the ground man.
Context 1-EN: I like a guy with a low voice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>低い声の男の人が好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our daughter is a little shorter than average.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちのむすめは、平きんよりやや身長が低いんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, Yuki. You don’t look so good." "Yeah, I know. I was diagnosed with hypotension." "What’s that?" "It just means that my blood pressure is really, really low." "How low is that?" "Well, this morning was about 80/40."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、ゆきちゃん。あんた、あまり元気じゃなさそうね。」「うん。そうなの。低血圧症って診断されたわ。」「何それ？」「つまり、私の血圧がめちゃくちゃ低いってこと。」「どれくらい低いの？」「えっと、今朝は上が80で下が40ぐらいだったかな。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When there's <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, what are they? Well, they're either just going to be simply <vocabulary>one person</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>alone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this vocab doesn't follow any rules you learned previously. It's an exception, which means you have to learn the reading separately too. Spend a few moments trying to remember this word, look away for 10 seconds, and then try to recall its reading. Could you do it? Try again, this time in thirty seconds. Did you do it again? Okay, go ahead and move on. You may know it now, though you'll need to recall it again in the next 5-10 minutes if you want to remember it for good.

Alternatively, if you know the reading for the vocab word 一つ (in the same level as this word), you can know that it uses the same reading!
Context 1-EN: I went to karaoke alone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一人でカラオケにいきました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>一人はアメリカ人です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My daughter did the errands by herself for the first time today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>むすめは、きょうはじめて一人でおつかいにいきました。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Lower,To Fall,To Drop,To Come Down,To Hang Down
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means below so this means something gets lower, by falling or dropping. For example: Prices get lower or fall. Squirrels come down from trees. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to get lower or to fall.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji:

You know it means to fall so instead of using a saw (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)
Context 1-EN: Stock prices all over the world fell.
Context 1-JP: <jp>せかいじゅうのかぶかが下がった。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>ねつが三十七どに下がりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Unfasten your belt so that your pants will hang down.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ズボンが下がるようにベルトをゆるめなさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Robber</kanji>s who sail on the high <kanji>sea</kanji>s are <vocabulary>pirate</vocabulary>s! Arrr!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: During the voyage they were attacked by pirates.
Context 1-JP: <jp>航海の途中で海賊に襲われました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? <vocabulary>Maybe</vocabulary>. How about this one? Hmm, <vocabulary>maybe</vocabulary> that one too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Maybe the umbrella is outside.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かさは、多分外にあります。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>多分、レイヤーさんなのかもしれないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s probably going to snow tomorrow, so let’s make a snowman.
Context 3-JP: <jp>明日の夜は多分雪になるから、雪だるまを作ろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>separate</kanji> <kanji>separate</kanji> you're putting things off into their own areas. You're marking them off <vocabulary>separately</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>individually</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the <jp>べつ</jp> reading you know, twice.
Context 1-EN: They're twins, but they each think separately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二人はふた子だが、いつもそれぞれ別々なことを考えてる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please plant this separately from the cactus.
Context 2-JP: <jp>サボテンとは別々にしてうえて下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Now do we really have to go our separate ways?" "Yup, but I believe we’ll see each other again soon."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「私達、本当に別々の道を進まなきゃいけないの？」「ああ。でもまたすぐ会えるさ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Lower,To Hang,To Lower Something,To Hang Something
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means below so the verb version of that is when you put something below you. It's to lower something.

This is a transitive verb, which means that the verb is done by one entity onto another. In other words, you lower something. Like your impossibly high expectations for yourself. Take it easy!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want to lower a tree so you need a saw (さ). Lower the tree to the ground gently while you slowly saw it down!
Context 1-EN: Please tell me how to lower my blood pressure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>けつあつを下げるほうほうをおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That shop has one wind chime hanging in its entrance.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのみせは、入り口にふうりんを一つ下げています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I tried to perform a rain dance to lower the temperature.
Context 3-JP: <jp>きおんを下げるために、あまごいダンスをおどってみた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>labor</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's <vocabulary>manual labor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How many hours do you work per week?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの労働時間は週何時間ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband is old, so manual labor would be a bit too hard for him.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの主人は年なので、肉体労働はちょっとさすがにきびしいかも。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You know what I need? A man cave and a new car. I need to properly reward myself for my labors.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺には何が必要か知ってるかい？趣味の部屋と新しい車だよ。労働の対価をきちんと受け取る必要があるだろ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>every</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji> to combine into <vocabulary>every year</vocabulary> (<vocabulary>yearly</vocabulary> works as well).
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for 毎 is what you'd expect. The reading for 年 is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab 年 to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours.

That being said, the reading まいねん works as well. I don't like this one as much as まいとし but it's equally acceptable.
Context 1-EN: Where does Yamada go for her trip every year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>山田さんは、毎年どこにりょ行に行きますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: That singer hints at retiring every year, so he must be saying it again this time just to get people to react.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのか手は毎年引たいを口にしているので、きっと今回もただのつりでしょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve built a new door for the Johnson family every year for the past decade. Why don’t they just stop letting the troll use it?
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、ジョンソンさん一家のために、10年間毎年新しい扉を建てている。どうしてジョンソンさんたちはトロールに扉を使わせないようにしないのだろうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus <jp>つ</jp> on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for <kanji>nine</kanji> plus <jp>つ</jp>. So, this one is <vocabulary>nine things</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion).

What thing do you have nine of? The nine things that you have are nine coconuts (ここの). Imagine yourself juggling nine coconuts in the air. Try counting them while you're doing this, arriving at nine things.
Context 1-EN: There are nine questions that require a dictionary on today’s test.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きょうのテストには、じしょをつかうもんだいが九つあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is it true that a cat has nine lives?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ねこには九つのいのちがあるってほんとう？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I made nine donuts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ドーナツを九つつくった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

"Everyone, we have rice! Come (こめ) and get it!"
Context 1-EN: I forgot to buy rice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>米をかうのをわすれてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that the weight of 100 million yen is about 10kg, so I tried to imagine what it would be like to hold 100 million yen while holding a bag of 10kg rice.
Context 2-JP: <jp>１おく円のおもさはやく１０キロときいたので、１０キロのお米のふくろをだきしめながら、１おく円をもっているところをそうぞうしてみた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My favorite breakfast consists of uncooked rice and miso soup.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の一番好きな朝ごはんは、生米と味噌汁です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: The small bird flapped its wings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小とりは、羽をパタパタうごかしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have eaten deep-fried chicken wings before, but I've never eaten deep-fried butterfly wings.
Context 2-JP: <jp>手羽先のからあげはたべたことがあるけど、ちょうちょうの羽のからあげはたべたことがありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you know what kind of bird this feather is from?" he asked me, holding out some of his own nose hair.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「この羽、どの鳥の羽か分かるかな？」と彼は自分の鼻毛を持ちながら聞いてきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus <jp>つ</jp> on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for <kanji>two</kanji> plus <jp>つ</jp>. So, this one is <vocabulary>two things</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion).

So what thing do you have two of? The two things that you have consist of one foot and another foot (ふた). Remember from the on'yomi how you had two knees (for the reading に)? Now look further down your leg at one foot then over to the other foot. Two foot!
Context 1-EN: It’s two dialogues.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二つのかいわです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please put two apples in this basket.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このカゴにリンゴを二つ入れてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: His second evil deed was the frog’s assassination.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かれの二つめのあくぎょうは、かえるのあんさつだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>two</kanji> and <kanji>person</kanji> and then put them together, what do you get? You get a <vocabulary>pair</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>two people</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is quite strange. If you know <jp>二つ</jp>'s reading, you can use that to remember the <jp>二</jp> part (<jp>ふた</jp>). But, the <jp>り</jp> that is the <jp>人</jp> is a total exception, something you won't see too often (though you may have seen it in <jp>一人</jp>). If you can use the reading of <jp>一人</jp> (aka if you've learned it already) then definitely use that. If not, do your best to remember the reading on your own. It's a strange one that doesn't connect to much else.
Context 1-EN: I am watching a DVD with my older sister.
Context 1-JP: <jp>DVDを、あねと二人でみています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Those two want to be a couple all the time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの二人はいつも二人でくみたがる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She was arrested for double murder.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かのじょは二人ごろしでたいほされた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word follows the "number of things" pattern where there's a kanji for a number plus <jp>つ</jp> on the end. Whenever you see this, you know the word means "____ things." Knowing that, as long as you know the kanji (which you do) you can figure out what number of things it is. For this one, it's the kanji for <kanji>eight</kanji> plus <jp>つ</jp>. So, this one is <vocabulary>eight things</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since all of the "number of things" words all follow the same pattern (number plus つ), you really just have to remember the part before the つ (and then remember that the つ is in all of these). All of the readings are the kun'yomi reading, which means we'll have to use a mnemonic to remember them (you know the on'yomi reading of the kanji portion).

So what eight things do you have? You have eight yachts (やっつ). Go ahead and count them. They're beautiful. Also, be sure not to be confused by this particular reading mnemonic. It includes the つ, even though the つ is outside the reading you need to learn (just makes things easier for you overall). Since you can see the つ outside, it shouldn't be too difficult for you.
Context 1-EN: There are eight potatoes in a bag.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ふくろには、じゃがいもが八つ入っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are only eight of them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>八つしかありませんよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What has eight faces and six arms?
Context 3-JP: <jp>八つのかおと六つのうでがあるもの、なーんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a kanji is alone and doesn't have any okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it's usually going to take the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. So in this case, you know that this word means <vocabulary>woman</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
When a word is a single kanji with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it tends to use a kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji itself, so let's use a mnemonic to remember the vocab word.

There's a woman in front of you. Who is she? She's the woman who lives on Ninth (おんな) Street!
Context 1-EN: Who is that woman?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの女はだれ？</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは女です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want a woman who will help look after my children.
Context 3-JP: <jp>おれはこどもをせわする女がほしい。</jp>

Meaning: To Think About,To Consider,To Give Thought
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think, so the verb version is to think about or to consider.

Note that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う.
Reading Mnemonic: If you want <vocabulary>to think</vocabulary>, the best way to do so is to do the <reading>conga</reading> (<jp>かんが</jp>). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.
Context 1-EN: Please let me think about it a little.
Context 1-JP: <jp>少し考えさせてください。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>考えるな！かんじろ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: My daughter thinks that the movie Titanic would have been better if the ship never sank and everyone went to Disneyland instead.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の娘は、もしタイタニック号が沈まなければ、みんなその代わりにディズニーランドに行くことができて、もっといい映画になったのにと考える。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do you call <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji>? You call it <vocabulary>beef</vocabulary> (what's for dinner?).
Reading Mnemonic: Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: I got off the train at a station near my home and went to the grocery store to buy beef.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いえのちかくのえきででんしゃをおりて、スーパーに牛肉をかいに行きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Last year, the import of UK beef was resumed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>去年、えいこくさん牛肉のゆ入がさいかいされました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The beef is so undercooked. I may have a kitchen nightmare tonight because of this.
Context 3-JP: <jp>牛肉はありえないくらい生焼けだ。この牛肉のせいで今夜はキッチンの悪夢を見ることになりそうだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab word is made up of a single kanji and that's it, it almost always takes the meaning from its parent kanji. So, this vocab word also means <vocabulary>power</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
When a vocab word is a single kanji all alone with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading with the kanji, so for this vocab word, we'll use a mnemonic.

The most powerful man in the world. All his power came from his cheek (ちから). Imagine him blowing up his cheek like a giant balloon, then unleashing his power on you. Thwap thwap thwap thwap.
Context 1-EN: I’m hungry and losing strength.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おなかがすいて、力がでない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That American woman has the power to move Mt. Fuji.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのアメリカ人の女にはふじ山をうごかす力がある。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mom is more powerful than the rest of my family put together.
Context 3-JP: <jp>おかあさんは、のこりのかぞくがたばになってもかなわない力をもっている。</jp>

Meaning: Sky Blue,Light Blue,Aqua Blue,Sky Blue Color,Light Blue Color,Aqua Blue Color
Meaning Mnemonic: You'd think that <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is <vocabulary>sky blue</vocabulary> in English. <vocabulary>Light blue</vocabulary> works as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>水</kanji> and the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>色</kanji>. For <jp>水</jp> you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For <jp>色</jp> it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I want that light blue bag.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの水色のバッグがほしいんですが。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu T-shirt is breezy sky blue.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのTシャツは、さわやかな水色です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why is the sky light blue today?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして今日の空は水色なんだろう？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adjective form of <kanji>big</kanji>. It has the same meaning, though it is a word for describing. Words that end with <jp>い</jp> are often adjectives, remember that for future words as well. So, as long as you know the meaning of this kanji, you can transfer that to the meaning of this word. It's the adjective <vocabulary>big</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>large</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What do you do when you see something really, really big? You say おお because you can't believe your eyes. Imagine something really large and say おお out loud to help seal the memory in that brain of yours.
Context 1-EN: This hat is too big.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このぼうしは大きすぎます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can I get those two big peaches?
Context 2-JP: <jp>その大きいももを二つください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My baby is about as big as a calf.
Context 3-JP: <jp>わたしのあかちゃんは、こうしとおなじくらい大きい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your home is out in the middle of a <kanji>coarse</kanji> looking <kanji>field</kanji>. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's <vocabulary>rustic</vocabulary>. That's pretty <vocabulary>rude</vocabulary> of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She’s never treated another person rudely.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、決して他人に対して粗野に振る舞うことがなかった。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well - that is the unit of time, <vocabulary>second</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji. It's presumably because it's usually attached to other things, like numbers, making it act more like a jukugo word would. Anyway, you should only need a <vocabulary>second</vocabulary> to learn this reading, since you should already know it.
Context 1-EN: I sent a LINE message to Koichi and he replied to me in a second. That made me chuckle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチにラインしたら秒で返事きてわらえた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I go to bed, I usually fall asleep in three seconds.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大体いつも、ふとんに入ったら三秒でねてる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your pronunciation can reach native-level in just twelve seconds.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの発音をたったの十二秒でネイティブレベルにしてみせますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Yesterday, the wind was so strong that all the leaves fell off of the trees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのうは風が強かったので、木から葉が全部落ちてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In fall, the leaves on the trees had changed to different colors.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あきになって、木の葉の色が色んな色にかわってきた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I made furikake with daikon leaves.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大根の葉でふりかけを作りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go</kanji> so the verb form of this is <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle."

You want to go somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An eagle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.
Context 1-EN: I'm about to go shopping.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今から、かいものに行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Something came up, so I'm not able to make it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ようじができて、行けなくなってしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wouldn’t want to go to Mars because they don’t have Taco Bell there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>タコベルが無いので火星には行きたくない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.
Context 1-EN: I already forgot the face of the travel agent I met yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのう会ったりょ行会社の人の顔をもうわすれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi has very defined facial features, don't you think?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチって、顔がこいよね？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, buddy. Are you picking a fight with me? Why are you staring at me like that?" "Well, your face looks really pale. Are you okay?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「おい、お前。何か文句でもあんのか？ジロジロ見てんじゃねぇぞコラ。」「えっと、あなたの顔、かなり青く見えるんですが、大丈夫ですか？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You know that the kanji 下 means down and that さい sounds like the word "sigh." You need to ask someone for something, so you look down, sigh, and say please give me that thing. You're ashamed that you have to ask. But you still need it. Please, please give it to me!

We only use this kanji version of ください when we're asking for something, that's why it's "please give me." If you're just saying "please" you don't need the kanji at all!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exceptional reading. You just have to be able to recall the <jp>くだ</jp> part, though (since <jp>さい</jp> is already there in the form of the hiragana). So, think about why you have to be polite to this misbehaving kid. Turns out, if you don't, he has the power to initiate a <reading>Coup d'é</reading>tat against you and your family, who runs the government. Just imagine yourself thinking over and over "Okay... I have to be nice to this kid. If I don't... he'll initiate a Coup d'état... and that would ruin my family..." You're walking on thin ice, here.
Context 1-EN: Please give me that one.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それを下さい。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>りんごを二こ下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please give me a million yen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ぼくに百万円を下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means <kanji>go</kanji>. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the <jp>き</jp> to help you to remember that this word means <vocabulary>train direction</vocabulary> (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (<jp>き</jp>) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "<vocabulary>bound for</vocabulary>" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station."
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way:

Just think about the train direction that you (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.
Context 1-EN: One shinkansen ticket for Shin-Osaka, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しん大さか行きのしんかんせんのきっぷをください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm thinking of walking both ways.
Context 2-JP: <jp>行きもかえりもあるくつもりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This train is bound for Tofugu Office Station.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この電車は、Tofuguオフィス行きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>向く</jp> and <jp>向ける</jp> by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add <jp>向け</jp> to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's <vocabulary>made for</vocabulary> them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's <vocabulary>aimed at</vocabulary> them, it's made for them. See the connection?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <jp>向く</jp> so work off of that word to be able to read this one.
Context 1-EN: This work isn’t intended for children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは子ども向けの作ひんではないですよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This curry was made for Japanese tastes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このカレーは、日本人向けのあじですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Aren’t the underpants Koichi is wearing for children? He’s outgrown his clothes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチが履いてるパンツは、子供向けなんじゃないのか？ツンツルテンだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Throw</kanji> a <kanji>ballot</kanji> in the ballot box <vocabulary>to vote</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using <jp>投</jp> to remember the on'yomi reading, <jp>投資</jp> for example.
Context 1-EN: In this company, every year all the workers have to vote to choose the CEO.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この会社では、毎年CEOを選ぶために全社員が投票することになっている。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji> is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a <vocabulary>tank</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Our city decided to use a tank instead of a garbage truck.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの市では、ゴミしゅう集車の代わりに戦車が使われることになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We have to wash this tank soon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この戦車、そろそろせん車しないとなぁ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "How are the tires on my tank?" "I think you should either pump them up a lot more or switch to tank treads."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「俺の戦車のタイヤ、どう？」「もう少し空気を入れるか、戦車用の履帯に換えた方がいいと思いますよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business.
Context 1-EN: The building on the west side of the hospital is my apartment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>びょういんの西のたてものがわたしのアパートです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>ダリンは、西にむかっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Meanwhile in West Portland, the Crabigator was crossing the road.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その頃、西ポートランドでは、鰐蟹がその道を渡っていた。</jp>

Meaning: To Chirp,To Bark,To Make An Animal Sound
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chirp</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to chirp</vocabulary>. Alternatively, this word can also be used for the sounds other animals make as well, though the primary definition has to do with birds chirping (it has bird right in the kanji, after all).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. So, spend more time chirping and less time memorizing, okay?
Context 1-EN: The puppy is barking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子犬がワンワン鳴いています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The guy mimicking a rooster's cock-a-doodle-doo over there is our president.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あそこでコケコッコーとおんどりが鳴くまねをしているのが、うちの社長です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s go to the new, chic Japanese restaurant tonight. Did you know that it has a few cute Japanese bush warblers singing with their beautiful voices?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今夜、あの新しい洒落た日本食レストランに行こうよ。知ってた？あそこには、ホーホケキョと美しい声で鳴く鶯も何羽かいるんだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the right side," for example. That would be <jp>右側</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!
Context 1-EN: There is a diner next to the cafe.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きっ茶店の横に、食どうがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If a robber breaks into the Tofugu office, just run to Koichi's desk and crouch down next to it because it's the safest spot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もし強とうがトーフグのオフィスにやって来たら、コウイチのデスクまで走ってその横にしゃがみこむんだ。そこが最も安全な場所だからね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: During my afternoon nap I sleep on my side.
Context 3-JP: <jp>午後の仮眠の間に横向きに寝る。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hear</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need to hear something very important, but you can't. In order to hear, you have to take a key (き) and unlock the doors covering your ears. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing that, focusing on the key.
Context 1-EN: We are going to listen to the text.
Context 1-JP: <jp>テキストを聞きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's ask the teacher since we don't understand this Japanese.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この日本語は分からないから先生に聞きましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Listen to me, Amy. This is not your fault. He is not justified in sleeping with someone else just because you two had a fight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねえ、聞いて、エイミー。これはあなたのせいじゃないわ。だって、ケンカしたからって、他の人と寝ていい正当な理由にはならないでしょ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji <kanji>sick</kanji> to another word, you're saying what kind of <vocabulary>sickness</vocabulary> it is; you are mentioning what <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary> it is.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I suffer from Ménière’s disease, so I often get dizzy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>メニエール病をわずらっているので、よくめまいが起きるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The reason I haven't been able to get further than Level 1 on WaniKani must be because I have "can't-learn-foreign-language" syndrome.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ぼくがワニカニレベル1から全ぜん進めないのはきっと外国語できない病にかかったからにちがいない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t make a big deal out of what he said. It’s definitely a lie that he’s suffering from an incurable disease.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼の言ったことを大袈裟に考えないで。難病で苦しんでるなんて明らかに嘘なんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>effective</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be effective</vocabulary> (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).
Reading Mnemonic: What is particularly effective? It's your <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>). It's effective at opening your house door.
Context 1-EN: I’m looking for the most effective medicine for treating lung cancer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>肺癌の治療に最も良く効く薬を探しています。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: When you ask <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>people</kanji> you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking <vocabulary>how many people</vocabulary>. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that <jp>何</jp>, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for <jp>何</jp> and the on'yomi reading for <jp>人</jp>. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that <jp>人</jp> uses its <jp>にん</jp> reading here.
Context 1-EN: How many people participated in the party?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのパーティーには、何人の人がさんかしましたか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many people have been killed by the killer fish in this pond?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今までこの池で何人の人々がさつ人ぎょにころされましたか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How many people will be joining us for dinner?
Context 3-JP: <jp>夕食にはいったい何人の人がやって来るんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>当て</jp> means something like <kanji>to guess correctly</kanji>. <jp>字</jp> means <kanji>letter</kanji>. So, this is a letter you guessed correctly. This refers to <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>, which are kanji that are used in words simply for their sounds, not for their meanings. They are there to be phonetic, and that is all. That is why this word refers to <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi reading for <jp>字</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>当て</jp>. You've seen <jp>当てる</jp> in the past, though, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.
Context 1-EN: "利休酒" are the phonetic kanji used for "liqueur."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「リキュール」には、「利休酒」という当て字が使われます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Lately, there've been a lot of kids with bizarre names using phonetic kanji.
Context 2-JP: <jp>近ごろは、当て字を使ったキラキラネームを持つ子どもがたくさんいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Sometimes kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored as in 亜米利加 (アメリカ). These are called phonetic kanji.
Context 3-JP: <jp>時々、漢字は、亜米利加 (アメリカ)のようにそれぞれの意味を無視して、読み方だけで選ばれます。これらの漢字を当て字と言います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>energy</kanji> is that of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness, you are probably <vocabulary>sick</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mother’s illness still hasn’t improved.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母の病気は、まだよくなりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got a disease that makes me fart all the time, so I've haven't been able to go outside.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おしりからおならが止まらない病気にかかってしまい、外に出られなくなってしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Can you fix my mom’s illness, doctor?" "I’ll give it a try, but don’t count on it."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「先生、僕のママの病気、直せるの？」「やってみるけど、当てにしないでね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The essence of your <kanji>house</kanji> and <kanji>garden</kanji> is your <vocabulary>family</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>household</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I want to get married and build a loving home someday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつかはけっこんして、あたたかい家庭をきずきたいと思っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My hobby is to pick up each household member's waste with my bare hands.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのしゅ味は、かく家庭から出るゴミをす手でしゅう集することです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Compared to Japanese women, foreign women tend to be pretty strict about separating family time and working time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本女性と比べると、外国の女性は家庭の時間と仕事の時間を分けることには、かなり厳格です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>決める</jp> before, hopefully. This is similar, except for instead of doing the action of deciding, something has just been decided (by something or someone else). You are not the decision maker, here. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be decided</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>決める</jp>, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.
Context 1-EN: Since I got the job, I’ve lost interest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>仕事が決まってからは、きょうみがなくなりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Every morning Koichi is late for work because he hasn't decided on a hairstyle yet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは毎朝かみがたが決まらないせいで会社にちこくする。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "That’s a really good idea. Let’s do that." "Okay, then it’s been decided."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「それは本当にいい考えだね。そうしよう。」「よし、じゃあ、それで話は決まりだ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>what</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> - as in: <vocabulary>what month</vocabulary> is it? It's <jp>１０月</jp>, you fool. Get a job, hippy.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. <jp>何</jp> is technically the kun'yomi, but it feels pretty on'yomi-ish if you ask me. The <jp>月</jp> uses the on'yomi, though.
Context 1-EN: What month do you start school?
Context 1-JP: <jp>学こうは何月にはじまりますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When did it happen? What year, what month, what day, what time, what second was it? How many times did Earth spin when it happened?
Context 2-JP: <jp>それって何年何月何日何びょう、ちきゅうが何回回ったとき？</jp>
Context 3-EN: What month were you born in, Ms. Tanaka?
Context 3-JP: <jp>田中さんは何月生まれですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>coarse</kanji>? <vocabulary>Coarse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most coarse thing you can think of is a rock (あら). You rubbed it on your face and it was really rough and kinda painful. You probably shouldn't be rubbing a rock on your face, actually.
Context 1-EN: I always use the coarse flour from corn, wheat, or beans in my smoothies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はいつも、トウモロコシ、麦、豆などをひき割って粗い粉にしたものをスムージーに入れます。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>open</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You go to open the door. When you do, a huge scream comes out: "AAAHHH!" (あ). Imagine giant あ characters flying out of the door you opened as well.
Context 1-EN: Please open your Japanese dictionary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語のじしょを開けてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My boyfriend always opens the car door for me when I get in.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのかれ氏は、車に乗る時は、いつもドアを開けてくれるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Can you open this bottle of wine for me?" "Of course. Piece of cake."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、このワインボトルを開けてもらえないかな？」「いいよ。朝飯前だよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>root</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, <jp>本</jp> is <jp>ぽん</jp>, which is a weird rendaku.
Context 1-EN: First of all, you are fundamentally wrong.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そもそも、根本から間ちがってるんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That couple had fundamentally different ideas about their kid's education.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのふうふは、子どもの教育についての根本の考え方が合わなかったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Kristen doesn’t eat bacon; where do you think the root of this problem lies?
Context 3-JP: <jp>クリステンはベーコンを食べませんが、この問題の根本の原因はどこにあると思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> equals the fairly obvious translation "<vocabulary>what day</vocabulary>." But, it also means <vocabulary>how many days</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case, we use the kun'yomi for <jp>何</jp>. <jp>日</jp> uses the on'yomi.
Context 1-EN: How many days will you take off from your part-time job?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アルバイト、何日休むんですか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>何日がいい？</jp>
Context 3-EN: How many days were you stuck in the elevator?
Context 3-JP: <jp>エレベーターから何日出られなかったんですか。</jp>

Meaning: To Learn,To Study In Depth,To Study
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means study or learning. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means to learn.

There is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there to learn manners (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.
Context 1-EN: I’m learning Japanese through self-study.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、どく学で日本ごを学んでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why don't you learn how to make weird faces and poses with Tofugu, instead of studying Japanese?
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本ごをべんきょうするのはやめて、トーフグといっしょにへんがおとへんなポーズを学びませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Learning is important, but perhaps what’s more important is how you learn.
Context 3-JP: <jp>学ぶことは大切だけど、おそらくもっと大切なのはどのように学ぶかということじゃないだろうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means end and so the verb version of this is to end or to be over.

It's an intransitive verb, meaning it happens on its own. Something ends, but you don't cause it to end.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

This situation has to end. You're the ower (おわ) of a lot of money. For this to end, you need to pay back all that money. Try to think of ways to stop being an ower so this stressful situation can end!
Context 1-EN: When school's finished, I'll go shopping.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校が終わったら、買い物に行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My life was over when I lost it all gambling.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ギャンブルにまけて人生終わってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, man! Back off! I told you to stay away from me until the atomic bomb has finished being dismantled.
Context 3-JP: <jp>おい、こら！引っ込んでろ！原子爆弾の解体が終わるまでは、私に近づくなと言っただろ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>enter</kanji> into a <kanji>study</kanji> (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka <vocabulary>school admission</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>university admission</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>entry into school</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Here is a congratulatory present for getting into school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、入学のおいわいのプレゼントです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My father forgot to pay the enrollment fee.
Context 2-JP: <jp>父が入学金をはらうのをわすれてしまったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tom thought he got into Oxford, but apparently the acceptance letter was an April Fool’s joke his parents made.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トムはオックスフォード大学に入学できたと思っていたんだけど、どうもその合格証明書はトムの両親がエイプリルフールのジョークとして作ったものだったようだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If it's <kanji>coarse</kanji> in a <kanji>bad</kanji> way it's still <vocabulary>coarse</vocabulary> but it's also <vocabulary>crude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inferior</vocabulary>. You don't want a fuzzy sweater to be coarse, do you? Or a carpet? If they are, they're this kind of coarse.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Crude gasoline will shorten a car’s lifespan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>粗悪なガソリンは、車の寿命を早める。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None

Meaning: Absent From School,Absence From School,School Absence,Leave Of Absence
Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>rest</kanji> from <kanji>school</kanji> you are <vocabulary>absent from school</vocabulary>. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m taking a one year leave of absence from university.

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>mouth</kanji> makes <kanji>tone</kanji>s we call it your <vocabulary>tone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tone of voice</vocabulary>. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>口</jp> yet. Remember when you learned the vocabulary word <jp>口</jp>? Just take the <jp>ち</jp> off and you get its other on'yomi reading <jp>く</jp>. That's easy, right?
Context 1-EN: I don’t really like her because of her harsh tone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かの女は口調がキツイのでちょっと苦手です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi said, in a very stern voice, that luck is just part of his talents.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、とてもきびしい口調で、「うんも実力のうちだ」と言った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She scolded me violently in a severe tone.
Context 3-JP: <jp>厳しい口調で責め立てられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>moving</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to <vocabulary>animals</vocabulary> instead.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don't like animals.
Context 1-JP: <jp>動物は苦手なんです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>何か動物はかっていますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi hosted a party at the Tofugu Zoo for one hundred very important animals and for some reason, I wasn’t invited. I thought I was one of the VIA to him too.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチがトーフグ動物園に100匹の重要な動物を集めてパーティーを開催したんだけど、何故か私は招待されなかったんだよね。私もコウイチにとっての重要動物の一匹だと思っていたんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The soarer!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.
Context 1-EN: There is a beautiful rainbow in the sky.
Context 1-JP: <jp>空にきれいなにじがかかっている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They say that women's minds and the autumn skies change quickly, but men's minds change quickly too.
Context 2-JP: <jp>女心とあきの空といいますが、男心だってかわりやすいんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hope the sky tonight is clear enough for us to see the famous scene from the movie E.T.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今夜映画E.T.の有名なシーンがちゃんと見れるくらい、空が晴れ渡っているといいんだが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Imagine you have to carry a hawk (はこ). Imagine carrying it in your hands. It's trying to claw and peck itself free, but you don't let go. It is your job to carry this hawk with you everywhere.
Context 1-EN: Oh, and don’t forget to move the desk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あ、それから、つくえを運ぶのをわすれないでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My duty as a father is to put food on the table and have tea parties with my daughter.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の父親としての役目は、食べ物をテーブルに運んで、娘と一緒にお茶会をすることだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want a bag to carry these textbooks.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この教科書を運ぶための鞄がほしい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means advance so the verb vocab version means to advance.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it is about something or someone advancing forward.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In order to advance, you must sue Sue for her misdeeds against you. Imagine her standing in your way, literally. She keeps saying, "You'll have to sue me if you want to get past me!" So you do. You sue Sue. Now tell her to move (む).
Context 1-EN: Are you making any progress in your work?
Context 1-JP: <jp>仕事は進んでいますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu always goes one step ahead, doesn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグは、いつも一歩先を進んでいるよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your daughter is advancing faster than the other students.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お嬢さんは他の学生よりずっと進んでいる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with <jp>お金</jp>, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.
Context 1-EN: I gave her a gold necklace.
Context 1-JP: <jp>金のネックレスをプレゼントしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If I had money, I would like to buy the gold Rolex that Kim Jong-un has.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お金があったら、金正ウンとおそろいの、金のロレックスをかいたいとおもっています。</jp>

Context 3-JP: <jp>この毛糸は24時間後に金に変わるんだけど、クリスマスプレゼントとして少しあんたにあげるよ。感謝しろよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>language</kanji>, so when you do language you're going <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Sometimes when you're trying to talk, there will be that one person who always cuts you off to tell everyone what they want to say. We call them language cutters (かた). They cut you off and make everyone pay attention to what they're saying. Don't be a language cutter.
Context 1-EN: What do you plan to talk about at the next seminar?
Context 1-JP: <jp>次のセミナーでは、何について語る予定ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mr. Tanaka, time is up, so please wrap up your adventure tale.
Context 2-JP: <jp>田中さん、時間がないので、ぼうけんだんを語るのはこの辺で止めてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t talk about this case with people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この事件を人に語ることはできない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who is <kanji>blue</kanji> in their <kanji>year</kanji>s. This makes sense when you know that Asian babies are often born with blue butts, which you can associate with being young. So, Blue = Young (not only in this word, but in others as well). Someone who is blue in their years is a <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして日本の青年は、下心があっていやらしい笑みを浮かべていることを隠そうとするのか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. Meaning Mnemonic: Imagine yourself <kanji>investigating</kanji> a <kanji>child</kanji>. Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

Did you hear that sound? It's barely audible (おと). Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of おと to help you to remember this.

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>make</kanji>. The verb form of that is <vocabulary>to make</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's too cool (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、ばんごはんにやきそばを作ります。</jp>

Context 3-JP: <jp>テスラ・コイルをどうやって作るのかを知っていたら良かったんだけどな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Measure</kanji> how much you've <kanji>accumulate</kanji>d and you'll have a <vocabulary>cumulative total</vocabulary>. That total includes all the things you've bought since the beginning of time. Probably.

This is talking about a <vocabulary>season</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be <jp>時間</jp> or something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a car raider (からだ). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider.

Of course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, からだ.

Context 3-JP: <jp>なぜだか、体中がかゆいんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>end</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the <vocabulary>last stop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: You have your <kanji>body</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. This is just another way to say <vocabulary>physical strength</vocabulary>. They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
