Meaning Mnemonic: You know <jp>日本</jp> is "Japan." So, when you add <kanji>language</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese language</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word <jp>日本</jp> (<jp>にほん</jp>) plus the reading that you learned for <jp>語</jp>. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.
Context 1-EN: Okay? Not English, Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いいですか。英語じゃなくて日本語ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you subscribe to WaniKani right now, it will come with Tofugu's autograph in Japanese.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今ワニカニを買うと、もれなく日本語でかかれたトーフグのサインが付いてきますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t be afraid of making mistakes. Speak in Japanese. Give it a shot. I think you can do it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>間違うことを恐れるなよ。日本語で喋ってみろって。やってみろよ。君ならできると思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji>, what are you doing? Simply put, you're <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please hand this essay in to professor Nakagawa.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この作文を、中川先生にわたしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got 100 percent on the essay exam.
Context 2-JP: <jp>作文のテストで百てんをもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My essays are still full of mistakes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕の作文は、まだ間違いだらけです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>tall</kanji> isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Beer when work ends is the best.
Context 1-JP: <jp>仕事終わりのビールは最高だな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm enjoying the best moment, looking at the night view of Tokyo Bay.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京わんの夜けいを見ながら最高の一時を楽しんでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Wow, you made the best chocolate cake. But, what’s gotten into you? You’ve never baked before." "Nothing, I just wanted to do something new."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「うわ！あんたの作ったの、今までで最高のチョコレートケーキだわ。でも、一体どうしちゃったの？お菓子作りなんてしたことなかったじゃない。」「別に。何か新しいことをしてみたかっただけだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!
Context 1-EN: Hashimoto’s voice is very low.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はし本さんの声は、とてもひくいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My friend's voice and her kid's voice are very alike.
Context 2-JP: <jp>友人の声とその子どもの声がそっくりだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your voice sounds awful!
Context 3-JP: <jp>あんたの声、ひどいな！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have an <kanji>older brother</kanji> and a <kanji>younger brother</kanji>. Wow! Both are here. These are <vocabulary>brothers</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have two siblings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしには、兄弟が二人います。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>マリオとルイージって兄弟だったの！？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like those brothers, but I hate their stuffed animals.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの兄弟は好きだけど、あいつらのもっているぬいぐるみは好きじゃない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>come</kanji> so you know this word means <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic:

"I want you to come to the cool (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader. "What?" replies Luke.

Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.
Context 1-EN: I came from America.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカから来ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: She will come. I'm sure she will come.
Context 2-JP: <jp>来る、きっと来る。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Never come back!
Context 3-JP: <jp>二度と戻って来るんじゃねーぞ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>end</kanji> thing is the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary> thing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I missed the last part of my favorite drama and cried.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大すきなドラマの最終回を見のがして泣いた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The train we just took was the last one of the day, so we can't go back anymore.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今乗ってきた電車が最終だったから、もうかえれないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is our final offer. Now the ball is in your court.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これが我が社の最終提案です。後はあなたの決断次第です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The amount of people with mouths (that you have to feed) is the <vocabulary>population</vocabulary> that you have to feed.
Reading Mnemonic: Both kanji in this jukugo (combo kanji) use the on'yomi readings that you've already learned! So just make sure you know those and you'll be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: Half the population is male.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人口のはんぶんはだんせいです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>このむらの人口はたったの二十三にんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Many Japanese people don’t know the population of their own town.
Context 3-JP: <jp>じぶんのまちの人口をしらないにほんじんはおおい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is <vocabulary>next year</vocabulary>! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m thinking of going back to America next year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来年はアメリカにかえるつもりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I plan to continue being a NEET this year, next year, and the year after that.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今年も来年もさ来年もわたしはニートをつづけるつもりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Come at this time next year. I’ll have the biggest trailer in the trailer park.
Context 3-JP: <jp>来年の今頃に来てくれよ。ハウストレーラー用のキャンプ場で、一番でかいトレーラーが俺のだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>public building</kanji> where you <kanji>welcome</kanji> <kanji>VIP</kanji> guests is a <vocabulary>reception hall</vocabulary>. Or a <vocabulary>guest house</vocabulary> if they're staying the night.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was invited to the reception hall.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、迎賓館に招待されました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: It's the <kanji>end</kanji>. It's the <kanji>finish</kanji>. This word means <vocabulary>end</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>finish</vocabulary>! How convenient.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The first day of the Osaka performance has ended!
Context 1-JP: <jp>大さか公えん1日目終了しました！</jp>
Context 2-EN: The main character died and the game was over.
Context 2-JP: <jp>主人公が死んでゲームが終了してしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "What if I got fat again? " "Well, our relationship wouldn’t end, that’s for sure."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「もし私がまたデブになったらどうする？」 「まぁ、俺達の関係が終了しないのは確実だね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you have years coming and going, you know it is for some years. Don't confuse this one with 来年 which means "next year." The kanji 来 comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate.

You can also add numbers to this word. For example ５年来 means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He’s been my friend for thirty years.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれは、わたしの三十年来の友人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My long-cherished wish has finally come true.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの年来のきぼうがついにかないました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve been trying to ask her out for a few years now, but she always says she will be busy washing her hair.
Context 3-JP: <jp>数年来彼女をデートに誘っているんだが、いつも「髪の毛を洗うのに忙しいから」と断られる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>winter</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji>! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a <vocabulary>winter holiday</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>winter break</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.
Context 1-EN: During winter break my family stayed in a hotel in the mountains.
Context 1-JP: <jp>冬休みに、かぞくで山の中のホテルにとまりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Winter holiday was pretty tough because my sons fight so often at home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>冬休みは子どもたちがいえで兄弟げんかばっかりしていて大へんでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: During winter vacation, I jogged everyday, all day long.
Context 3-JP: <jp>冬休みは、毎日一日中ジョギングをしていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is a place where sick people go. That is a <vocabulary>hospital</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It takes about a thousand yen to get to the hospital by taxi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>病院までタクシーで、千円ぐらいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The head of this hospital can't even do his multiplication tables.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この病院の院長は、九九もできない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hate being a doctor in this hospital. The patients are all idiots.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この病院で医者をすることには本当に嫌気が差すね。患者は馬鹿ばっかりなんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>collect</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are <vocabulary>collecting money</vocabulary> (or doing <vocabulary>money collection</vocabulary>). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much <jp>集金</jp> in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We collected money from everyone and bought a bunch of flowers and a message board.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんなから集金して、花たばと色紙を買いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't worry about collecting money anymore. What will be, will be.
Context 2-JP: <jp>集金のことはもう心配するなよ。なるようになるさ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve got tons of work I have to catch up on. Anyway, maybe I should start collecting money from my clients.
Context 3-JP: <jp>やらなければならない仕事が山のようにあるよ。とりあえず、お客さんから集金することから始めようかな。</jp>

Meaning: Within The Company,In House,Inside The Company,Inside A Company,In The Company,Within A Company
Meaning Mnemonic: When you're doing something <kanji>inside</kanji> the <kanji>company</kanji> you're doing it <vocabulary>within the company</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in-house</vocabulary>. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Next Sunday there will be an in house basketball tournament.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つぎの日よう日に、社内のバスケットボール大会があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hana left the company after she married a man who worked in the same company.
Context 2-JP: <jp>花さんは、社内けっこんをしてたいしょくしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Recently, there is a strange new trend in our company. Workers put names on food in the company fridge. Today, I had a rice ball named "Suzuki."
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近、社内で変なことが流行っている。従業員が、会社の冷蔵庫の中の食べ物に名前をつけるのだ。今日は、俺は、「鈴木」と名付けられたオニギリを食べた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The way you say things could be translated as your accent... but this is much bigger. This is an entire "way" of speaking. This is a dialect.

You can even think of the 方 as being "direction" where you go in different directions in a country and discover different dialects, if that way of thinking helps.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m making a dialect dictionary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>方言のじしょを作っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Damn! My boyfriend's dialect has rubbed off on me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ああっもうっ！かれしの方言がうつっちゃってるずら。</jp>
Context 3-EN: People from the eastern part of my country use such an odd dialect that they are impossible to understand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の国の東側出身の人達は変わった方言で喋るので、彼らが何を言っているのか全く分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>surface</kanji> that <kanji>accumulate</kanji>s into one area is a particular <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The area of his forehead is 100 square meters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼のおでこの面積は100平方メートルある。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji>d that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of <vocabulary>doll</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>puppet</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>人</jp> is pretty normal, though the reading for <jp>形</jp> is different from the one you learned. To remember this, think of a doll... made totally of <reading>gyo</reading>za (<jp>ぎょう</jp>) dumplings. This doll is crazy (like most dolls) and it's eating itself and trying to get you to eat some of it too. Hey... why you no eat me? Mmmm. Gyoza doll.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to bring a doll for her birthday present.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たん生日プレゼントに、人形をもって行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Put the doll back the way you found it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その人形、ちゃんと元のところにもどしておいてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Until the age of 17, my best friend was a sock puppet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>17歳まで、私の親友は靴下で作った腕人形だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you collect to the middle of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme concentration abilities. Now you're really, really good at focusing.

Just imagine a light in the middle of your brain, so concentrated that you're able to concentrate, shooting a little laser out of your forehead onto the thing you're concentrating on.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We were too concentrated on the meeting and we missed the last train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会ぎに集中しすぎて終電をのがしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Concentrate! Focus! Give it your all!
Context 2-JP: <jp>集中集中！気合いを入れろ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey! Stop breathing down my neck. I can’t concentrate.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もう！まとわりつくのは止めてよ！集中できないでしょ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Accumulate</kanji> enough of a good reputation at your company in <kanji>advance</kanji> and you'll be able to have <vocabulary>successive promotion</vocabulary>s. You'll be boss in no time!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He was promoted to section head at a very young age.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は若くして部長に累進した。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>company</kanji> you're actually <vocabulary>joining a company</vocabulary>. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I joined this company in April.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この会社には、四月に入社しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu's employment exam is more difficult than Google's.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの入社しけんはグーグルの入社しけんよりもむずかしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As soon as I graduate from college, I hope to either join a big financial firm or be the president of the United States.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大学を卒業したらすぐに、大きな金融機関に入社するか、アメリカ合衆国の大統領になれたらいいなと思っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is a <vocabulary>government-run company</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>government-owned company</vocabulary>. In other words, it's a company that's run by national or local government in the interests of the public.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If I remember correctly, he works for a goverment-run company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たしか、かれは公社ではたらいています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This passenger rail services were operated by the Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このりょきゃくてつどうは、みなみアフリカりょきゃくてつどう公社がうんえいしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On April 1st, a goverment-owned company called Japan Post opened for business and it wasn’t an April Fools’ joke.
Context 3-JP: <jp>4月1日に国営公社である日本郵政公社が業務を開始したが、エイプリルフールのジョークではなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji> is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your <vocabulary>headquarters</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The headquarters are in Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本社はとうきょうにあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: On Monday, I visited Tofugu HQ.
Context 2-JP: <jp>月よう日に、トーフグの本社におじゃましてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s so quiet in the head office today, I can hear myself not working.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は本社がやけに静かだな。俺が働いていない音まで聞こえるぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

But this word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading. You should make sure you don't mix them up. The first one is the reading you learned with the kanji. かく means angle.

The second reading (かど), is something you haven't learned, and it means corner. Just picture a deck of cards (かど). Now take one card at a time and fold them to make a corner. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!
Context 1-EN: Please turn left at the next corner.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つぎの角を、左にまがってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that the teacher got knocked out from hitting her head on the corner of a block of tofu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの先生は、とうふの角にあたまをぶつけて気ぜつしたらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: All three internal angles of an equilateral triangle are equal.
Context 3-JP: <jp>正三角形では，三つの角の大きさがみんな同じです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>向</jp> means <kanji>yonder</kanji>. So, think of a "yonder <jp>こういち</jp>." All you know is that he's <vocabulary>over there</vocabulary> on the <vocabulary>other side</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>opposite side</vocabulary> of where you are. Basically, he's just pretty <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary>, wherever he is.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Standing with こういち is a cow. It is saying moo (む). Weird, now こういち is saying it too. Also, if you know the reading of 向く you should be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Let’s buy bread at the bakery over there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>向こうのパンやで、パンを買いましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Ichika might have come from the other side of the world.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一花は、向こうの世界からやって来たのかもしれない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll tell you my secret if you go stand on the opposite side of the road.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし君が道路の向こう側に立つのであれば、私の秘密を君に打ち明けるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What shape has <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>angle</kanji>s? The most common one is a <vocabulary>square</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!
Context 1-EN: Cut the potatoes into squares, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>じゃがいもを、四角に切ってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want the twitter icon to go back from the current round shape to the square one.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ツイッターのアイコンの形を今の丸から四角にもどしてほしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why are most windows either squares or rectangles? They should start making windows shaped like Italy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうしてほとんどの窓は真四角か長四角なんだろう。イタリア型の窓とかも作ったらいいのに。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!
Context 1-EN: I saw a bear in that valley.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこの谷で、くまを見ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Hakone, there is a valley called Owakudani, which used to be called "Death Valley" a long time ago, and it is a famous tourist spot nowadays.
Context 2-JP: <jp>はこねには大わく谷というむかし「じごく谷」といわれた谷があって、かんこうの名しょになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The guy who committed suicide in Death Valley was dressed as Darth Vader.
Context 3-JP: <jp>死の谷で自殺した男は、ダース・ベイダーのコスプレをしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A vehicle that run-goes is running and it's moving you somewhere else. You're traveling!

We usually use this word to describe moving or running vehicles like cars and trains. Keep an eye on those context sentences to make sure you're using it right. ;)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you tell me the mileage of your car?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの車の走行マイルをおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Leaving your seat while the bus is moving is dangerous.
Context 2-JP: <jp>バスの走行中にせきを立つのはきけんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The train will start running to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry again as soon as the strike is over.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その電車は、ストライキが終わり次第、ホグワーツ魔法魔術学校への走行を再開する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Accumulate</kanji> and <kanji>accumulate</kanji> make <vocabulary>accumulation</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How do you think the Japanese government accumulated such a great amount of national debt?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本政府が巨額の国債を累積していることについて、あなたはどのようにお考えですか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>near</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nearby</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the ちか portion to be able to read this word. Imagine someone close to you... Too close. They are so close to you that they're touching their cheek (ちか) to your cheek. Feel the cheek on yours, it's getting awkward.
Context 1-EN: My house is close to the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしのいえはえきから近いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm wearing close to no makeup today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は、ほぼすっぴんに近いです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Drinking American beer is like doing somersaults in a canoe. It’s too close to water.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカのビールって、カヌーの上ででんぐり返しをするみたいなものだよね。超水に近いんだもん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day coming very <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>. It's a day coming <vocabulary>in a few days</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both on'yomi readings that you've learned. Just take note that <jp>日</jp> is the alternate reading <jp>じつ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: This game is scheduled to be released soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このゲームは、近日はつばいよていです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The movie Mr. Tanaka was looking forward to will finally be released in a few days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>田中さんがたのしみにしていたえいがが、ついに近日こうかいします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s hang out in person soon and talk about things we saw online.
Context 3-JP: <jp>近日中にお会いして、ネットで見たことを一緒に語り合いましょう。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Close,To Approach,To Draw Near,To Near,To Bring Near
Meaning Mnemonic: Because this word ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you can tell it's probably a verb. The kanji portion means <vocabulary>near</vocabulary>. The verb version of that is <vocabulary>to draw near</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get close</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary>. Essentially, the general idea is that you're getting closer to something. You're becoming more nearby. You're approaching.
Reading Mnemonic: There's hiragana attached to this kanji, which means it's probably the kun'yomi reading (and it is). You've seen the kun'yomi reading via the word <jp>近い</jp>. So, as long as you know that word, you should be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: When the cameraman approached it, the turtle ran away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カメラマンが近づくとカメはにげてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't go anywhere near my girlfriend!
Context 2-JP: <jp>おれの女に近づくな！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Strange as it is, the zombie approaching us right now is actually my type.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達に今近づいてきているゾンビ、めちゃくちゃ私のタイプなんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you use a <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>tone</kanji> on certain words, then you are putting <vocabulary>emphasis</vocabulary> on whatever it is you're talking about. It's the <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary> you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'd like to emphasize that Tofugu articles are super high quality, interesting, and helpful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguの記事は超ドきゅうにおも白くて役に立つことを強調しておきたい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Highlighting important words with a highlighter helps you memorize them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大事な用語は、けい光ペンで強調するとおぼえやすいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’d just like to stress again that dressing neatly and being polite are very important for this job.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この仕事では身支度をきちんとしていることと礼儀正しいことが重要になることを改めて強調させて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are now <kanji>open</kanji> for <kanji>departure</kanji>. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its <vocabulary>development</vocabulary> where you will create a new world.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The development team will answer everyone’s questions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>開発チームがみなさんのごしつもんにお答えします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please tell us about the story behind Tofugu's development.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの開発ひ話を教えてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi pulled an all-nighter to develop a new Japanese learning site.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは新しい日本語学習サイトを開発するために徹夜をした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who is <kanji>sick</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sick person</vocabulary>. They are also a <vocabulary>patient</vocabulary>, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that this uses the <jp>にん</jp> reading for <jp>人</jp>. This is because every sick person enjoys laying in bed playing <reading>nin</reading>tendo.
Context 1-EN: If you don’t want to catch something, you shouldn’t go near sick people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うつったらいやだから、病人には近よりたくない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The fortuneteller told me that my previous life was as a sick person.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うらないしに、前世は病人だったと言われました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "How’s it going?" "Couldn’t be better." "Good. I’m surprised to hear that from a sick person though."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「調子はどうだい？」「絶好調だよ。」「それは良かった。病人からその言葉を聞けるとは思ってもみなかったがな。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>真似</jp> is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also <vocabulary>impersonation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>物</jp> plus <jp>真似</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: "What do you do every day?" "I practice impersonations all day, every day."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「いつも何してるの？」「毎日一日中物真似の練習をしてるよ。」</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I have a wheat allergy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、麦アレルギーがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What's the difference between barley and wheat?
Context 2-JP: <jp>大麦と小麦のちがいは何ですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Squats, squats, squats, squats, oats and squats," he sang while squatting.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「スクワット、スクワット、スクワット、麦とスクワット♪」屈伸をしながら彼は歌った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To remember the meaning of this word, just think about how in the olden days, before perforation was invented, people had to <kanji>cut</kanji> their <vocabulary>postage stamp</vocabulary>s by <kanji>hand</kanji>. It took forever, especially if you had a lot of friends to mail things to. Be thankful that perforation was invented to save you time cutting them.
Reading Mnemonic: You'd think that the reading for this would consist of the on'yomi readings, but human body parts (hand) do funny things to words. In this case, it's the kun'yomi readings of both the kanji. You should know the kun'yomi reading for 切 and 手 from the previous levels, meaning you should be able to remember the reading for this word fairly easily. Watch out for the small っ, though.
Context 1-EN: Then I’m going to go to the post office and buy stamps.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それから、ゆうびんきょくへいって、切手をかいます。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの外人さんは切手を一万まいもかっていったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since I lost her, I've lost interest in stamp collecting.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女を失ってから、切手集めへの興味も失ってしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know <jp>人気</jp> which means "popular." And you also know that <jp>不</jp> means "not." So what do you get when you combine the two? Something that's <vocabulary>not popular</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unpopular</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What do you think is the most unpopular anime this year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年、もっとも不人気だったアニメは何だと思いますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The Koichi vs Michael sumo match is unpopular because it lacks the intensity when you watch it on YouTube.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチたいマイケルのすもうのし合は、Youtubeで見るとはく力に欠けるので不人気です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He was unpopular among his classmates because his favorite phrase was, "I’m gonna tell your mom."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「お前の母ちゃんに言ってやる」が口癖だったため、彼はクラスメートに不人気だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know the word <jp>直す</jp> from a couple levels ago. It means "to fix." So, when you fix what you see, what are you doing? You're reevaluating something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to reevaluate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are all kun'yomi readings, like the vocab you've seen already. This is like two vocab words put together, which is why it's using the kun'yomi reading. The hiragana on the end is a hint!
Context 1-EN: Let’s look at the plans one more time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう一ど、けいかくを見直しましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: On the last junk removal day, my husband was much more dependable than I expected and it made me look at him differently.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この間のはいひん回しゅうの日、主人が思ったよりたよりになって、ちょっと見直しちゃった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think you should reevaluate your choices in university classes. I don’t think catching dodo birds is a good career path.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大学の授業の選択を見直す方がいいと思うよ。だって、愚鳩を捕まえるのが、いいキャリアになるとは思えないもん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have the <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>town</kanji>. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: <vocabulary>downtown</vocabulary>. It isn't the downtown you might be used to though. In Japan, this is an old word that was used for the commercial districts literally, physically down (lower than) the main city. So picture an old, urban Japanese area!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I grew up downtown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、下町でそだちました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'd like to go to a good old fashioned saloon in the backstreet areas of the old cities of Tokyo.
Context 2-JP: <jp>とうきょうの下町にあるむかしながらのさかばに行ってみたいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A shitamachi is an old Japanese style of downtown; it isn’t the same as the downtown we think of today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>下町とは、日本の古いスタイルのダウンタウンのことで、現代のものとは異なっている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something <kanji>normal</kanji> and <kanji>universal</kanji> is still <vocabulary>universal</vocabulary>. Normally.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Universal themes are easily accepted by many people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>普遍的なテーマは、多くの人に受け入れられやすい。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary>. <jp>心配しないでね！</jp>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the <jp>ぱい</jp> in <jp>配</jp> got rendaku'd from <jp>はい</jp>, as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried because it’s unusual for him to be so down.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれが元気がないのはめずらしいので心配です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got worried about whether the ship was heading east or west.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この船の進行方向が西なのか東なのか心配になった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t worry, everything is going to be fine. You can believe what I say.
Context 3-JP: <jp>心配しないで。すべて上手くいくよ。私の言うことを信じて。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>string</kanji> (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully <vocabulary>wool yarn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With <jp>毛</jp> you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With <jp>糸</jp> it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.
Context 1-EN: Do you have green yarn?
Context 1-JP: <jp>みどり色の毛糸はありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It is very cold today, so I am wearing the wool sweater that my friend knitted for me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日はとてもさむいので、友人があんでくれた毛糸のセーターをきています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Unwind a ball of yarn please. Please. Please!" the ghost asked me over and over again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「毛糸の玉をほどいてください。お願いします。お願いします。」と、その幽霊は何度も私に頼んできた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's <vocabulary>one hundred</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!
Context 1-EN: I read one hundred pages in one week.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一しゅうかんで、百ページよみました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you get to Level 100, Prince, you can change your job from prince to king or queen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王子がレベル百になったら王か女王にてんしょくできますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can buy a bunch of different things with a hundred yen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>百円で色々なものが買えるんですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>meet</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I’m having a girls-only party on Friday night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きんようびの夜に、女子会をします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The assembly with those members sounds very interesting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのメンバーの会はとてもおも白そうですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s open this meeting again!
Context 3-JP: <jp>この会、また開こうよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The meaning is the same as the kanji. When you <kanji>stand</kanji> and <kanji>drink</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>standing and drinking</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are from the words <jp>立つ</jp> and <jp>飲む</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: In summer you can stand and drink on the terrace.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夏には、テラスせきで立ち飲みもできます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are a lot of stand-and-drink bars near Shinbashi Station in Tokyo.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京の新ばしえき近辺には立ち飲み屋がたくさんあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you get any action last night after leaving the standing bar?
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日、あの立ち飲み屋の後、誰かとやった？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word has two different meanings. <vocabulary>One day</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>first day</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic:
The first meaning is one day, and it has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so you should already know this reading.

The reading for first day, however, is a big old exception. It doesn’t take the on’yomi or kun’yomi readings, and has its own special (weird) readings. Here’s a mnemonic to help you remember this one:

On the first day of your new relationship you can get two touches (ついたち) only. That’s the rule! You can touch their hand and maybe high five. But that’s all you get. Just think when you’re on your first day of dating, two touches! Two touches only!
Context 1-EN: I was studying for the test all day yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのうは一日テストのべんきょうをしていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The fact that an American and French couple succeeded to climb Mt. Everest on June 1st is still fresh in people's memory.
Context 2-JP: <jp>六月一日にアメリカ人とフランス人のふうふ二人がいっしょにエベレストをのぼりきったことは人々のきおくにあたらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you really read this book in one day?
Context 3-JP: <jp>本とうに一日でこの本をよんだんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Seventh day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day seven</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

You've been stuck inside working for seven days and today you finally have a day off. Your friend asks you if you want to go for a drive but you say, "Nah, no car today" (なのか), because you've been cooped up long enough. Seven days is too long to be inside.
Context 1-EN: I was in bed for seven whole days because of a cold.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かぜで、七日かんもねこんでいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I visit our family grave on the 7th of every month.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まい月七日に、おはかまいりをします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I left the company after only seven days.
Context 3-JP: <jp>たった七日でかいしゃをやめた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> times <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>days</kanji> is <vocabulary>twenty days</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. The readings for 二十 are exceptions, and 日 takes the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help with that:

If you make one hat for twenty days you'll have enough hats (はつ) to fill up your car (か) completely! That's a lot of days and a lot of hats.
Context 1-EN: There is a test on the twentieth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二十日にテストがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It will be 2019 in twenty days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あと二十日で２０１９年です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Payday is the twentieth day of every month.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎月二十日は給料日です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>universal</kanji> event can only happen <vocabulary>once</vocabulary>. It's too rare to happen more than that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because <jp>へん</jp> becomes <jp>ぺん</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: I wanted to eat caviar but one time was enough.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一遍だけでいいから、キャビアを食べてみたかったの。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning: Opening A Business,Opening Of Business,Starting A Business
Meaning Mnemonic: This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You <kanji>open</kanji> a <kanji>business</kanji>... aka <vocabulary>opening a business</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We also had a ton of debt when we opened our business.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちも、開業当時はしゃっ金だらけだったんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As of this year, this eye doctor has been in practice for 35 years.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この目医者は、今年で開業して三十五年になります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I blew off school yesterday to help Koichi prepare for the opening of his business.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチの開業準備を手伝うために、昨日は学校をサボったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Tenth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day ten</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

Ten days is just TOO (とお) long from now. Why do you have to wait until the tenth day? Maybe fewer would have been okay, but ten is too many.
Context 1-EN: Please take this medicine for ten days.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このくすりを、十日かんのんでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please complete it within ten days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>十日でかんせいさせてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The tenth of July is the anniversary of my grandfather’s death.
Context 3-JP: <jp>七月十日はそふのめい日です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you end up in a situation where you have to <kanji>enter</kanji> an <kanji>institution</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>hospitalization</vocabulary>. Hopefully you aren't there for very long.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: His condition deteriorated and they decided he's to be hospitalized.
Context 1-JP: <jp>病じょうがあっ化し、入院する事になりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: While I was hospitalized, I was so bored that I couldn't stop yawning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>入院中は、たいくつであくびが止まらなかったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm going to be hospitalized due to breast cancer soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今度、乳癌で入院することになったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is an <vocabulary>old shop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This reading is an exception, but there is another way you can say it that uses the jukugo (on'yomi) readings instead! But to help you remember the more common, exception, here's a mnemonic:

If you go to an old shop you can get what's called a shiny sale (しにせ). A shiny sale is if you can find something in the shop that's still new and shiny it's on sale! It's hard when you're at an old shop though. And that's the challenge!
Context 1-EN: They naturally showed the old shop’s spirit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼らは、まさに老舗の意地を見せたんだ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Ninth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day nine</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You learned this reading for <jp>九</jp> when you learned <jp>九つ</jp>, so you should be able to read this one too!
Context 1-EN: Would you like to go watch some soccer with me on the ninth?
Context 1-JP: <jp>九日に、いっしょにサッカーをみにいきませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Since Koichi hasn't seen Nikka for nine days, he feels so lonely he could die.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは九日もニッカにあっていないので、さびしくてしにそうだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mami’s birthday is April ninth.
Context 3-JP: <jp>マミのたんじょう日は四月九日だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <vocabulary>Eighth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day eight</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

Every eighth day you have to buy yogurt to fuel your car (ようか). Your car runs on yogurt, but it needs to be refilled every eight days to keep running. It's really inconvenient because it's just ONE day more than a week. And a week just feels better. Oh well.
Context 1-EN: My summer break is eight days long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしのなつやすみは、八日かんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you please give me some water? I haven't eaten anything for eight days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>すみませんが、水を下さいませんか。もう八日もなにもたべていないんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to get hemorrhoid surgery on the eighth of next month.
Context 3-JP: <jp>らい月の八日にじの手じゅつをするよていです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I bet you can guess that <jp>フランス</jp> means "France." So what happens when you add <kanji>language</kanji> to it? You get the "France Language" aka the <vocabulary>French Language</vocabulary>.
Reading Whitelist: ふらんすご,フランスご
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi reading for <jp>語</jp> which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: <jp>日本語</jp> = "Japanese Language." <jp>中国語</jp> = "Chinese Language." <jp>スペイン語</jp> = "Spanish Language."
Context 1-EN: My daughter can speak both French and English.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしのむすめは、フランス語もえい語も話せます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In many African countries, both English and French are used as their official languages.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アフリカの多くの国では公用語にえい語とフランス語が使用されています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Learning French is too difficult! I can’t take it anymore. Give me a break!
Context 3-JP: <jp>フランス語の学習は僕には難しすぎるよ。もうたく山だ！勘弁してくれよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> is iron under the ground. It isn't a deposit of iron, though. It's man-made. And what's made of iron? Trains. In this case, because it's underground, it's a <vocabulary>subway</vocabulary>. Depending on where you live, you might call it <vocabulary>the Underground</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>the Tube</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>the Metro</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ll go on the subway.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地下鉄に乗って行きます。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京の地下鉄はかなりふくざつです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What a relief! I thought I missed the subway train.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ああ、よかった！地下鉄に乗り遅れちゃうかと思ったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <vocabulary>become</vocabulary> so the vocab verb version would be <vocabulary>to become</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are starting <vocabulary>to become</vocabulary> something else. You're transforming, but you're not sure what it is. First, you get fins... uh oh, something in the water. Then, you gain a tail and rubbery skin... hmm, something sea mammal-like. Oh, and then a huge horn flies out of your nose. You are going to become a <vocabulary>na</vocabulary>rwhal (<jp>な</jp>).
Context 1-EN: You're worrying for nothing. What will be, will be.
Context 1-JP: <jp>取りこし苦労だよ。成るように成るさ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm visually impaired because I looked directly at an eclipse.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日食を直に見てしまったため、目が不自由に成りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh my God! Koichi finally became the President of the United States! Where there's a will, there's a way!
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわーー！！コウイチがとうとうアメリカ大統領に成ったよ。「為せば成る。為さねばならぬ何事も、成らぬは人の為さぬなりけり」だね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you’re at <kanji>neck</kanji> <kanji>rank</kanji> you’re in <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>. Haven’t you ever heard the phrase, “neck and neck” when two people in a race are both super close to first place? Just remember that and you’ll never forget this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned this reading for <jp>首</jp> when you learned <jp>部首</jp>, and the reading for <jp>位</jp> is the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I got the first place in an academic test.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学力テストで首位に立った。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Since our leading hitter got injured, we fell six games behind first place.
Context 2-JP: <jp>首位打者がケガをしたせいで、首位のチームに６ゲームさを付けられてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That old person seemed to have zero interest in both teams' fight for first place.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その老人は、両チームの首位争いには全く興味が無いようだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You can probably figure out that <jp>スペイン</jp> is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji <kanji>language</kanji> on there and you have the <vocabulary>Spanish language</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>Spanish</vocabulary>), if you'd like.
Reading Whitelist: すぺいんご,スペインご
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.
Context 1-EN: There’s a Spanish quiz tomorrow!
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日はスペイン語の小テストだぜ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: That Spanish textbook is currently sold out, so it's not available.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのスペイン語のテキストは今売り切れているので、ご用いできません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Garlic in Spanish is "ajo," which is pronounced "aho." "Aho" means "stupid" in Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ニンニクはスペイン語で「ajo」っていうんだけど、「アホ」って発音されるんだよ。「アホ」は日本語で「stupid」って意味だよ。</jp>

Meaning: Research Institute,Research Laboratory,Research Establishment,Research Lab,Research Facility
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>研究</jp> is research from previous vocab. So, a "place" that is a research place could be many things, though mainly a <vocabulary>research institute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>research laboratory</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>けんきゅうしょ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>けんきゅうじょ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: けんきゅうしょ,けんきゅうじょ
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of <jp>研究</jp> already. Also note that <jp>所</jp> is normal for one reading, but also gets the rendaku treatment, meaning <jp>しょ</jp> becomes <jp>じょ</jp>, for the secondary reading.
Reading Audio Male: [sound:Vocab-けんきゅうしょ-Male.mp3],[sound:Vocab-けんきゅうじょ-Male.mp3]
Reading Audio Female: [sound:Vocab-けんきゅうしょ-Female.mp3],[sound:Vocab-けんきゅうじょ-Female.mp3]
Context 1-EN: I heard that a certain American lab has made a pill that will make you fluent in Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とあるアメリカの研究所が、日本語がペラペラになるくすりを開発したそうだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is an emergency drill in the Miso Soup Research Facility today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は、みそしる研究所で、ぼうさいくんれんがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I work for the Burger King Research Institute. My job consists of eating french fries and then having my body weighed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はバーガーキング研究所で働いています。私の仕事は、フライドポテトを食べ、その後自分の体重を測ることです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you dig up <kanji>hollyhock</kanji>s in the <kanji>mountain</kanji>s, and grind up their roots, you'll have <vocabulary>wasabi</vocabulary>! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.
Reading Mnemonic: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!
Context 1-EN: Of course, freshly shaven wasabi is delicious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やはり、すりたての山葵は美味しいね。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>friend</kanji> who is like one of your <kanji>parent</kanji>s is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means <vocabulary>best friend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close friend</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Well, I was objected to by a close friend.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ま、親友には反対されたんですけどね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi and Viet are good friends. They are more than friends, but not lovers.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチとビエトは親友で、友だち以上、こい人未まんのかんけいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, you know what? Sara is going out with Beth." "What? I didn’t know that. I thought she was my best friend but she never told me about that."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、知ってる？サラがベスと付き合ってるのよ。」「え、知らなかった。サラのこと親友だと思ってたけど、私そのこと何も聞いてないわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>hear</kanji> is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a <vocabulary>newspaper</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は、毎朝新聞を読みます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu and Domo-kun were collaborating on the front page of the local newspaper this morning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今朝の地元の新聞の一めんでトーフグとどーも君がコラボしていたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This newspaper is so highbrow. No wonder Scott had to read it so many times.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この新聞すっげー専門用語だらけじゃん。スコットがこの新聞を何回も読まなきゃいけないのは当然だな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know the word <jp>外来</jp> to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for <kanji>language</kanji> and you have an imported word, aka a <vocabulary>borrowed word</vocabulary>. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a <jp>外来語</jp>, in fact.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Many Japanese words are used as loanwords in modern day Chinese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>げんざいの中国語では、たくさんの日本語が外来語として使われています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is rucksack a foreign word, or Engrish?
Context 2-JP: <jp>リュックサックは、外来語ですか？それとも和せいえい語ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, did you know that there's kanji for the word tobacco even though it’s a loanword?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねえ、煙草って外来語なのに漢字があるって知ってた？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What <kanji>place</kanji> in your house has most of the <kanji>machine</kanji>s in it? Your <vocabulary>kitchen</vocabulary>! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for <jp>台</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>所</jp>. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!
Context 1-EN: My mother is cooking in the kitchen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は、台所でりょうりをしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that in Michael's kitchen, there are 3,008,917 empty natto boxes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルの家の台所にはなっとうの空きばこが三百万八千九百十七こおいてあるんだって。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I smell something burning in the kitchen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>台所から焦げ臭い臭いがするよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>revolve</kanji> X number of <kanji>times</kanji>. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is <vocabulary>revolve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rotate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "<jp>回転ずし</jp>?" That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyer belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.
Context 1-EN: My pet hamster is vigorously rotating his hamster wheel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ペットのハムスターがものすごいいきおいで回し車を回転させています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you been to the conveyer belt sushi restaurant over there? Apparently their sushi chefs hate plates there, so the sushi is directly on the rotating, hot conveyor belt.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あそこの回転ずし、もう行った？なんか、そこのすししょく人は皿がきらいらしく、すしが回転してあつくなってるコンベアベルトの上に直でおかれているらしいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The moon revolves around the earth and the earth revolves around the sun.
Context 3-JP: <jp>月は地球の周り回転していて、地球は太陽の周りを回転している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you think about it, an <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a <vocabulary>path</vocabulary> (you know, like a dirt path!) or a <vocabulary>dirt road</vocabulary>. Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the <jp>じ</jp> reading that you learned with <jp>生地</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: Our store is in an alley just off Western Street.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちのお店は、ウェスタン通りから、少し路地に入ったところにあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That path is a bit sketchy at night, so be careful.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その路地は、夜は少しきけんだから気を付けてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The policeman chased the mugger who stole the strawberries down the alley.
Context 3-JP: <jp>警察官は、路地まで苺泥棒を追いかけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>使う</jp> hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>use</kanji> something is the <vocabulary>way of using</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>how to use</vocabulary>). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab words <jp>使う</jp> and <jp>方</jp>. So long as you're okay with those you can apply that knowledge over here.
Context 1-EN: You should be more careful about how you use language.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう少し、言葉の使い方に気を付けた方がいいでしょ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't know how to use iPhones.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アイフォンの使い方が分かりません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to train my dog how to use a hammer and bring him to work with me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>一緒に仕事ができるように、俺の犬に金槌の使い方を訓練してみようと思うんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Catch</kanji> a <kanji>captive</kanji> and he'll be a <vocabulary>prisoner of war</vocabulary>. Or, if you're not in a war, just an ordinary <vocabulary>captive</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Great burdock was fed to the prisoner of war and the Japanese soldier felt guilty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ごぼうを捕虜に食べさせて有罪になった日本兵がいます。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Could you microwave this potato, please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このお芋、レンジでチンしてくれない？</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A thing that <kanji>carries</kanji> <kanji>rotation</kanji>s (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to drive</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I really like driving around aimlessly when I’m on holiday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>休日には、とくにあてもなく運転するのがすきなんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I never look back when I drive. I'm like a shark—only looking forward.
Context 2-JP: <jp>運転する時は、ぜっ対に後ろはふり返りません。サメと同じで、前しか見ないんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This Fugu model car is amazing! I love it! I can’t wait to start driving it every day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このフグモデルの車は最高だね！とても気に入ったよ。毎日運転するのが待ち遠しいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>手</jp> can sometimes refer to a person? In this case, we have a <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> (or perhaps a "person who handles songs"). What is a song person also known as? A <vocabulary>singer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already (you learned <jp>手</jp>'s on'yomi reading with word <jp>投手</jp>), so you should be able to read this like a <vocabulary>singer</vocabulary> sings with a bunch of <reading>cashew</reading>s <jp>かしゅ</jp> in their mouth. FAST AND LOUD!
Context 1-EN: My mother had a large influence in my becoming a singer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歌手になったのは、母のえいきょうが大きいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That singer got quite a tan, didn't she?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの歌手、かなり日やけしたね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I used to be a singer when I was kid. Well, who am I kidding, I’m still a singer now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>子どもの頃は、歌手だったのよ。なんちゃってね。今でも歌手なんですけど。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Sick,To Fall Ill,To Be Ill,To Come Down With,To Suffer From
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sick</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be sick</vocabulary>. It can also be used as <vocabulary>to come down with</vocabulary> when you have the flu or some other illness.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There is only one time you allow yourself to be sick, and that's when the Yankees (や) are playing. You can't miss any games so you just happen to fall ill whenever they're playing so you can stay home and watch. That's pretty convenient, isn't it?
Context 1-EN: Stress interviews make you feel really sick afterwards, don't you agree?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あっぱくめんせつって、終わった後、ほんと病むよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My coworker got sick from work-related stress.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しょく場の同りょうは、仕事のストレスが原いんで病んでしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I never thought that he would get mentally ill.
Context 3-JP: <jp>まさかアイツが心を病むなんてな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There is only one place in Japan that has a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji> and that's <vocabulary>Chiba</vocabulary>. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for 千 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>引く</jp> means "to subtract?" Add <kanji>calculate</kanji> to that and you'll have <vocabulary>subtraction</vocabulary>! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you subtract.
Reading Mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for <jp>引</jp> and the on'yomi for <jp>算</jp>. And the <jp>さん</jp> reading is rendaku'd into <jp>ざん</jp>. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

Reading Mnemonic: This is the kun'yomi reading for <jp>足</jp> and the on'yomi for <jp>算</jp>. And the <jp>さん</jp> reading is rendaku'd into <jp>ざん</jp>. Meaning Mnemonic: Taking the <kanji>nearby</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>short way</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird in this one. It uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary> with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have <jp>ちか</jp> for <jp>近</jp> (short for <jp>近い</jp>) and you have <jp>道</jp> (<jp>みち</jp>), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."
Context 1-EN: Tracing a good picture is a shortcut for improvement.
Context 1-JP: <jp>上手な絵をも写する事は、上たつの近道です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you really think memorizing kanji on WaniKani is actually a shortcut to Japanese acquisition?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニで漢字をおぼえることは、本当に日本語習とくの近道になると思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Oh my God! You are such an airhead! Why are we going down a one-way street?" "I thought it would be a shortcut!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ありえねぇ！お前って本当脳みそ無いのな。なんで一方通行を逆走してるんだよ。」「近道になると思ったんだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>song</kanji> so the verb vocab version of this is <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>, because you don't "to song," you "to sing."
Reading Mnemonic: Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words <jp>歌</jp>. Just throw the <jp>う</jp> onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO <jp>♬</jp>!"
