Context 2-JP: <jp>人前で歌うのはすきじゃないんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "It’s raining outside. I just want to stay in and sing." "I’ll tell you what. Let’s stay in tonight and I’ll make dinner for you if you’ll sing songs for me."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「外は雨が降ってるね。外出せずに家で歌でも歌いたいな。」「じゃあ、こうしよう。今夜は出かけるのをやめよう。で、私が夕食を作るから、あなたは私のために歌ってよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>VIP</kanji> is a <vocabulary>noble visitor</vocabulary>. They're probably a queen or a diplomat or something. So you better treat them really well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When the company president went to welcome a distinguished foreign visitor, I attended as an interpreter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長が外国の貴賓を接待する際に、通訳として同行しました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning: To Fall Down,To Fall,To Drop,To Fail
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fall</kanji> and the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to drop</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to fail</vocabulary>, in the sense of failing an exam.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you start to fall down, what do you yell? "OHHHH (お)!"
Context 1-EN: Your eraser fell under the desk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのけしゴム、つくえの下に落ちていますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: On the day I failed the exam, I dropped my teeth from exhaustion.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しけんに落ちた日に、ひろうから、はがぬけ落ちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "What are you guys playing? Let me in!" "Really? We’re playing a game called Stair Fall where a stickman just keeps falling down the stairs." "Sounds fun!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「何してるの？私も入れて？」「本当？俺たち、ステアフォールっていう、棒人間がひたすら階段から落ちるゲームをしてるんだけど。」「おもしろそうじゃん。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>好き</jp> is "like." Although <jp>好き</jp> is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to like</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is <jp>この</jp>, so think of this. What is it that you're particularly fond of? Getting a <reading>cone</reading> (<jp>この</jp>) with your ice cream (which you're also fond of, who isn't?). Think of all the different cones you can get: waffle cones, sugar cones, oreo cones, yum!
Context 1-EN: This Japanese sake is what my heavy drinker of a father liked when he was alive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この日本酒は、大変酒好きだった私の父が生前に好んで飲んでいたものです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、黒ニンニクを好んで食べます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry, Mr. Koichi. Whether you like it or not, your secrets might get revealed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチさん、申し訳ありませんが、好むと好まざるとに関わらず、あなたの秘密は暴露されてしまうかもしれません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wind</kanji> of the <kanji>gods</kanji>. These are <vocabulary>divine winds</vocabulary>. More popularly, this is a word known as <vocabulary>kamikaze</vocabulary>, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of <jp>風</jp> from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word <jp>神</jp> to be able to read the rest.
Context 1-EN: Divine winds blow on this shrine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この神社には神風がふいています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: At the end of WWII, the Japanese army used the kamikaze corps to attack the American army.
Context 2-JP: <jp>第二次世界大戦の末期には日本ぐんは神風とっこうたいを使ってアメリカぐんをこうげきしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Five years ago, Koichi drove Viet’s troops back from his shores where they were swallowed up by a divine wind.
Context 3-JP: <jp>五年前、神風が吹き、コウイチはビエトの軍隊を海岸から後退させた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji version of <jp>話</jp> means <kanji>talk</kanji>. This word also means <vocabulary>talk</vocabulary>, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my <jp>話</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Who tells a great story? Hana, she (はなし) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too.

You can also use 話す's reading to help you to remember this one, as well.
Context 1-EN: And then you will listen to the story and choose the best answer between 1-4 on the answer sheet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それから話を聞いて、もんだい用紙の１から４の中から、一番いいものを一つえらんでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I didn't sign up for this!
Context 2-JP: <jp>話がちがうよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Now, I’d also like to say something else, Brittany!" "Jeremy! Give it a rest! I’m tired of listening to you."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「それから、私、他にも言いたいことがあるのよ、ブリタニー！」「ジェレミー、いい加減黙ってくれないか！君の話はもう聞き飽きたよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>parent</kanji>s are very close to you, most likely. They are your closest relatives. They are the ones who are <vocabulary>intimate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> with your affairs. They want to know everything!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Those who are most intimate with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the sh*tter (した). Gross, your family is.
Context 1-EN: I've only told this to close friends.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ親しい友人にしか話してないの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They say, "A hedge between keeps friendship green," right? We're good friends, but don't peek at me when I'm on the toilet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「親しき仲にも礼ぎあり」って言うでしょ？いくら親しいからってトイレはのぞかないで！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh Koichi. Calm down. I’ll ask my close friends if anyone can lend you the 80 cents.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと、コウイチ。落ち着いてよ。 親しい友人たちに誰か80セント貸してあげれる人がいないか聞いてみてあげるから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>楽しい</jp>, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means <vocabulary>looking forward to</vocabulary>. Why? Because it has a <jp>み</jp> on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's <reading>me</reading>! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just like <jp>楽しい</jp>, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m looking forward to seeing you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたに会うのが楽しみです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think there are lots of different fun activities during summer break, like going to beach and camping and stuff.
Context 2-JP: <jp>夏休みの楽しみと言えば、海にキャンプに色々あると思いますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are all looking forward to burning turtles, aren’t we?
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達、みんな亀を燃やすのを楽しみにしているんだよね？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>learn</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take lessons in</vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to learn about Nara, the city of deer... lots and lots of deer. If you don't know about it, how about learning about it?
Context 1-EN: I’ve learned Japanese since coming to Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本に来てから、日本語を習いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My older sister is taking piano lessons.
Context 2-JP: <jp>姉は、ピアノを習っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to learn how to make the world’s best fugu cookies today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は、世界一のフグクッキーの作り方を習いに行くのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>VIP</kanji> from another <kanji>country</kanji> is a <vocabulary>state guest</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The American President visited Japan as a state guest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカ大統領が国賓として来日しました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dark</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is an <vocabulary>assassination</vocabulary>. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That yakuza boss ended up getting assassinated.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのヤクザの組長は暗殺されてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you already watched the Assassination Classroom movie? It was fun, isn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>もう暗殺教室の映画は見ましたか？とってもおも白いですよね〜。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, Viet! How did you come up with such a unique assassination plan?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、ビエト！どうやってこんなに面白い暗殺計画を思いついたの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>think</kanji>. You can't help but think, you do it <vocabulary>unintentionally</vocabulary>. So put this in front of things to say that you did them <vocabulary>involuntarily</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is the kun'yomi reading which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I spoke of my real intentions unintentionally.
Context 1-JP: <jp>思わず本音を口にしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi farted sooooo loudly that everybody reflexively covered their ears, but we should have covered our noses instead.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチがすんげー大きな音のオナラをしたから、みんな思わず耳をふさいだんだけど、はなをふさいだ方がよかったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I saw the delicious looking picture and involuntarily started drooling.
Context 3-JP: <jp>美味しそうな写真を見て、思わず涎が出た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>pour</kanji> your <kanji>ideas</kanji> into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close <vocabulary>attention</vocabulary> and using <vocabulary>caution</vocabulary>. You'll see this on a lot of signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Today, I got a warning from my boss.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日、上しに注意されちゃったよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you’re reading in Japanese, pay attention to interesting words and grammar.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本語で何かを読んでいる時には、おも白い語句や文ぽうに注意を払って下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m worried that he’s going down the wrong path. I cautioned him, but he doesn’t listen to me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は彼が間違った道を進んでるんじゃないかと心配しているのよ。注意したんだけど、聞く耳持たずって感じで。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>God</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji>... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a <vocabulary>Shinto Shrine</vocabulary> because of the <jp>しん</jp> in the <jp>神</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: But wait! <jp>神</jp> is read <jp>じん</jp> in this word for some reason. Darn them gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto Shrine. You are praying to the Gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains <reading>Ginger</reading> (<jp>じんじゃ</jp>). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.
Context 1-EN: When I visited a shinto shrine at the beginning of the new year, I saw Koichi and Viet having a fist fight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>神社に初もうでに行ったら、コウイチとビエトがなぐり合いのけんかをしていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I totally forgot about the charm I bought at a shinto shrine in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本の神社で買ったおまもりのこと、すっかりわすれてた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yo! Very cool selfie, but why were you in a shinto shrine instead of at school?
Context 3-JP: <jp>よぉ、中々イケてる自撮りじゃん。でも、お前、なんで学校じゃなくて神社になんていたんだよ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>finger</kanji>. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to point</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You are pointing at something in fear. It is a saw (さ). Thing is, you're pointing at this saw with a missing finger. It just cut off your finger and you're freaking out, trying to point with a bloody non-finger.
Context 1-EN: Which way is the arrow pointing?
Context 1-JP: <jp>矢じるしは、どちらの方向を指していますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Japan, it's rude to point at people with your finger.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人を指で指すのは、日本では失礼です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh, you’re color blind, eh? So that means you can’t point at which one is red and which one is green, then.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ああ、あなたは色盲なんですか。ということは、どっちが赤色でどっちが緑色かを指すことはできませんね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is towards (<jp>に</jp>) <kanji>special</kanji>. That thing is <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> special, wouldn't you say?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same reading you learned for this kanji.
Context 1-EN: You have to be quiet, especially in the hospital.
Context 1-JP: <jp>特に病院ではしずかにしなければいけません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This melon is particularly hard. It's like a squash.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このメロンは特にかたいですね。まるでカボチャのようだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "What would you like for supper?" "Anything is fine. I’m not especially picky."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「お夕飯は何が食べたい？」「何でもいいよ。特にこだわりはないよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Everyone has to <kanji>carry</kanji> their <kanji>fate</kanji>. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your <vocabulary>fate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you believe in destiny?
Context 1-JP: <jp>運命をしんじますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I thought those two were tied together by the red thread of fate, but it seems that their hearts are growing ever distant.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二人は運命の赤い糸でむすばれているって思ってたけど、だんだん心がはなれていってるみたい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Rest in peace iPhone. I just dropped it in a toilet filled with more than just water. Maybe this was just fate but I am so sad right now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>iPhoneさん天国行き。用を足した後のトイレに落としちゃいました。まぁ、これがiPhoneさんの運命だったのかもしれないけどさ。でも、猛烈に悲しいぜよ...。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>natur</kanji>ally <kanji>right</kanji> is something that's very <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary>. You know that, right? <jp>当然</jp>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Wow! You scored a one hundred on that test?" "Naturally."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「すごい！あのテストで百点とったの？」「当然さ。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's only natural that you must practice kanji little by little every day in order to become good at it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かん字が上手くなりたければ毎日少しずつ練習するのは当然でしょう！</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are very lucky to have such a lovely wife. Don’t take her for granted.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あんな素敵な奥さんがいるなんて、お前は本当に運がいいよな。当然のことだなんて思うなよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! No need to burn any <jp>橋s</jp> with this word and its kanji.
Context 1-EN: Woah, he kissed me on the bridge!
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれに橋の上でキスされちゃった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you sing a song with my daughter while crossing the bridge?
Context 2-JP: <jp>橋をわたる間、むすめと歌を一しょに歌ってくれませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The name of the bridge built in 1603 is Nihonbashi and it was truly the central point of Japan, as its name suggests.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その1603年に建てられた橋の名前は日本橋といいます。日本橋は、その名の通りまさに日本の中心でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading (<jp>倉</jp>) you learned earlier. They're both basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (<reading><jp>くら</jp></reading>).
Context 1-EN: We are cleaning our storehouse now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今、蔵の掃除をしているんです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning: To Be Returned,To Return,To Come Back
Meaning Mnemonic: You hopefully know the word <jp>返す</jp>, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning). Use the <jp>る</jp> to help you to remember this. <jp>る</jp> the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>返す</jp>, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.
Context 1-EN: When he came to, he was lying on the sofa in the Tofugu office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>われに返ると、かれはトーフグオフィスのソファーに横たわっていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The precious keepsake pendant from my mom that I thought I'd lost was returned to me before I knew it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>失くしたと思っていた大事な母の形見のペンダントが気づいたら手元に返ってきていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thinking my money would be returned properly was a huge mistake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>貸したお金がちゃんと返ってくると思ったら大間違いよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>feeling</kanji> the <kanji>fever</kanji>, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of  <vocabulary>passion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You can do whatever you want as long as you have passion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>情熱さえあれば何だってできるよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't believe how enthusiastic Viet is.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトがこんなに情熱てきだったなんて、信じられません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi decided to make his passion in life achieving a fusion between Japanese and American traditions.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、日本とアメリカの伝統を融合させることに、生涯情熱を捧げることを決意しました。</jp>

Meaning: To Release,To Let Go,To Release Something,To Let Go Of Something
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you are going <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary> something. It is a <reading><jp>花</jp></reading> (<jp>はな</jp>). You release it from your hand and it falls, hitting the ground in slow motion. You have the power to release and you are doing the releasing (versus <jp>放れる</jp> where something is just released). You can remember this because even though you did the releasing of the flower, you're going to sue the pavement company for breaking your flower. It's all a big scam you're running.
Context 1-EN: Let go of me!
Context 1-JP: <jp>放せよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi finally released Viet's hand after thirty minutes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>三十分後、コウイチはついにビエトの手を放した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Every time I let Fugu loose in the sea, he swims off and when I call him he doesn’t listen. What should I do to teach him to not run away?
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグを海に放すといつも、泳いで逃げちゃって、私が呼んでも知らんぷりするの。どうすれば逃げないように教えることができるのかしら。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Western style</kanji>d <kanji>West</kanji> is still known as <vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>. The one everyone refers to over in Asia when they talk about <vocabulary>Western countries</vocabulary> in Europe and North America. This is the place you'll hear people say you're from if you live in Canada or something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How many Tofugu fans are there in the West?
Context 1-JP: <jp>西洋には、トーフグのファンはどのぐらいいますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: India has a very low divorce rate compared to Western countries.
Context 2-JP: <jp>西洋の国々にくらべて、インドのりこんりつはとても低い。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That’s a Western ghost.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これは、西洋の妖怪です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: My husband's eye color is storm gray.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの主人の目の色は、緑がかったはい色です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Choosing a green carpet shows you have pretty bad taste, right?
Context 2-JP: <jp>緑のじゅうたんとか、ちょっと悪しゅ味だよね。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi as you probably guessed from the hiragana sticking out, but that doesn't matter because you learned the kun'yomi readings already.

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you attach your energy (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), you have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means to realize or to notice.

Don't confuse this with 気を付けて which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the <jp>気</jp> kanji (which you know) and the word <jp>付く</jp> which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the <jp>付く</jp> part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.
Context 1-EN: Don't pretend like you didn't notice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>気付かないふりはしないでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think I realized my feelings for Koichiko three days after we met.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチ子へのおもいに気付いたのはかの女と出会って三日目のことだったと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t believe you gave me your ice cream. I didn’t realize that you were so kind until now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あんたが私にアイスクリームをくれるなんて、本当に信じられないよ。あんたがそんなに優しいなんて今まで気付かなかったわ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a fun one. <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>silver</kanji> is <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>quicksilver</vocabulary>, if you prefer.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The larger the oceanic fish, the more mercury in its body.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海魚の体が大きいほど体内にたくさん水銀がたまっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wonder if it's a coincidence that we call both Mercury, the planet, and mercury, the substance, "mercury" in English.
Context 2-JP: <jp>水星と水銀はえい語で共にマーキュリーと言いますが、これはぐう然でしょうか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s so funny that people used to insert mercury thermometers into their butts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昔はみんな水銀体温計をお尻に差し込んでいたんだよね。めっちゃうける。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji>'s <kanji>universal</kanji>? <vocabulary>How many times</vocabulary> do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because <jp>へん</jp> becomes <jp>べん</jp> here.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>topic</kanji> that we are <kanji>talk</kanji>ing about is the <vocabulary>topic</vocabulary> that we are talking about. It's the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of our conversation.

Meaning Mnemonic: *Ahem.* This is the <kanji>place</kanji> of <kanji>convenience</kanji>. What place above all others do you want to be convenient? Just in case, you know... that would be the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary>. You might also call it the <vocabulary>lavatory</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the rendaku.

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned the words <jp>文字</jp> and <jp>通り</jp>? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is <vocabulary>literally</vocabulary> <vocabulary>to the letter</vocabulary>. Wink.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>文字</jp> and <jp>通り</jp>, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this one. Just make sure you remember that <jp>とおり</jp> becomes <jp>どおり</jp> because of rendaku.

Meaning Mnemonic:
The fat peace ocean is the Pacific Ocean. The Japanese language thinks this ocean is peaceful, just like English does (the word 太平 actually means "peace").

Note that we're using the alternative meaning of 洋 here! If you didn't learn that with the kanji, just imagine that to get to Western Style places you need to cross the ocean from Japan!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The Tofugu team is planning a company retreat to travel across the Pacific Ocean on a luxury cruise.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグチームは、ごうか客せんで太平洋をわたる社いんりょ行をけいかくしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That Pacific bluefin tuna in the fridge is Kanae's souvenir.
Context 2-JP: <jp>冷ぞうこの中の太平洋クロマグロは、カナエちゃんのお土産です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Nowadays, most pufferfish are harvested in the spring during the spawning season, then farmed in floating cages in the Pacific Ocean.
Context 3-JP: <jp>現在、ほとんどの河豚は繁殖期である春に収穫され、太平洋に浮かぶ籠の中で養殖されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word uses <jp>長</jp> in the same way as <jp>社長</jp>, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this <jp>長</jp> is the boss of the <kanji>station</kanji>, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the <vocabulary>stationmaster</vocabulary> (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My favorite idol was selected to be a one-day train station master.

Context 3-EN: Oh my God! Did the station master just spit on the train? Did you see that?
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわっ！あの駅長、今電車に唾はかなかったか？お前、見たか？</jp>

Meaning: Train Station Employee,Train Station Staff,Train Station Attendant,Station Attendant,Station Employee
Meaning Mnemonic: A train <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at the train station. They are a <vocabulary>train station employee</vocabulary>. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 3-EN: You couldn’t tell from looking at him, but that station attendant is a really rich guy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの駅員、こう見えてすっごくお金持ちなのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>instance</vocabulary> of what you're describing. Just one <vocabulary>example</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is just one example.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これはほんの一例にすぎません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As an example, you can't get skinnier by simply eating less rice and potatoes.

Context 3-JP: <jp>秘書としてサーモンを迎え入れた後で、彼女が職場で突然感情を爆発させる性格であることが判明したのです。例えば、自分のデスクの電話を引き抜いて、粉々にブチ壊しちゃったりとか、まあ、ほんの一例を挙げればそんな感じです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>仮名</jp> means "kana?" Well this is <kanji>flat</kanji> kana. Flat kana is just <vocabulary>hiragana</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You should know the reading for this word because it's the same as the English meaning.

Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトが、平仮名を五分で全部おぼえられるアプリを開発しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>流行</jp> refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" <kanji>song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>popular song</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We say "pop song" these days, so when I hear "popular song," it reminds me of popular songs from the Showa period.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今時は「流行りの歌」って言うよね。「流行歌」っていうとなんかしょう和の歌よう曲って感じがする。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Follow our Twitter for updates on the latest popular songs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ツイッターでフォローして、最新の流行歌情ほうをチェックしてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like finding good music, but not necessarily popular songs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、流行歌ではないけど良い曲を見つけるのが好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Cooperation</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your level of <vocabulary>cooperation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is the result of everyone's cooperation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは皆様のご協力のたまものです。</jp>

Context 3-JP: <jp>我々に協力するか、少なくとも協力するふりをしてくれませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've already been introduced to the word <jp>苦しい</jp>. That word means painful, or agonizing. So, if you turn that into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to suffer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>苦しい</jp>, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.
Context 1-EN: I struggle to understand Tofugu's way of thinking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの考え方は、理かいに苦しみます。</jp>

Context 2-JP: <jp>はんざいに手をそめるようそそのかしてくるコウイチからの強れつなプレッシャーに苦しんでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why do innocent people suffer?
Context 3-JP: <jp>なぜ罪のない人が苦しんでいるのか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>labor</kanji> for <kanji>work</kanji> is a <vocabulary>laborer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What does president Koichi think about the shortage of blue-collar workers?

Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっとコピー機使わせてもらってもいい？新しい労働者を雇うために、チラシを作ってるんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: On the <kanji>surface</kanji> of a <kanji>score</kanji> you'll find <vocabulary>music</vocabulary>. This is only written music though, so remember that this music has to be on the surface of some paper.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 3-EN: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conflict</kanji> so the vocabulary means <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to argue</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to quarrel</vocabulary>. Your views conflict with someone else's so you're going to compete with them to see who's right.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're starting to compete and to argue with someone, who is yelling at you: "You are so (あらそ) stupid!". You might want to imagine this in an accent that gets you closer to the Japanese pronuncation.
Context 1-EN: Please don't argue about me!
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの事で争うのはよして！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu workers are competing with each other for the position of president.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社いんたちは、社長のざをねらって争っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are so chill. It’s great hanging out with you. You know what? We’ve never had an argument yet, either. That’s crazy, isn’t it?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたって本当に落ち着いているし楽しいし、あなたと遊ぶのは最高だわ。しかも、私たち言い争ったこともまだ一度も無いわよね。それってすごくない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> of your <kanji>foundation</kanji> is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the <jp>基本</jp> portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary> you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I think Darin's claim is fundamentally right, and that this formula is basic to mathematics.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この公しきが数学の基本だというダリン君の主ちょうは、基本的に正しいと思います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is learning the basics of Yakuza external economic policy from Viet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ビエトからヤクザの対外けいざいせいさくの基本について学んでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m a super beginner who doesn’t even know the most basic of basics of Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は日本語の基本中の基本も知らない超初心者です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>season</kanji>s are <vocabulary>the four seasons</vocabulary>. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that <jp>四</jp> is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of <jp>し</jp> meaning "death" (like <jp>死</jp>), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.
Context 1-EN: The photos Viet took depict the beauty of the four seasons very well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトのとった写しんは、四季の美しさをとてもよくびょう写しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My younger brother used to wear Japanese geta all year round.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの弟は、昔は四季を通じて下たをはいていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can you tell me about Japan’s four seasons and what people do and eat during them?
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の四季についてと、それぞれの季節にどんなことをしたりどんなものを食べるのかについて、教えてもらえませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Pardon</kanji> someone out of the <kanji>kindness</kanji> in your heart and you'll have granted them <vocabulary>amnesty</vocabulary>. How kind of you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The president granted amnesty to the turkey.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大統領は、七面鳥に恩赦を与えた。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fruit</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as <vocabulary>fructose</vocabulary>. Mmm, delicious fructose.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s said that high-fructose corn syrup isn’t good for you, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブドウ糖果糖液糖は体に悪いって言うじゃない？</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Long ago</kanji> people used to <kanji>talk</kanji> about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about <vocabulary>folk tale</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku of <jp>はなし</jp> to <jp>ばなし</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Is this a Japanese folk tale?
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは日本の昔話ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That's like a princess in a legend.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まるで昔話の中に出てくるおひめさまみたいね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: While waiting for a bus in the bus shelter, I read a folk tale picture book for my child.
Context 3-JP: <jp>バス待合所でバスを待ちながら、昔話の絵本を子どもに読み聞かせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a lot like <jp>鳴く</jp>, which means "to chirp" (or some other animal noise). This has to do with noises too, but not so much animal and more like bells (including telephones). This word means <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>. If it helps, think of the <jp>る</jp> as a hint, kind of like the first sound of the word "ring" (<jp>る</jp>). So, <jp>る</jp> = "ring" and it's a verb, so <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can come from <jp>鳴く</jp>. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: My stomach growled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お腹が鳴ってしまった。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>だれかの電話が鳴ってるね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thunder rumbled but it didn’t rain.
Context 3-JP: <jp>雷が鳴ったが、雨は降らなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You should know <jp>開ける</jp> by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Do you remember the reading for 開ける, which you learned in level 10? That's right, it's あける! So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.

Just a quick side note — 開く can also be read as ひらく, but we're going to focus on the あく reading here. Since ひらく has slightly different meanings, we won't accept it as a reading for this word, so be sure to enter あく!
Context 1-EN: What time does this shop open?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このお店は何時に開きますか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>社会のまどが開いていますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Excuse me, is the Tofugu Museum open tomorrow?" "Yes, it's open."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「すみません。トーフグ博物館は明日は開いてますか？」「開いてますよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning <vocabulary>yard</vocabulary> to your memory bank as well, if you'd like.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a <reading>newer</reading> (<jp>にわ</jp>) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!
Context 1-EN: I'm gonna level the ground in the yard today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は、庭の地ならしをします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I grow vegetables in our garden.
Context 2-JP: <jp>庭で家庭さいえんをしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a beautiful garden but my neighbor’s chickens keep eating my flowers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちには美しい庭があるんだが、隣の人の鶏がいつも花を食べてしまうんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>excuse</kanji> and a <kanji>pardon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pardon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>amnesty</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He was granted a special pardon for his crimes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は特別に罪の赦免が認められた。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Lumber</kanji> <kanji>tree</kanji>s are what you use to make <vocabulary>lumber</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>timber</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why are you mopping that wood with a Quickle wiper?
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんで材木にクイックルワイパーをかけてるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that if you go to the lumber yard at 8 p.m. you'll be able to meet God.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの材木おき場に夜の八時に行くと、神様に会えるらしいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We should get started building the doghouse as soon as the lumber gets here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>材木が来たらすぐに犬小屋作りに取り掛からないとな。</jp>

Meaning: To Pass A Test,To Pass An Exam
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>status</kanji> <kanji>joins</kanji> together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing <vocabulary>to pass a test</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You worked so hard to pass the exam, so why did you quit university so suddenly?
Context 1-JP: <jp>折角苦労して合格したのに、何でそんなすぐに大学やめちゃったの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: As of this morning, I didn't know if I passed the exam yet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今朝の時点では、まだ合格したのかどうか分からなかったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I attended a cram school ostensibly to pass entrance exams, but I actually just wanted to hang out with my friends there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>表向きは入学試験に合格するために学習塾に通ってたんだけど、私は実は友達と一緒にいたかっただけなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>leaves</kanji> of a <kanji>pine</kanji> are not really leaves, they're more like needles, thus making this word <vocabulary>pine needle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>葉</jp> gets rendaku'd to <jp>ば</jp> though, so watch out for that.
Context 1-EN: One dried pine needle was laying on the floor of my room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かんそうした松葉が一本私の部屋のゆかに落ちていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The pine needle spun ten times and fell into a puddle.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その松葉は、クルクルと十回転した後、水たまりへ落ちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Getting this raise will finally enable me to buy a Matsuba crab for my parents.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今度の昇給が得られれば、ようやく両親に松葉ガニを買ってやることができる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tooth</kanji> <kanji>bug</kanji>... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that <jp>は</jp> turns to <jp>ば</jp>, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.
Context 1-EN: Today, I had my decayed tooth extracted at the dentist.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日、歯医者で虫歯をぬいてもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Streptococcus mutans bacteria, the cause of tooth decay, can be transferred from adults to the kids around them as they grow up.
Context 2-JP: <jp>虫歯のげんいんであるミュータンスきんは子どもの成長とともにまわりの大人からうつってしまいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have so many cavities but I don’t have dental insurance and I can’t afford to get them treated.
Context 3-JP: <jp>虫歯がいっぱいあるんだけど、歯科保険が無いので、治療代を捻出することができないんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extinguish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extinguish</vocabulary>. You can also use this word to refer to turning something off (like lights). Technically you're extinguishing the lights or power, right?
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The <reading>ke</reading>ttle is getting too hot so it catches on fire. You have to extinguish the flames before your house burns down too, just because of this stupid little kettle.
Context 1-EN: I have a past that I want to erase.
Context 1-JP: <jp>消したい過去があるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I erased all the data by mistake.
Context 2-JP: <jp>間違えてデータを全部消しちゃったんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After you leave the classroom, please don’t forget to turn off the light.
Context 3-JP: <jp>教室を出た後は電気を消すのを忘れないで下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Don't think of this as a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. Think of <jp>話</jp> the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a <vocabulary>children's story</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This fairy tale will actually make you cry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この童話、意外と泣けるんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm finally getting serious about writing children's stories.
Context 2-JP: <jp>やっと、童話のしっぴつに、本気モードになってきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Miyazawa Kenji’s fairy tale "Night of the Festival" was my favorite story when I was a child.
Context 3-JP: <jp>宮沢賢治の童話「祭の晩」は、私が子供の頃大好きなお話でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>floor</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second floor</vocabulary>. Going up!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The dentist is on the second floor of this building.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歯医者さんなら、このビルの二階にあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We bought a second story home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二階だてのマイホームを買いました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Every afternoon I go to the same classroom on the second floor and teach two hours of English.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎日午後に二階にある同じ教室に行って、英語を二時間教えます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of <vocabulary>times</vocabulary> something has increased. For example, <jp>３倍</jp> means something increased "three fold."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the <jp>〜</jp> when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.
Context 1-EN: WaniKani's review count has quadrupled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニのレビューの数が四倍になってしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why not just pay me ten times more than usual on Christmas day at least?
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリスマスの日ぐらい、きゅうりょうを十倍にしてくれたっていいじゃないか！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since the introduction and subsequent spread of conveyer belt sushi shops, salmon consumption in Japan has tripled.
Context 3-JP: <jp>回転寿司の普及に伴い、日本におけるサーモンの消費量は輸入開始から三倍となった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: By now you should know that <jp>終わる</jp> means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the finish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>終わる</jp>. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!
Context 1-EN: This is the end.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これで終わりだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: All is well that ends well, right?
Context 2-JP: <jp>終わり良ければ全て良し、でしょ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Work ends this week and Christmas holidays starts next week! Aww I can't wait for that.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今週で仕事も終わりで、来週からはクリスマス休暇だー！あー、待ちきれない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You receive <kanji>profit</kanji> at every <kanji>breath</kanji>. What kind of profit is this? It's <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary>. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you miss the interest payment, Viet will probably bring some of his yakuza friends to your place.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし利息の支はらいがおくれたら、ビエトがヤクザの友だちをつれてお前のところにやって来ると思うぜ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi has enough money in the bank to live on his interest.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは利息で生活できるぐらい十分なお金をぎん行にちょ金しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m afraid there is no one here who can answer your question right now, but you can also check your interest rate online, if you can connect to the Internet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あいにく今、その質問に答えられる者がいないのですが、もしインターネットにアクセス可能なら利息のレートはそちらでもご確認頂けますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place where <kanji>I</kanji> <kanji>stand</kanji> is my own <vocabulary>private</vocabulary> area. Think of the "circle of personal space." This is where you stand plus an arm's length. This area is very private to you. Who knows what you do in your own private area.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The private kindergartens are closed on Christmas Day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私立のようちえんはクリスマスの日はお休みだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Go out of here and walk left along the street until you come to the third intersection and you'll get to the private hospital.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ここを出て、前の通りを左の方へ三つ目の交さ点まで歩くと、その私立病院に着きますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I found out that the guy Koichi secretly met at the cafe was a private detective.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチがカフェでこっそり会っていた男の人は、私立探偵だったということが判明しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is something that will first <kanji>extinguish</kanji> something and then <kanji>change</kanji> it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your <vocabulary>digestion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This medicine will stimulate your digestion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このくすりは、消化をそく進してくれます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's having a touch of diarrhea, so please have him eat something easy to digest.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは下り気味だから、消化の良いものを食べさせてあげてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I haven’t finished digesting the ramen I ate for lunch.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昼に食べたラーメンをまだ消化しきっていない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>約束</jp> is a “promise.” So when you add <jp>する</jp> to it you’re making it a verb, meaning <vocabulary>to promise</vocabulary>. Now promise you’ll remember!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>約束</jp> with <jp>する</jp> added. Make sure you know <jp>約束</jp> and you'll know this word as well.
Context 1-EN: "Let's get married when we grow up." "Promise?" "Yes. I promise."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「大きくなったらけっこんしよう。」「約束する？」「うん、約束するよ。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you promise that you won't tell this to anybody else?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ぜっ対にだれにも言わないって、約束してくれる？</jp>
Context 3-EN: As they sang a song that goes, "If I lie, I'll cut my pinky off and drink a thousand needles," they pinky promised to make pancakes on Sunday together.
Context 3-JP: <jp>二人は、「指切拳万、嘘ついたら針千本呑ます」という歌を歌いながら指切りをし、日曜日に一緒にホットケーキを作ろうと約束した。</jp>

Meaning: As One Pleases,One's Own Convenience,One's Own Way,One's Way
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> (or person, as you know <jp>手</jp> often refers to a person) that <kanji>win</kanji>s gets to do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary> you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small <jp>っ</jp> in there before, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.
Context 1-EN: You are so selfish!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ほんと、勝手だよね！</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>勝手なことばっかり言わないでよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Salmon! Fugu cheated on you five times. Never trust a guy like that." "I know… but he says he can’t live without me." "Well, suit yourself then!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「サーモン！フグは五回も浮気したんだよ。そんな男のこと、信じちゃダメだってば。」「分かってるんだけど、でも、彼、私がいないと生きていけないって言うの。」「じゃあ、もう、勝手にすれば！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>double</vocabulary> (or it is just simply <vocabulary>two times</vocabulary>). Of course, this all works with things like <jp>三倍</jp>, <jp>百倍</jp>, and <jp>四十二倍</jp> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This stock's price doubled just in two days.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このかぶのかぶかはたったの二日で二倍になった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't forget to dilute the noodle soup base two times.
Context 2-JP: <jp>めんつゆを二倍にうすめるのを忘れないでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wow! Your brother weighs twice as much as you, huh?
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわ！君のお兄さんって、君の二倍の体重があるんだね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>wear</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swimsuit</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>bathing suit</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>swimwear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. <jp>着</jp> uses the reading you learned with the vocab word <jp>着る</jp>, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that <jp>き</jp> becomes <jp>ぎ</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: I forgot to bring my bathing suit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水着を持ってくるの、わすれちゃった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why is Koichi wearing women's swimwear?
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんでコウイチは女せい用水着を着てるの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you have swimsuits? I’m looking for a super sexy one.
Context 3-JP: <jp>水着はありますか？とびきりセクシーなのを探しているんですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>climb</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as <jp>上る</jp> which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!
Context 1-EN: Going up this long, steep slope is really tough, eh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この長くてきゅうなさかを登るのはかなりキツイっすね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi climbed up the tree as fast as a monkey and came down with bananas without breaking a sweat.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、さるのようにスイスイと木に登り、いともかんたんにバナナを取っておりてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A dream of mine is to climb Mt. Fuji at least once in my lifetime.
Context 3-JP: <jp>一生の内、少なくとも一度は富士山に登ることが夢なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Beauty</kanji> <kanji>art</kanji> is <vocabulary>fine art</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I am taking a fine arts class at college.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学で美術のクラスをとっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Leaders of companies need to have a sense for fine art, but Koichi doesn't have anything like that.
Context 2-JP: <jp>き業のリーダーには美術のセンスも必要とされるが、コウイチにはそんなセンスは全くない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Aya named her hideout the "Tofugu Terrible Art Gallery" because it was filled with her beautiful artwork-stuffed corpses. Koichi and Viet were to join her collection.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アヤは、人間の剥製という美しい美術作品が並べられたアジトを「Tofuguの恐ろしい美術館」と名付けた。そして、コウイチとビエトもその剥製の一つにされようとしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>spirit</kanji> of <kanji>sunshine</kanji> you're a really <vocabulary>cheerful</vocabulary> person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You are really blessed to have such a cheerful wife who's good at cooking and loves her children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>りょう理上手で子ども好きで陽気なおくさんがいるなんて、お前は本当にしあわせものだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got carried away by the warm spring weather and fell asleep before I knew it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>はるの陽気にさそわれて、いつの間にかねむってしまっていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My family is poor but jovial.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちの家族は貧乏だが陽気だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Do you remember the word <jp>転がる</jp>? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means <vocabulary>to fall over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a <jp>ぶ</jp> sound.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>転がる</jp>. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.
Context 1-EN: It was funny that the player fell over after hitting a game-ending home run.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サヨナラホームランを打った後であのせん手が転んだのはおも白かったね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today, Koichi didn't cry even though he fell down for the first time in a long time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日のコウイチは、久しぶりに転んでもなかなかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi had almost fallen to the ground but he was saved by Viet, who was wearing a Superman costume.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはもう少しで地面に転ぶところだったが、スーパーマンのコスプレをしたビエトに助けられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You gotta <kanji>believe</kanji> it will <kanji>return</kanji>. What are you believing in returning? The <vocabulary>reply</vocabulary>. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Oh no, I forgot to reply. What have I gotten myself into?
Context 1-JP: <jp>やばい、返信するのわすれてた。ちょっと大変なことになってしまうかも。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It said "read," but I never got a reply.
Context 2-JP: <jp>き読になったのに、いつまでたっても返信が来ないんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How’s it going? I thought I sent a reply to you, but it seems that I was too tired and fell asleep before pressing the ’send’ button. Sorry. Forgive me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お疲れ〜。返信したつもりだったんだけど、どうやら力尽きて、送信ボタンを押す前に寝てたみたい。ごめんね、許して〜。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>task</kanji> is to <kanji>believe</kanji>. In order to do that, you have to have plenty of <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> in what you believe in... not to mention <vocabulary>confidence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The Tofugu team completely trusts what Koichi says.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグチームは、コウイチの言うことを全めん的に信用しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's scandal has injured Tofugu's credit.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの不しょう事が、トーフグの信用をきずつけてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I thought I would score some points with my wife if I cleaned the house, made dinner, gave her a massage, and sung her to sleep, but instead she divorced me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、掃除や料理、マッサージや寝る前の歌なんかで、妻から信用点をつけられていると思っていたが、なんと逆に離婚されてしまったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the <vocabulary>school term</vocabulary>. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time???
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but <jp>がく</jp> gets shortened to <jp>がっ</jp>, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened <jp>がく</jp> like that?
Context 1-EN: I am planning to take Japanese and kimono classes with Fugu next semester as well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>次の学期にもフグと日本語と着物のクラスをとるつもりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After this term ends, Koichi and Koichiko will have their wedding ceremony in Hawaii.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この学期が終わったら、コウイチとコウイチ子はハワイでけっこんしきをあげる予定です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Final exams are held in March so there's still plenty of time to prepare.
Context 3-JP: <jp>学期末試験は三月なので、まだまだ勉強する時間はたっぷりあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plant</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to plant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for 植 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You decided to plant an uni (う) tree in your backyard. That's right, you can plant uni and they'll grow like fruit off a really spiky tree. Just picture it. And then you'll get to eat all the uni you want!
Context 1-EN: There are some cacti planted on the rooftop of the Tofugu office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグオフィスの屋上にはサボテンが植えてあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think you've planted more than enough tulips.
Context 2-JP: <jp>チューリップ、ちょっと植えすぎなぐらい植えたんじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Where do you plan on planting that seed?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この種をどこに植えるつもりだい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: That <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>courage</kanji> is <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: WaniKani users were encouraged by Koichi's speech.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニユーザーは、コウイチのスピーチに勇気づけられました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It usually takes courage to oppose other people, but you don't have to worry about that when you work at Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>他の人の意見に反対するにはふ通は勇気がいると思うけど、トーフグで働いている時はそんな心配はいらないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Fugu, my dad was a great person. He always told me that it requires strength and courage to swim against the stream, while any dead fish can float with it." "Salmon, isn’t that a quote by Samuel Smiles?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「フグ、私のお父さんは素晴らしい人だったのよ。いつも私に、流れに逆らって泳ぐには力と勇気が必要だ。浮かぶだけなら死んだ魚でもできるって言ってたわ。」「サーモン、それって、サミュエル・スマイルズの名言じゃなかったっけ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>紹介</jp> is an introduction. So the verb version is <vocabulary>to introduce</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.
Context 1-EN: It’s hard to choose which girl to introduce to you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前にどの娘を紹介するかを選ぶのは難しいよ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: For a <kanji>period of time</kanji> you have to <kanji>wait</kanji>. During this waiting period, you are <vocabulary>expect</vocabulary>ing or <vocabulary>anticipat</vocabulary>ing something to happen. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I expected more from the grad student.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの大学院生には、もっと期待してたのに。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The new snack that I bought and had sent all the way from Japan the other day was not as good as I anticipated.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この前わざわざ日本からとりよせた新しいおやつは期待外れでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wall Street always needs top-level talent and I’m pretty sure that Koichi will be able to live up to those expectations.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ウォール・ストリートは常にトップレベルの人材を求めていますが、コウイチならきっとそこでも期待に応えられると思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a weird one. You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a <vocabulary>first rate</vocabulary> stream in terms of quality and anything else.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That's something only first-rate pianists can do.
Context 1-JP: <jp>さすが、一流のピアニストは違うね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My sister fell in love with a wealthy, first-class gentleman.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの妹は、お金持ちで一流のしんしとこいに落ちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is now a member of the upperclass. He will meet a bunch of celebrities and start going to champagne parties soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これでコウイチは一流社会の仲間入りだ。たくさんのセレブに会ったり、シャンパンパーティにもすぐ行き始めるだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>mother</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is the <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of <jp>母</jp> and <jp>親</jp>. If you do, you should be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: I want to make up with my mother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母親と仲直りがしたい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mother and her boyfriend ended up breaking up because apparently they had been gradually growing apart.
Context 2-JP: <jp>母親とそのかれ氏、気持ちがだんだんはなれていっちゃったみたいで、けっきょく別れたんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m sorry but I have to cancel lunch tomorrow. My mother got sick." "It’s no big deal. Let’s meet another time. I hope your mom gets well soon."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ごめんなさい。明日のランチ、キャンセルしなくちゃいけなくなったの。母親がちょっと体調崩しちゃって。」 「気にしないで。また今度、会いましょう。それより、お母様、早く良くなるといいわね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>carry</kanji> your <kanji>move</kanji>ments (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing <vocabulary>exercise</vocabulary>. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I feel like I haven't had enough exercise recently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近、運動不足気味です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to exercise, but I don't have time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>運動したいけど、時間がないんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I read neither books, nor newspapers, nor magazines because I like exercising more than reading.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は読書よりも運動の方が好きなので、本も、新聞も、雑誌も読みません。</jp>

Meaning: Shop Staff,Store Staff,Store Employee,Shop Employee,Clerk,Shop Assistant
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the <vocabulary>shop staff</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I used to have a part time job where I taught English to the younger brother of that clerk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昔、あの店員の弟に家庭教しのバイトで英語を教えていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That shop employee was a real kidder, wasn't he?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの店員さん、とってもお茶目だったね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Well, while standing in the checkout line I heard one of the salespeople yell, "Shoplifter! Grab him!" so I grabbed him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>えっと、レジの順番待ちの列に並んでいる時に、ある店員さんが「万引きです！捕まえて！」と叫ぶのが聞こえたので、彼を捕まえたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>sword</kanji> is the <vocabulary>short sword</vocabulary>. What's another word for a short sword? It's a <vocabulary>dagger</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Where did you buy that tanto?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その短刀、どこで買ったの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet cooks very well with a short sword.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは、短刀を使ってとても上手にりょう理をします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mother stabbed my father with a dagger and he died.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の父は、母に短刀で刺されて死にました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji>s means <vocabulary>all members</vocabulary>. This is also a fancy way to say <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: They are all males.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全員男せいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They decided that every Tofugu employee will take the bacon sommelier exam.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員は、全員がベーコンソムリエのしけんを受けることになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Looks like it'll be difficult for everyone to make it, yeah?
Context 3-JP: <jp>全員がさんかするのはむずかしそうですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is a villain, but his hobby is gardening.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは悪人だが、ガーデニングがしゅ味なんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is just playing an evildoer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは悪人をえんじているだけだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you really think it’s possible to differentiate between good people and bad people?
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前、本当に善人と悪人を区別することが可能だと思っているのか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Tranquilize</kanji> <kanji>pressure</kanji> with medication that helps with its <vocabulary>suppression</vocabulary>. Then you won't have to feel it anymore.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The police suppressed the demonstrators by the third day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察が三日がかりでデモ隊を鎮圧しました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>meet</kanji> enough <kanji>member</kanji>s you will become a <vocabulary>member</vocabulary> yourself!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That member seems to be a huge worrywart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの会員はかなり心配しょうのようなんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You may not be able to see it, but there's one more little member over there.
Context 2-JP: <jp>見えないかもしれませんが、そこにもう一人小さな会員がいるんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you have a membership card?
Context 3-JP: <jp>会員カードはお持ちですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The one floor is the first floor (or floor one). Pretty simple.

Unless you're British, that is. For you this is the ground floor!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the <jp>一</jp> though. It gets shortened and has a little <jp>っ</jp> in there.
Context 1-EN: Do you have those snakes on the first floor?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヘビたちは一階でかっているんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The ground floor is still wet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一階はまだまだびちょびちょだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Where should I put my stuff?" "Here, the first floor, the second floor, anywhere. You can put them any place you’d like." "Okay. Thank you."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「荷物はどこに置いたらいいかな？」「一階でも、二階でも、下でも、どこでも。あなたの好きなところに置いてくれていいよ。」「わかったわ。有難う。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>move</kanji>s you make are <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>s. They're the <vocabulary>activities</vocabulary> you do every day to stay fit and healthy!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Kristen is an active cosplayer on weekends.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クリステンは、週末はコスプレイヤーとして活動しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I study biology in the mornings and afternoons at college, and in the late afternoon, I engage in religious activities.
Context 2-JP: <jp>午前と午後は大学で生物学を勉強し、夕方からはしゅう教活動をしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Action verbs are one of the four verb types categorized from the aspect perspective.
Context 3-JP: <jp>活動動詞とは動詞を相の観点から四つに分けた内の一つです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>shallow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>shallow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this <reading><jp>あさ</jp></reading>
Context 1-EN: This beach is shallow, so even kids can swim safely here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この海は浅いから子どもも安心して泳げます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't want to become a person with shallow thoughts.
Context 2-JP: <jp>考えの浅い人間にはなりたくありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever I get drunk, I only get light sleep and wake up early in the morning.
Context 3-JP: <jp>酔っ払うと、眠りが浅くなっちゃって、早朝覚醒しちゃうんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>cat</kanji> is an adorable <vocabulary>kitten</vocabulary>. D'awww!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word <jp>子</jp> (<jp>こ</jp>) and the reading for cat (<jp>ねこ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: The kitten jumped nimbly from branch to branch.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その子猫は、えだからえだを軽かいにとびうつりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I uploaded a video to Youtube of a kitty walking clockwise, round and round.
Context 2-JP: <jp>子猫が時計回りにクルクル歩き回っている動画をYoutubeにアップロードしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We just found this kitten and we’re looking for the owner.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達、ちょうどこの子猫を見つけて、飼い主をさがしているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>go</kanji> to <kanji>move</kanji> you're actually making an <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>. It's these <vocabulary>behavior</vocabulary>s when you go and move that determine what people think about you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is the result of your conduct.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これはあなたの行動がまねいたけっかです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's behavioral patterns are always the same.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつもコウイチの行動パターンは決まっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What they say and what they do don't match up, so I always have a hard time and get confused.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの人は発言と行動が一致していないからいつも惑わされて困る。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>rich</kanji> and <kanji>abundant</kanji>, you are super <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>, probably.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do we separate people into the rich and the poor?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして人は富裕層と貧困層に分けられるのでしょうか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is tough, because there's another word in this level (<jp>着る</jp>) that means "to wear" that is so similar. This word, however, means <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>. You should have seen that meaning with the kanji <jp>着</jp> as well, so I hope that helps. To differentiate between this and <jp>着る</jp>, though, zoom in on the <jp>く</jp>. You want to be <reading>coo</reading>l (<jp>く</jp>) so you arrive to the party late.
Reading Mnemonic:
This uses a different kun'yomi reading than the one you just learned (sorry). To help you, think about this:

You wanted to arrive on time but you showed up late. How late were you? Two (つ) hours and two minutes late, to be exact.
Context 1-EN: I've just arrived at Narita Airport.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今、成田空港に着きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let me know when you figure out what time you will arrive.
Context 2-JP: <jp>着く時間が分かったら、またれんらくして。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The train didn’t arrive on time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電車が時間通りに着かなかったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, <reading><jp>あき</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Fall is my absolute favorite season.
Context 1-JP: <jp>秋はわたしの一番好きなきせつです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you hear "fall" what do you associate it with? As you can probably imagine, I do think of "fall appetites."
Context 2-JP: <jp>秋と言えば何を思いうかべますか。わたしはやっぱり食よくの秋ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Hot water</kanji>'s <kanji>energy</kanji> isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The ゆ part of the reading makes sense. The げ part for 気 is a bit of an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help with that:

No creature likes steam and vapor more than geckos (げ). Geckos live in hot places, so wherever you see steam, you'll be sure to see at least one gecko nearby, if you look hard enough.

Context 2-EN: That's still steaming hot, so be careful.

And <jp>さん</jp> becomes <jp>ざん</jp> thanks to our old friend rendaku.

Meaning: To Be Involved With,To Be Connected With,To Be Affected,To Have To Do With
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>connection</kanji>. This is a verb, so one meaning is <vocabulary>to be connected with</vocabulary>. There are many other ways to say this too. This word is a bit full featured. You can say <vocabulary>to be involved with</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary>to be affected</vocabulary>. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want <vocabulary>to be connected with</vocabulary> them.

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>落ちる</jp> means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to stream</vocabulary> (though it's also <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from <jp>流す</jp> because with <jp>流す</jp> you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) the toilet maker. With <jp>流れる</jp> you find a <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>流す</jp>. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!
