Most likely you have. This is <vocabulary>origami</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>art of paper folding</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>折る</jp> and the vocab word <jp>紙</jp>. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.
Context 1-EN: Today, in Koichi's bento box, there were some origami instead of food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日のコウイチの弁当箱の中には、なぜか食べ物の代わりに折り紙が入っていました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>私はプロの折り紙アーティストです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to thank everyone who has shown me support over the years. Thankfully, I’ve finally mastered how to make an origami Fugu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のことをこの数年間支えてくれたみなさん、本当に有難うございます。お陰様で、ついに折り紙で河豚が折れるようになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>私立</jp>, which is "private," and you've seen <jp>大学</jp>, which is "college" or "university." So, combine them together and you have a <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the readings of the words <jp>私立</jp> and <jp>大学</jp> you'll be able to read this. It's also all jukugo on'yomi readings too, so you can read it that way.
Context 1-EN: Tuition for private universities is more expensive than that of public universities.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私立大学は公立大学よりじゅ業料が高いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Waseda University is a famous, private university in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わせ田大学は日本の有名な私立大学です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The private college that’s on fire is the college I’m currently attending.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの出火した私立大学は、私が通っている学校だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>妥協</jp> means <kanji>compromise</kanji>. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to compromise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the vocab word <jp>妥協</jp>, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).
Context 1-EN: We compromised on 100,000 yen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>十万円で妥協しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi and Viet compromised by going to McDonald's.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチとビエトは、マクドナルドに行くことで妥協しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey Salmon, did you and Fugu have to make any compromises when you first moved in together?" "Well, not me, but Fugu did."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、サーモン。あんたとフグが一緒に住み始めた時、やっぱり二人とも妥協しなきゃいけなかった？」「うーん。私はしなかったけど、フグはね！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You hopefully know that <jp>要求</jp> is a <kanji>demand</kanji>. When you make that a verb it becomes <vocabulary>to demand</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word <jp>要求</jp>. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.
Context 1-EN: Don't demand too much from him, okay?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんまりむ理なことを要求するなよ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: They are demanding we compromise on the price.
Context 2-JP: <jp>先方は、か格の点で妥協するようこちらに要求してきています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When he demanded money from me I told him to kiss my ass. Then I was beaten up and he forcibly stole the money from my wallet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼にお金を要求されたから、ふざけるなって言ってやったんだけど、そしたらボコボコにされて、財布から無理やりお金を盗られちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>卒業</jp> is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to graduate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the same as the vocab word <jp>卒業</jp>.
Context 1-EN: After graduating from university, I was able to, uneventfully, get a job at my company of choice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学を卒業した後、ぶ事に第一希望の会社にしゅうしょくすることができました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Are you saying that you can't graduate from high school because you haven't attended enough? Don't be ridiculous.
Context 2-JP: <jp>出せき日数が足りなくて高校を卒業できないだって？冗談だろう？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My brother overcame his disability and graduated from college. I’m very proud of him. His graduation is the result of his determination and effort.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の兄は障害を乗り越え、大学を卒業しました。私は兄をとても誇りに思います。大学卒業は彼の決意と努力の賜物です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji> that takes place is something that shouldn't have happened (but it did). This is a <vocabulary>strange incident</vocabulary>. The difference between this and <jp>事変</jp> is that while <jp>事変</jp> can also be used to describe a strange incident, it also can be used to talk about another type of incident as well. For example, the "Manshuu Jihen" is the "Manshuu Incident." This word, <jp>変事</jp> is more just a strange or unusual incident.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Because of the sudden, strange incident, today's stock market is in a grave situation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とつ然の変事で、今日のかぶ式市場は大変なことになっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: All WaniKani users were worried that some unusual incident had befallen Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグに何か変事が起きたんじゃないかと、全ワニカニユーザーが心配していたんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I always get excited during that ominous silence that happens before an unusual incident.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は変事の前の不気味な静けさにいつもワクワクする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>建築</jp> is architecture. So, someone of <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>architecture</kanji> is someone who does architecture. They are an <vocabulary>architect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read <jp>建築</jp> already.
Context 1-EN: Dad is very proud of you because you became an architect.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お父さん、あんたが建築家になったから、鼻が高いのよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The doctor incorrectly diagnosed the architect with stomach cancer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>医者は、その建築家をあやまって胃がんだとしんだんしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My house was designed by a famous architect.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の家は有名な建築家によって設計されたんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> part of <kanji>Europe</kanji> is <vocabulary>Central Europe</vocabulary>, wherever that is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ve wanted to travel around Central Europe for a really long time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>中欧を旅してみたいなと随分長い間思っていたんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: The best thing to <kanji>receive</kanji> and <kanji>accept</kanji> into your life is <vocabulary>enjoyment</vocabulary>! Don't block it out, let it in! Be happy!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our company is enjoying the benefits of cheap yen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我が社は円安の恩恵をもろに享受しているんだ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>泣く</jp> is to cry, so you can probably guess that <jp>泣き</jp> is just "cry." You've also seen how <jp>虫</jp> is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a <vocabulary>crybaby</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>泣く</jp> and <jp>虫</jp>. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: Hey, crybaby Ko-chan. Here comes a tunnel you like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>泣き虫コウちゃーん、ほら、コウちゃんの好きなトンネルだよーっ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Only Koichi knows Viet is a crybaby.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチだけがビエトが泣き虫だということを知っている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My daughter's high fever doesn't seem to be coming down. She is usually a crybaby, but it seems like she doesn't even have energy to cry now and I'm worried.
Context 3-JP: <jp>娘の高熱が中々下がりません。普段は泣き虫なんですが、今は泣く元気も無いようで、心配です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious <vocabulary>lunch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the words <jp>昼</jp> and <jp>ご飯</jp>. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: My boyfriend started drooling when he saw some cute girl even though we were eating lunch together.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれったら、私と一しょに昼ご飯を食べている時に、他のかわいい女を見て鼻の下をのばしてたんだから。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Oh no, I was thinking of doing okonomiyaki for lunch, but I forgot that we ran out of sauce.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あ、まずい！昼ご飯はお好みやきにしようと思ってたのに、ソースが切れてるのわすれてた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh no, I just burned the toast again. That was the last slice. Now I have to find something else for lunch.
Context 3-JP: <jp>しまったぁ、またトーストを焦がしちゃったよ。最後の一枚だったのに。何か別のものを昼ご飯に探さなくちゃ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>除く</jp> is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>除く</jp>. It's just the te-form of it.
Context 1-EN: She managed to do well on those tricky jobs... except for that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は厄介な仕事をうまくやってのけた…あることを除いて、だが。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: This takes the <kanji>luck</kanji> meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary> because of it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary>-filled?
Context 1-EN: If you're lucky, you may be able to meet Koichi from Tofugu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>運が良ければ、トーフグのコウイチに会えるかもね。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>たまたま運が良かっただけだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I might have run out of luck though, and I don't want to use it up on something like this.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こんなことで使い果たしたくはないけど、これで運を使い果たしちゃったかも。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right side</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word <jp>右</jp> by now. Also, the <jp>側</jp> reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word <jp>側</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The steering wheels of Japanese cars are usually on the right side.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の自動車のハンドルは通常右側にあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There's a lot of salt in the right-hand drawer of Koichi's desk.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのつくえの右側の引き出しには、塩がたくさん入っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We took a picture of a ghost. Look. There is a little girl who wasn’t there on the right in the picture. Can you see her?
Context 3-JP: <jp>心霊写真を撮っちゃったの。ほら。この写真の右側に、その場にはいなかった幼い女の子が写ってるのよ。分かる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>West</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> of something is known as the <vocabulary>West</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>West side</vocabulary>. Sorry, I have no story to go along with your West side.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You should know both of them, with <jp>西</jp> being <jp>にし</jp> and <jp>側</jp> being <jp>がわ</jp> (what you learned with the kanji).
Context 1-EN: I'm working at the post office on the west side of this town.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この町の西側のゆう便局で働いています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Which countries are considered Western countries?
Context 2-JP: <jp>西側しょ国とみなされるのはどの国ですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you eat makizushi on Feb 3rd of this year, you have to face west.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今年の二月三日に巻き寿司を食べるなら、西側を向いて食べなくてはいけませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>East side</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>東口</jp> read as <jp>ひがしぐち</jp>? This word is like that too, with <jp>東</jp> being read as <jp>ひがし</jp>. <jp>側</jp> is read like you learned it with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The agar factory is on the east side of that street.
Context 1-JP: <jp>寒天工場なら、その道路の東側にあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a dish that's eaten in the Eastern region of the Mediterranean.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こちらは、地中海東側の地いきで食べられている料理です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s on the east side of the airport, so just go east on Dundas for about thirty minutes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>飛行場の東側なので、ダンダス通りを真っ直ぐ東側に三十分ぐらい行くと着きますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main cause</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>primary cause</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The primary cause of my diarrhea is probably the soft serve I ate just now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>下りの主因はおそらくさっき食べたソフトクリームです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The main cause behind the near-miss is that the train sped up when it wasn't supposed to.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ニアミスの主因は、この電車がスピードを上げるべきではないタイミングで上げたことです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The main causes behind many conditions like cancer and autism are still unknown.
Context 3-JP: <jp>癌や自閉症など、多くの病気の主因は未だに分かっていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> thing you <kanji>make</kanji> is the <vocabulary>original work</vocabulary>. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Comic book movies often lose the flavor of the original work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マンガが原作の映画は、原作の良さを失ってしまうことが多いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you read Shakespeare's original works?
Context 2-JP: <jp>シェイクスピアを原作で読んだことはありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: This manga was made into a TV anime and drama series.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この漫画は、テレビアニメとドラマの原作です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is still just another <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I cannot get the soldier's cry out of my head.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの兵士の泣き声が頭からはなれません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The soldier set Koichi’s car on fire.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その兵士はコウイチの車に火を付けた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The soldier walked at a brisk pace thinking about how long distances feel much longer without any companions.
Context 3-JP: <jp>仲間がいないといつもの道が遠く感じると思いながら、兵士は足早に歩いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> with <kanji>salt</kanji> in it is <vocabulary>salt water</vocabulary>. Best not to drink <jp>塩水</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know <jp>塩</jp>'s from the kanji and you know <jp>水</jp>'s from the vocab word <jp>水</jp>. Combine them together and you have <reading><jp>しおみず</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I thought I had a good nose, but I couldn't tell which one was salt water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鼻が利く方だと思っていたんだが、どちらが塩水か分からなかった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think puffer fish dipped in salt water and dried in the sun would be pretty tasty.
Context 2-JP: <jp>塩水につけて天日干ししたフグってきっと美味しくなると思うんだけどなあ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The temperature itself isn't that high, but the sun's rays are really strong, so why don't you take some salt water to prevent heatstroke?
Context 3-JP: <jp>気温はそんなに高くないけど、日差しは強いから、熱射病対策で塩水を持って行った方がいいんじゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In <kanji>defense</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji>, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good <vocabulary>hygiene</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As the dental hygienist told me to open my mouth I saw a flash of white teeth from her tanned face.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その歯科衛生士は、お口を開けてください、と私に言いながらにやりと笑い、日焼けした顔に白い歯をキラリと見せた。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>s are what you have in your regular <vocabulary>everyday life</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>normal life</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I want to know what Koichi's daily work life is like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの日常の仕事がどんなものなのか知りたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My daily life is very ordinary.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の日常はとても平ぼんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you learn a new language, it’s more efficient to begin with everyday, practical words at first.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しい言語を学ぶ際、まず始めに日常で一般的に使われる実用的な言葉から覚える方が効率的だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need to dry something off? Because someone used a <reading>hose</reading> (<jp>ほす</jp>) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...
Context 1-EN: I told you not to put the sweater in the dryer but to hang dry it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>セーターはかんそうきに入れないで、干してねって言ったじゃない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think that comedian has definitely been deprived of any chance to appear on television recently. Don't you agree?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの芸人、ぜっ対最近干されてるよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wanted to put our laundry outside to dry, but our clothesline just broke.
Context 3-JP: <jp>洗濯物を外に干したかったんだけど、物干し竿が壊れちゃって。</jp>

Meaning: Bottom Of One's Heart,Bottom Of My Heart
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bottom of one's heart</vocabulary>. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from <jp>心底</jp>? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: I'm sincerely happy that Koichi's incurable disease actually has been cured.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの不治の病が治って、心底うれしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think Koichi hates me from the bottom of his heart.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチには心底からきらわれていると思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There are a lot of nice people in my new department and I feel tremendously relieved.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しい部署、優しい人がいっぱいで、心底ホッとしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>ford</kanji>ing a stream, and you suddenly feel <kanji>dry</kanji> feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary>. It's an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary> trying to stop you from fording.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi warned workers not to interfere in his private life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、私生活への干渉はしないよう社員たちに注意しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I assume that both sides want to avoid armed intervention.
Context 2-JP: <jp>両国とも、ぶ力干渉はさけたいはずだと思うよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is definitely not the type of boss to interfere, but it seems he likes meddling in what Viet is doing for some reason.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、どんなことにも干渉してくるタイプの上司ではありませんが、何故かビエトが何をしているのかについては口出しするのが好きなようです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Tranquilize</kanji> your <kanji>pain</kanji> with a strong <kanji>dose</kanji> of <vocabulary>painkiller</vocabulary>s! Yum yum. Don't take too many though!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I received a shot of the painkiller from the doctor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>医者に鎮痛剤を注射してもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>love</kanji> for your <kanji>country</kanji> deep within your <kanji>heart</kanji>, that is <vocabulary>patriotism</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: A very patriotic man entered Tofugu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>愛国心がやたらに強い男が、トーフグに入社しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Michael composed a very patriotic 8-bit song.

Meaning Mnemonic: You helped your city <kanji>prosper</kanji>, and a <kanji>light</kanji> shines out of you, so that the entire city can bask in your <vocabulary>glory</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>ford</kanji> into the thick of things and <kanji>mix</kanji> everything up, you're getting involved in a <vocabulary>negotiation</vocabulary>. Meaning Mnemonic: Someone with "<kanji>nothing</kanji>" for their <kanji>name</kanji> is trying to remain <vocabulary>anonymous</vocabulary>.

Meaning: Tip Of The Nose,Tip Of Nose,Nose Tip
Meaning Mnemonic: You know the <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>nose</kanji>? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the <vocabulary>tip of the nose</vocabulary>. Time to cut off the rest, next!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With <jp>鼻</jp> you learned that with the kanji. With <jp>先</jp> you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.
Context 1-EN: You got mustard at the tip of your nose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鼻先にマスタードがついてるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That police dog started twitching the tip of its nose and sniffing at the stranger.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その警察犬は、鼻先をひくひくさせて、見知らぬ人のにおいをかぎ始めた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When Fugu saw that the tip of Salmon’s nose was so red, he found it very cute.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグはサーモンの鼻先が赤くなってるのを見て、とても可愛いと感じた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>nose</kanji> with <kanji>blood</kanji> is a nose with a <vocabulary>nosebleed</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>bloody nose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know <jp>鼻</jp>'s reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of <jp>血</jp> as well. Put them together and you have <jp>はなち</jp>, though you want to change the <jp>ち</jp> to <jp>ぢ</jp>. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as <jp>はなじ</jp>. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.
Context 1-EN: If you have a mustache it'll be a pain if your nose bleeds, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>鼻の下にひげをはやしていると、鼻血が出た時に大変ですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Excuse me. I just need a quick word with you. Your nose is bleeding.
Context 2-JP: <jp>すみません。ちょっと一言、言わせてもらいたいんだけど、あなた、鼻血が出てますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I tried to rush onto the train, but the doors closed, squished my nose and made it bleed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電車に駆け込み乗車をしようとして鼻が挟まれて、鼻血が出ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <jp>曜日</jp> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>tree</kanji> day of the week is <kanji>Thursday</kanji>. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>曜日</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: The gas pipe cracked on Thursday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>木曜日に、ガスパイプにヒビが入ってしまったんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think I'm gonna do the laundry on Thursday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>洗たくは、木曜日にしようと思ってます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On Thursday, do you want to do something fun like making a snowman or building an igloo?
Context 3-JP: <jp>木曜日に、雪だるまを作るとかかまくらを作るみたいな、何か楽しいことをしたくない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>news report</kanji> that covers things <kanji>beforehand</kanji> (before they happen) is a <vocabulary>forecast</vocabulary>. For example, a weather forecast is a <jp>天気予報</jp>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>news</kanji> is that it should give you <vocabulary>information</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>data</vocabulary>, not fluff.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>correct</kanji> way to <kanji>sit</kanji> is this way: <vocabulary>traditional Japanese sitting</vocabulary> (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). You can also call it <vocabulary>seiza</vocabulary>. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>留守</jp> means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's  turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the <vocabulary>caretaker</vocabulary>, someone who's <vocabulary>looking after one's house</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <jp>留守</jp> will be important as well.

Context 3-JP: <jp>２ヶ月間旅行したければ、留守番を雇う必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>forget</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to forget</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what <reading>was</reading> (<jp>わす</jp>) the reading? I <vocabulary>forget</vocabulary>... What was it?

Context 1-JP: <jp>ごめんね、カナエちゃん。みんなカナエちゃんがどれだけ努力したのかすっかり忘れちゃってたんだ。</jp>

Context 3-JP: <jp>もう忘れなって。過ぎてしまったことは今さらどうにもならないんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>path</kanji> of the <kanji>bow</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>archery</vocabulary>.

Meaning: Year End Party,End Of Year Party
Meaning Mnemonic: Time to get <kanji>together</kanji> and <kanji>forget</kanji> the <kanji>year</kanji>... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a <vocabulary>year end party</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>枚</jp> is a <kanji>flat objects counter</kanji>. So, now we're counting! You have <vocabulary>five flat objects</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning: To Bake,To Cook,To Grill,To Burn,To Fry
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bake</kanji> or <kanji>cook</kanji>. So, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cook</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I achieved my goal to bake one hundred cheesecakes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>チーズケーキを百こ焼くという目標を達しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I burned the letter when I made baked sweet potatoes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その手紙は焼いもと一しょに焼いてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Does your hubby bake cakes too?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの旦那さんも、ケーキを焼くの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>cook</kanji>s something, and that something is you, it is giving you <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have <jp>ひ</jp> for <jp>日</jp> and <jp>や</jp> for <jp>焼け</jp> (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: It seems like my daughter is deeply in love with that tan young man.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうやらうちの娘は、あの日焼けした青年への恋に胸をこがしているようです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Your back is super red from that sunburn.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日焼けでせ中が真っ赤になってるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In Hawaii, strong sunscreen is essential and covers are also used to protect people from getting sunburned.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ハワイでは強い日焼け止めが必需品で、人達を日焼けから守るのにシートで覆ったりもします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a <vocabulary>smoke</vocabulary> machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "<reading>Kay, Murray</reading> (<jp>けむり</jp>), it's time to stop that," you say.
Context 1-EN: The city of Portland was covered with fire and smoke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ポートランドの町は火と煙につつまれた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hey! Smoke is coming out of the grill!!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ちょっと！バーベキューグリルから煙が出ているよ！！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Viet was surprised to see smoke rising from the other side of Koichi’s computer because smoking is banned in the office.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトは、コウイチのパソコンの向こうから立ち上っている煙を見て驚きました。何故なら、オフィスは禁煙だったからです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pray</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pray</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray if you want Santa to bring you Christmas presents!" "<reading>I know</reading> (<jp>いの</jp>), I know," you reply as you begin to pray to Santa. You should say this out loud to remember it better.
Context 1-EN: I prayed for the hurricane victims.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ハリケーンのひがい者のために祈りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I will pray for your success on the national exam.
Context 2-JP: <jp>国家試験に無事合格できるように祈っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t think many Japanese people know Japan’s national sport "sumo" used to be a ritual to pray for a bountiful rice harvest.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の国技である相撲が、かつては米の豊作を祈る儀式だったことを知ってる日本人がたくさんいるとは思えないな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Marrow</kanji> that gives you <kanji>stature</kanji> is inside of your <vocabulary>spinal cord</vocabulary>.

Meaning: To Put On Shoes,To Put On Pants,To Put On Boots
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>boots</kanji>, but "to boots" doesn't make sense. What actions do you do with boots, though, usually? You put them on. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to put on shoes</vocabulary> (or boots, I guess). It's also <vocabulary>to put on pants</vocabulary>, probably because it's all kind of the same motion, no?
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide <vocabulary>to put on shoes</vocabulary>. That will teach Mrs. Chou and her streets! "<reading>HA</reading> (<jp>は</jp>) HA HA!" you laugh out loud like a maniac.

When a disaster strikes, you start moaning and groaning. Say it along with me: "Wahhhhh! Zaahhhh! Waahhhh!" (わざわ). Be careful of the い on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.
Context 1-EN: This is a lucky charm that protects you from misfortune.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、災いを防いでくれるお守りです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I believed in the phrase, "turn disaster into advantage," and it really worked.
Context 2-JP: <jp>災い転じて福となすという言葉を信じてがんばりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It seems like Shark wishes misfortune upon other people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>シャークは他人の災いを願っているようだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>disaster</kanji> that does <kanji>damage</kanji>. Usually these are <vocabulary>natural disaster</vocabulary>s, though they could also just be regular <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary>s as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There is nothing scarier than natural disasters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自然災害ほどおそろしいものはありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't understand why they built the nuclear power plant on a potential disaster site to begin with.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そもそも、どうして災害が起こる可能性の高い場所に原子力発電所を建てたのかが理かいできません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Each room has been prepared with flashlights and water bottles in case of a natural disaster.
Context 3-JP: <jp>それぞれの部屋には、災害の場合に備えて懐中電灯とペットボトルのお水が何本か用意してあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>smoke</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>smoky</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You sort of did learn this reading with the vocabulary word 煙, but this one is just different enough where we thought we should make a mnemonic for this one:

All this smokiness is from a terrible chemical (けむ) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smoky.
Context 1-EN: The entire town is smoky now due to the wildfire.
Context 1-JP: <jp>山火事のせいで町中が煙くなっているんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The smoky fireworks made me cough.
Context 2-JP: <jp>花火が煙くて、むせてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s so smoky! When the heck are you going to quit smoking? This really smells awful.
Context 3-JP: <jp>煙いなあ！一体いつになったら煙草やめるんだよ？本当に臭いんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is just that, an <vocabulary>earthquake disaster</vocabulary>. These are no good.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for <jp>災</jp> is the <jp>さい</jp> reading because *<reading>sigh</reading>* earthquakes suck man.
Context 1-EN: Because of the earthquake disaster, there are a lot of potholes on the ground now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>震災で、地面が穴ぼこだらけになってしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I still can't forget the trauma I experienced from the day of the earthquake disaster.
Context 2-JP: <jp>震災にあった日のことが、今でもわすれられないトラウマになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I go to Japan, I want to see the single pine tree that withstood the giant tsunami caused by the Great Tōhoku Earthquake in 2011.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本に行く時に、2011年の東北大震災の大津波に耐えた一本の松の木を見に行きたいです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grudge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hold a grudge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be <reading>you, Ra</reading> (<jp>うら</jp>). You and your dumb sun.
Context 1-EN: Why do you have a grudge against that stuntman?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてあのスタントマンを恨んでいるんだい？</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: It is <kanji>correct</kanji> and you're <kanji>certain</kanji> of it. When you've done this much checking and you're this sure, your measurements must be very <vocabulary>accurate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>precise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi doesn't know the accurate number of WaniKani users.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはワニカニの正確なユーザー数を知りません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Michael completed his mission to memorize Koichi's lunch request perfectly and order it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルはコウイチのランチリクエストを正確に記おくし、注文するというにんむを終えました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Actually, I’m pretty annoyed at how you have a comeback for everything and how what you say is so accurate.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君って、ああ言えばこう言うし、しかも言うことがどれもいちいち正確なのが結構頭にくるんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What's your <kanji>nose</kanji>'s <kanji>hole</kanji>? How about your <vocabulary>nostril</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings for <jp>鼻</jp> and <jp>穴</jp>. Smell that fresh air through your <vocabulary>nose hole</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: "Aren't the shapes of Koichi's nose holes a bit weird?" "Really? I think they are cute."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「コウイチの鼻の穴の形ってちょっと変じゃない？」「そう？私はかわいいと思うけど。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: When Koichi has a nose bleed, he sticks a tube-shaped fish paste cake in there to stop it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、鼻血が出てくる時は鼻の穴にチクワをさしこんで止血します。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Your nostril..." "What? I can’t hear you." "Well never mind. It’s nothing." "Now you have to tell me. What were you saying?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「君の鼻の穴…。」「何？聞こえないわ。」「ええっと、やっぱり何でもないよ。大したことじゃないから。」「教えてくれなきゃだめよ。何を言おうとしてたの？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Stand</kanji>ing and <kanji>enter</kanji>ing are both <jp>禁止</jp> (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying <vocabulary>do not enter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no entry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for 立入 is a bit strange, but it might help you to know that it can also be written 立ち入り. The 立ち is the same one you learned with 立ち飲み and the 入り is the reading you learned with 入り口. In our version of the word, the hiragana isn't visible (it's sort of pushed into the kanji), but the word is still pronounced the same way: たちいり.

And 禁止 doesn't have any weirdness going on, so at least you have that!
Context 1-EN: This door says Authorized Personnel Only.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このドアには、関係者以外立入禁止って書かれているよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The backroom of the grocery store is off-limits.
Context 2-JP: <jp>スーパーのバックヤードは立入禁止です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That is wild! I can’t believe you went into a place marked "Do Not Enter" and then peed in there!
Context 3-JP: <jp>それは大胆だね！君が本当に立入禁止って書いてる場所に入ってションベンしたなんて信じられないよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Through various <kanji>test</kanji>s over the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>, you have gained much <vocabulary>experience</vocabulary>. Time and testing is all it takes.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I've never had the experience of traveling by plane.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、飛行機で旅行をした経験がありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Has anyone else had the experience where you try to help a friend and then you get blamed instead?
Context 2-JP: <jp>友達を助けようとしたら、今度は非難のほこ先が自分に向いてしまうという経験をしたことがある人はいますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Oh! Have you tried marriage counseling yet?" "Of course. We experienced that a long time ago but it went badly."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「そうだ、結婚カウンセリングは試してみたの？」 「もちろん、とっくに経験済みだわよ。でも、上手くいかなかったわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>経</jp> means <kanji>passage of time</kanji>, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to elapse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary> you by? "<reading>Ta</reading> ta (<jp>た</jp>), Time!"
Context 1-EN: I was so into the game I didn't notice the time pass.
Context 1-JP: <jp>時間が経つのを忘れて、ゲームに夢中になっていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many years have passed since Tofugu started?
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグができてから、もう何年経ちましたか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you think they will have a happy marriage?" "Time will tell."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「あいつら、幸せな結婚生活を送れると思う？」「時間が経てばわかるよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Trying to <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>fire</kanji>? Better get into <vocabulary>fire prevention</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I put my knowledge of fire prevention in writing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私なりの防火の心得を文章にまとめました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you can invent a paint that makes wood 100% fireproof, you'll be super rich.
Context 2-JP: <jp>木材にぬると完全防火すると料を発明することができれば、大金持ちになれますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How often does Tofugu have fire drills?
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguはどのくらいの頻度で防火訓練を実施しますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>degrees</kanji> is how you measure an earthquake. The <jp>震度</jp> is the <vocabulary>earthquake intensity</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>earthquake magnitude</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>seismic intensity</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seismic scale</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The seismic intensity was three, but it felt quite strong.
Context 1-JP: <jp>震度は3でしたがけっこうゆれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What’s the difference between magnitude and seismic scale?
Context 2-JP: <jp>マグニチュードと震度って、何が違うの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: They say the aftershocks from the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake hit a magnitude of seven, and that they'll continue for the next hundred years, even the big ones.
Context 3-JP: <jp>2011年に震度七を記録した東日本大震災の余震は、今後百年程は続き、巨大余震もあるだろうと言われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You meet an artisan and they're tacking pictures on a wall to sell. You want the artisan to make a picture of you too so you yell, "TACK ME (たくみ)!"
Context 1-EN: This product’s design was the first time I was able to implement that technique.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この商品のデザインは、匠の技をもって初めて実現することができました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>government office</kanji> for police (<jp>警察</jp>) is a <vocabulary>police station</vocabulary>, because that's where they hang out, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What's the use in going to the police station?
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察署へ行って、何の得があるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I found a wallet and brought it to the police station, then they took my fingerprints.
Context 2-JP: <jp>財布をひろったので警察署にとどけたら、指もんをとられました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wish there was always someone who could speak English in police stations in Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の警察署に英語が喋れる人が常駐してたらいいのにな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fly</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When you try <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>, the main thing holding you back is your <reading>toe</reading> (<jp>と</jp>). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.
Context 1-EN: When we arrived at a park, there were a lot of bubbles floating in the air.
Context 1-JP: <jp>公園につくと、たくさんのシャボン玉が空を飛んでいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi may not look like he is able to do something like that, but he can actually jump very high.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ああ見えて、コウイチはすごく高く飛ぶことができるんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu’s latest e-book is flying off the shelves.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの最新のEブックは、飛ぶように売れています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The people who will <kanji>review</kanji> a <kanji>problem</kanji> are those who know more about the problems. They are the <vocabulary>advisor</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Rumor has it, he’s a good coach for the basketball club.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は良いバスケ部の顧問だとの評判があります。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>steam</kanji> <kanji>ship</kanji> is a <vocabulary>steam ship</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>steam boat</vocabulary>. So fancy back in their day!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How big is this steam ship compared to the rest in this country?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この汽船は、あなたの国で何番目に大きい汽船ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: We chartered a steam boat for our trip to Singapore.
Context 2-JP: <jp>汽船を一台借り切って、シンガポールへ行きました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How can we finance our trip around the world by steam boat?
Context 3-JP: <jp>汽船での世界一周旅行の費用なんて、どうやって捻出するんだよ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>explanation</kanji> (<jp>説明</jp>) in <kanji>writing</kanji> is a <vocabulary>written explanation</vocabulary>. I guess sometimes you don't want to do your explanations in person, huh?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The instructions for the ice cream maker I bought yesterday were missing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日買ったアイスクリームメーカーに説明書がついていませんでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you play a new game, are you the type of person who reads the instructions first or do you start playing without reading them?
Context 2-JP: <jp>新しいゲームをする時に説明書を読んでから始めるタイプですか。それとも、説明書は読まずにいきなり始めるタイプですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are currently looking for someone who can translate some instructions written in Japanese into English.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達は現在、日本語で書かれた説明書を英語に翻訳してくださる方を探しています。</jp>

Meaning: To Become Muddy,To Become Impure,To Become Cloudy
Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>濁す</jp> means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means <vocabulary>to become muddy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as <jp>濁す</jp>. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.
Context 1-EN: The air in the room is getting cloudy with tobacco smoke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>煙草の煙で部屋の空気が濁っています。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>flute</kanji>... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By <vocabulary>whistling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank <jp>口</jp> for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have <jp>口</jp> (<jp>くち</jp>) and <jp>笛</jp> (<jp>ふえ</jp>) put together, though <jp>ふえ</jp> changes to <jp>ぶえ</jp>, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.
Context 1-EN: My dog doesn’t come to my whistle because I’m bad at whistling.
Context 1-JP: <jp>口笛が下手くそなので、私が口笛を吹いても犬が来てくれません。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>chest</kanji> is <kanji>cook</kanji>ing and <kanji>burn</kanji>ing, you have what's known as <vocabulary>heartburn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings (hint is that there's hiragana sticking out there). So, just make sure you know the word <jp>胸</jp> and <jp>焼く</jp>. If you do, you can combine that knowledge into this word, and hopefully not get any heartburn in the process.
Context 1-EN: How many times can you jump rope when you're suffering from heartburn?
Context 1-JP: <jp>胸焼けしている時に、なわとびで何回飛べますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: It may be because of my age, but I get heartburn when I eat deep-fried food.
Context 2-JP: <jp>年を取ったせいか、あげ物を食べると胸焼けがするんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t you get heartburn from eating katsu-don in the morning?
Context 3-JP: <jp>朝からカツ丼なんて、胸焼けしないの？</jp>

Meaning: To Be Amazed,To Be Shocked,To Be Astonished
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shock</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be shocked</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be amazed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you were going to be shocked, you'd shout, "ACK (あき)!"
Context 1-EN: The phrase the idol repeatedly snapped shocked the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイドルの度重なるプッツン発言に、世間はみんな呆れました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Meaning Mnemonic: You have an <kanji>electronic</kanji> (<jp>電子</jp>) <kanji>container</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji>. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. It is, basically, just <vocabulary>electronic equipment</vocabulary>. Though, you can say <vocabulary>electronics</vocabulary> if that's easier for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please turn off all personal electronic devices or set them to airplane mode on this plane. Thank you for your cooperation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>機内ではお手持ちの電子機器の電げんはお切りになるか機内モードにごせっ定くださいますよう、ご協力お願い申し上げます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We manually check electronic equipment one by one to make sure there are no defects.
Context 2-JP: <jp>電子機器に欠かんが無いか、一個ずつ手作業で確認しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why did some airlines start relaxing their rules about the use of electronics during flights?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうしていくつかの航空会社は、飛行中の電子機器の使用についての規制を緩和し始めたんでしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>焼く</jp> is <vocabulary>to cook</vocabulary>? Well, <jp>焼ける</jp> is <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>. This is when you're not doing the actual cooking, and the cooking is just happening. Can also refer to when something burns, making it <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>焼く</jp>, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: My house was burned in a fire.
Context 1-JP: <jp>火事で家が焼けてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>このパンはこんがりとよく焼けています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "This meat is thick, so I think it'll be a while until it's cooked." "I think it'll cook while you're doing the dishes."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「この肉は厚いから、焼けるまでに時間がかかりそうだね。」「あなたが皿洗いをしている間に、焼けると思うけど。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>child</kanji>ren are the same as each other. They're <vocabulary>twins</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is like <jp>二人</jp>, (the <jp>ふた</jp> part) plus <jp>子</jp>, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: "Is it a boy or a girl?" "They are actually twin boys."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「男の子ですか？女の子ですか？」「実は双子の男の子なんです。」</jp>
Context 2-JP: None
Context 3-EN: None
Context 3-JP: None

Reading Mnemonic: The reading is that of <jp>履く</jp> and <jp>物</jp> put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語で、屋内の履き物は「上履き」、屋外の履き物は「外履き」と呼ばれます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>主義</jp> is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to <kanji>protect</kanji> and <kanji>conserve</kanji> their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's <vocabulary>conservatism</vocabulary> and they're <vocabulary>conservative</vocabulary> people.

This word uses a new kun'yomi reading for 生 and a new on'yomi reading for 地. You haven't learned either of these readings yet, sorry! Here's some mnemonics to help you:
